outcome: The proposed model, even with its simple architecture, demonstrates competitive performance when compared with pretrained models. The results also highlight the role of the citation graph in understanding the content of papers and generating high-quality summaries.
future_impact: The research suggests that the citation graph is crucial for better understanding the content of papers and generating high-quality summaries and paves the way for future research in enhancing scientific paper summarization using citation networks.
title: Enhancing Scientific Papers Summarization With Citation Graph

context: In the Multi-Armed Bandit (MAB) problem, most algorithms focus on minimizing regret, which can lead to over-exploration in larger problems or brief interaction environments. These algorithms often struggle to find the optimal arm and therefore may produce undesirable results.
key_idea: The authors propose a novel, more lenient regret criterion for the MAB problem that disregards suboptimality gaps smaller than a certain threshold. Furthermore, they suggest a variant of the Thompson Sampling (TS) algorithm, referred to as (sic)-TS, that operates according to this new lenient regret criterion.
method: The authors demonstrate the performance and efficiency of the proposed (sic)-TS algorithm theoretically, proving its asymptotic optimality in terms of the lenient regret.
outcome: It is shown that when the mean of the optimal arm is high enough, the lenient regret of (sic)-TS is bounded by a constant, indicating efficiency under certain conditions.
future_impact: (sic)-TS can potentially improve performance in scenarios where the agent knows a lower bound of the suboptimality gaps, paving the way for better action decisions in MAB problem settings.
title: Lenient Regret For Multi-Armed Bandits

context: Assignments form the core of student learning experience in AI education and the need for innovative assignment designs is recognized by the community.
key_idea: The Abstract introduces the 'Model AI Assignments' session which is a platform that gathers and disseminates superior AI assignment designs from the educational community.
method: The session presents selected abstracts of six AI assignments from the 2021 session that meet specific criteria including adaptability, playful engagement, and flexibility.
outcome: The session successfully collected and presented six AI assignments which are adoptable, engaging and flexible for different instructor needs.
future_impact: The assignments presented can be used by instructors in the AI education community to enhance the student learning experience. The supporting resources and specifications for these assignments are available online for further adoption and adaptation.
title: Model Ai Assignments 2021

context: The ongoing research has been focusing on the facility location problem under a model where monetary transfers between the mechanism and the agents are not possible (no-money constraint) and facilities serve different purposes (heterogeneity). Previous studies mostly use utilitarian optimization methods.
key_idea: This study proposes to use non-utilitarian optimization functions for such problems, specifically focusing on minimizing the maximum connection cost of the agents.
method: The authors investigate both deterministic and randomized algorithms and derive both lower and upper bounds for the approximability of strategyproof mechanisms.
outcome: The study derived lower and upper bounds regarding the approximability of strategyproof mechanisms when non-utilitarian optimization functions are applied in facility location problem.
future_impact: This study sets a precedent for using non-utilitarian optimization functions in heterogeneous facility location problems which could inspire future development of algorithms and mechanisms in this area.
title: Truthful mechanisms without money for non-utilitarian heterogeneous facility location

context: Speech enhancement is challenging due to the diversity of background noise types. Most of the current methods are focused on modelling the speech rather than the noise.
key_idea: The authors propose a novel model called SN-Net that simultaneously models speech and noise using a two-branch convolutional neural network. One branch predicts speech and the other predicts noise. The model introduces interaction modules at several intermediate feature domains to benefit each other.
method: The authors evaluated their model using various evaluation metrics on public datasets.
outcome: The authors discovered that the interaction module played a key role in simultaneous modeling, and their proposed SN-Net outperformed the state-of-the-art methods by a large margin on various evaluation metrics.
future_impact: The proposed SN-Net also showed superior performance for speaker separation, suggesting potential for future use in speaker separation tasks.
title: Interactive Speech And Noise Modeling For Speech Enhancement

context: Code clone detection has attracted significant attention from researchers, and many methods have been proposed. However, these existings methods lack robustness against adversarial revisions of the code, as they do not consider the dynamic 'contest' between plagiarists (the code clone creators) and detectors.
key_idea: This paper proposes a novel clone detection approach, Adversarial Clone Detection (ACD), which mimics the adversarial process between plagiarists and detectors. It is designed to build a robust clone detectector and also to model the behavior of plagiarists.
method: The authors model the adversarial process and use the learned policy of the plagiarist to construct the clone detector.
outcome: Experiments show that the plagiarist's learned policy can help in building a stronger clone detector, substantially outperforming existing clone detection methods.
future_impact: The understanding and modeling of plagiarist behavior may help identify the vulnerabilities of current software clone detection tools, potentially leading to improved clone detection methods.
title: Find Me If You Can: Deep Software Clone Detection by Exploiting the Contest between the Plagiarist and the Detector

context: Existing methods of extracting values from key fields in form-like documents often ignore the semantics of the keys, considering them only as class labels. This leaves them incapable to handle zero-shot keys. Although these models often leverage attention mechanisms, the learned features may not accurately reflect why humans would recognise the value for the key, and thus may not generalise well to new documents.
key_idea: The authors propose a Key-Aware and Trigger-Aware (KATA) extraction model which uses the input key to explicitly learn two mappings: from key representations to trigger representations, and then from trigger representations to values. These mappings could be intrinsic and invariant across different keys and documents.
method: The model uses a large training set constructed based on Wikipedia data to pre-train these two mappings. It is then fine-tuned to two applications.
outcome: The proposed KATA model achieves more than 70% accuracy for the extraction of zero-shot keys, at which all previous methods fail.
future_impact: This approach can improve the performance of many downstream applications such as knowledge base construction, question answering, document comprehension and could potentially generalize to new documents.
title: Extracting Zero-Shot Structured Information From Form-Like Documents: Pretraining With Keys And Triggers

context: Propositional Power Default Reasoning (PDR) is a form of non-monotonic reasoning where the underlying logic is Kleene's 3-valued propositional logic, known for its complex skeptical entailment problem.
key_idea: PDR provides a more concise meaning of the problem of skeptical entailment, which in turn has better complexity characteristics than the usual formalisms.
method: An implementation called 'powdef' is created to encode and solve hard graph problems and explore instances of skeptical entailment generated randomly.
outcome: The implementation shows that PDR has better complexity characteristics than usual formalisms, with complexity co-NP(3)-Complete instead of ?2P-Complete.
future_impact: The improved efficiency of PDR in terms of complexity could be beneficial in solving hard graph problems and other applications requiring non-monotonic reasoning.
title: Experimenting with power default reasoning

context: Learning effective embeddings for irregularly sampled time-series that operate on different time scales is crucial for tasks like classification and clustering. Existing time-series similarity measures aren't valid distance metrics, making it challenging to accurately capture the relationships in multivariate time-series data and learn useful embeddings. Traditional Monte-Carlo-based expectation evaluations for measuring distances face difficulties due to high data dimensionality and the inability to sample from encapsulating distributions.
key_idea: The authors introduce a novel distance metric, I-SEA, that leverages Importance Sampling and Non-parametric Density Estimation. Unlike earlier measures, I-SEA focuses on adaptively estimating distances and enables implicit estimation from high-dimensional distributions, leading to increased accuracy and reduced variance.
method: The authors delineate the properties of I-SEA theoretically and verify its capabilities through experimental evaluations on real-world healthcare datasets.
outcome: I-SEA, the proposed distance metric demonstrated superior performance in tasks such as classification and representation learning and showed improved accuracy and reduced variance when evaluated on real-world healthcare datasets.
future_impact: The development of I-SEA opens new possibilities for learning effective embeddings for time-series data, potentially improving the performance of machine learning tasks such as classification and representation learning particularly in complex fields like healthcare.
title: I-SEA: Importance Sampling and Expected Alignment-Based Deep Distance Metric Learning for Time Series Analysis and Embedding.

context: Previous approaches to generating complex scenes with multiple objects from layouts face some problems. These include the generation of spurious objects not corresponding to bounding boxes in the layout and the merging of objects in the images due to overlapping bounding boxes in the layout.
key_idea: The main idea is the Object-Centric Generative Adversarial Network (OC-GAN), a new image generation method based on Scene-Graph Similarity Module (SGSM) that understands individual objects and their relationships. In addition, changes are proposed to the generator's conditioning mechanism to improve object instance-awareness.
method: Durability and performance of the proposed OC-GAN is evaluated through quantitative evaluation and ablation studies, using COCO-Stuff and Visual Genome datasets.
outcome: OC-GAN improves image quality, and alleviates previously identified failure modes. It outperforms past state-of-the-art techniques on both the COCO-Stuff and Visual Genome datasets.
future_impact: The paper introduces an object-centric adaptation of the Frechet Inception Distance metric, called Scene-FID. This new metric, being more suited for multi-object images, could be influential in the evaluation of future layout-to-image generation methods.
title: Object-Centric Image Generation From Layouts

context: The task of inferring causal relationships from patterns of dependencies in the context of constructing probabilistic networks from human judgments is less understood, particularly determining the directionality of interactions from non-temporal probabilistic information.
key_idea: This paper develops efficient algorithm for inferring the directionality of interactions from non-temporal probabilistic information, a crucial step in attributing a causal interpretation to these interactions.
method: An efficient algorithm is developed that recovers the structure of the underlying causal polytree given data generated by an undisclosed causal polytree and also determines the directionality of all its identifiable links.
outcome: The authors created an efficient algorithm capable of determining the directionality of identifiable links and the underlying structure of causal polytrees.
future_impact: The development of this algorithm could pave the way for improved and more accurate inference of causal relationships from patterns of dependency, which would have implications in the construction of probabilistic networks from human judgments.
title: Learning causal trees from dependence information

context: While rescaling the classes according to their misclassification costs is a popular approach to cost-sensitive learning in binary-class problems, recent studies show that it is often not effective when applied to multi-class problems directly.
key_idea: This paper proposes a new approach to rescaling for multi-class cost-sensitive learning, which should be chosen if the user wishes to utilize rescaling for such problems. Before applying rescaling, however, the consistency of the costs must be examined.
method: The authors analyze why the traditional rescaling approach often proves ineffective on multi-class problems, and through this analysis, introduce a new approach for using rescaling in multi-class cost-sensitive learning.
outcome: The authors demonstrate that the proposed method is effective when unequal misclassification costs and class imbalances occur simultaneously and that it can also handle pure class-imbalance learning.
future_impact: This new approach provides a unified framework for addressing multi-class cost-sensitive learning as well as multi-class class-imbalance learning, paving the way for further research in these areas.
title: On multi-class cost-sensitive learning

context: Relational learning has enabled new machine learning applications, but efficient knowledge extraction from such networks is a challenge. Specifically, the CILP++ system that depends on the BCP propositionalization algorithm struggles with the issue that the features generated by BCP lack independent relational description which hinders sound knowledge extraction.
key_idea: The paper presents a methodology for generating independent propositional features for BCP using semi-propositionalization of bottom clauses, aiming to allow proper relational knowledge representation and extraction from CILP++ networks.
method: The proposed semi-propositionalization method is tested through empirical results, comparing accuracy and runtimes with the original version of BCP.
outcome: The new semi-propositionalization approach exhibits comparable accuracy and runtime to the original BCP while enabling proper relational knowledge representation of features.
future_impact: The proposed approach will improve knowledge extraction in neural-symbolic systems like CILP++, which will enhance the application of these systems in various areas such as link analysis in social networks and graph mining.
title: Neural Relational Learning Through Semi-Propositionalization of Bottom Clauses

context: Prior to this study, the design of algorithms has been a manual and expertise-intensive process, necessitating the need for an automated system to design algorithms. Previous works have attempted to design such a system with mixed results.
key_idea: The author proposes a novel system for designing algorithms, which operates in two problem spaces -- one focusing on the algorithm itself and the other on the task-domain. The partially worked out algorithms are represented as configurations of dataflow components that construct and modify the representations.
method: The author provides a detailed description of the automatic algorithm-design system, highlighting its use of general-purpose operators and how they are adapted to different situations using instantiation and means-ends analysis rules. The system also utilizes symbolic and test-case execution rules that drive the component-refinement process by exposing problems and opportunities.
outcome: Though the author describes the implementation of the system and provides a specification for it, the system's performance is not evaluated in the paper, and therefore there are no reported outcomes.
future_impact: This work could contribute to the development of more advanced and efficient algorithm-design systems, potentially automating the entire process of algorithm design and testing.
title: An automatic algorithm designer: an initial implementation

context: The teacher-student framework in reinforcement learning deploys an advising mechanism where a teacher advises the student about the optimal action to take in a given state. This mechanism, while effective, doesn't allow the teacher to give more informative and nuanced advice about the state of the environment
key_idea: The authors extend the current advising framework to allow the teacher to provide not only the optimal action, but also a qualitative assessment of the state. A novel architecture, Advice Replay Memory (ARM), is introduced to effectively reuse the advice provided by the teacher.
method: The authors tested their approach on multiple Atari 2600 games using a fixed set of hyper-parameters, looking at performance of students when provided with different advising budget and teacher quality.
outcome: Experiments demonstrate that even a student advised by a sub-optimal teacher can achieve significant performance increases and ultimately outperform the teacher. The approach outperforms baselines even with comparatively suboptimal teachers and a small advising budget.
future_impact: The authors' contributions, including supplementing a student's knowledge, introduction of ARM, performance boost with coarse state categorization, and enabling a student to outperform teacher, could guide future enhancements to the teacher-student framework.
title: An Enhanced Advising Model In Teacher-Student Framework Using State Categorization

context: The stable model semantics was recently generalized for the full first-order language, a syntax translation approach akin to McCarthy's circumscription. However, the decidability and undecidability of first-order language fragments under both stable model semantics and circumscription remain unclear.
key_idea: The paper investigates the decidability and undecidability of various fragments of first-order language under both semantics of stable models and circumscription, aiming to identify maximally decidable and undecidable classes.
method: The researchers explored different fragments of first-order language under the semantics of stable models and circumscription to identify decidable and undecidable classes.
outcome: The paper reveals that the boundaries between decidability and undecidability for the two semantics are distinct despite the similarity in definitions. Furthermore, it is found that for all fragments considered in this study, decidability under the semantics of circumscription aligns with that in classical first-order logic.
future_impact: The discrepancies observed in the boundaries between decidability and undecidability for these two semantics could influence future explorations in this domain.
title: Decidable fragments of first-order language under stable model semantics and circumscription

context: The exact computation of probabilities of missing deadlines in series-parallel schedules is NP-hard. Existing methods for approximation of discrete random variables are not efficient and optimal.
key_idea: This paper presents an efficient algorithm for creating an approximation of a discrete random variable with a support size limited to a specific number (m). This approximation minimizes the Kolmogorov distance from the original random variable.
method: The author presented several variants of the main algorithm and conducted a detailed empirical evaluation of their performance and complexity.
outcome: The author showed that the proposed algorithms perform efficiently and effectively in practice, as demonstrated through empirical evaluations.
future_impact: The algorithms proposed in this paper could be used for estimating the probability of missing timelines in series-parallel schedules, potentially providing more efficient and accurate approximations for these complex calculations.
title: Efficient Optimal Approximation of Discrete Random Variables for Estimation of Probabilities of Missing Deadlines.

context: Interpreting temporal relations between events mentioned in narratives (such as which event occurs before another) has been a challenge. Previous works lacked rigorous descriptions for time relations of tenses and did not provide deterministic interpreting algorithms.
key_idea: This paper presents a three-level language concept-based algorithm for interpreting temporal relations in narrative text, and a novel, more rigorous description for time relations of tences is introduced, which can express all 16 tenses in English and incorporate the interval properties of events into the relations.
method: The algorithm decides the relations through aspectual information for verbs, time relations for tenses, and time relations between clauses and/or sentences. In interpreting time relations between clauses, the use of anaphoric references to events and the concept of situational description for an event is emphasized. To make the algorithm deterministic, a fixed rather than parallel order for applying interpreting rules was proposed.
outcome: The authors suggest a tree-like structure for the representation of temporal relations between events, which allows us to include vaguely specified relations, and facilitates the interpretation of subsequent temporal relations.
future_impact: Since the interpretation of temporal relations between events may be clarified later, this work can improve subsequent interpretations of temporal relations in narrative texts.
title: The interpretation of temporal relations in narrative

context: Predictive uncertainty in humans is highly interpretable but poorly accessible. The predictive uncertainty of machine learning models, while poorly interpretable, is relatively easily accessible. Estimating human predictive uncertainty is crucial to improve sampling efficiency and prediction reliability of human-in-the-loop systems used in smart healthcare, smart education, and human-computer interactions.
key_idea: The authors propose a model for inferring human predictive uncertainty, called proxy ensemble network (PEN), which exploits simple and universally accessible deterministic neural networks.
method: Simulations with a few benchmark datasets were performed. To show the applicability in real-world problems, behavioral experiments were conducted, in which 64 physicians classified medical images and reported their level of confidence.
outcome: The model was able to efficiently learn human uncertainty from a small amount of data. The PEN could predict both the uncertainty range and diagnoses given by subjects with high accuracy.
future_impact: This way of accessing human predictive uncertainty via deterministic neural networks has the potential to guide human decision making and can assist individuals in learning more efficiently and accurately.
title: Human Uncertainty Inference Via Deterministic Ensemble Neural Networks

context: Factorization Machines (FMs) are widely used for collaborative filtering and recommendation tasks due to their ability to express and model pairwise feature interactions.
key_idea: This paper proposes Holographic Factorization Machines (HFM), a method that enhances the representation capability of FMs by replacing the inner product in FMs with holographic reduced representations, without increasing parameter size.
method: The authors conduct tests on nine publicly available datasets for collaborative filtering with explicit feedback to evaluate HFM's performance, and compare it against Attentional Factorization Machines and Neural Matrix Factorization.
outcome: HFM consistently improves over vanilla FMs by up to 4% in terms of mean squared error, and achieves state-of-the-art performance on all nine datasets.
future_impact: The authors propose a neural adaptation of HFM which could enhance its capability to handle nonlinear structures, suggesting a potential direction for future improvements.
title: Holographic Factorization Machines for Recommendation

context: Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) are efficient for classification tasks but are often viewed as a 'blackbox', making understanding predictions and debugging challenging. Current debugging and explanation methods diagnose potential causes for model prediction, but subsequent model optimization is done manually.
key_idea: A tool named Model Doctor, which automates model diagnosing and treating, is proposed. This tool is based on two findings that: (1) each category is connected with sparse and specific convolution kernels and (2) adversarial samples and normal samples behave differently in feature space.
method: A simple aggregate gradient constraint is developed to diagnose and optimize CNN classifiers. The efficacy of Model Doctor is assessed through experiments on existing CNN classifiers.
outcome: The proposed Model Doctor can be applied to all existing CNN classifiers, and it improves the accuracy of 16 mainstream CNN classifiers by 1%~5%.
future_impact: Model Doctor, as a versatile module, could potentially provide a standardized tool for diagnosing and optimizing different CNN classifiers, enhancing their accuracy and operational efficiency.
title: Model Doctor: A Simple Gradient Aggregation Strategy for Diagnosing and Treating CNN Classifiers.

context: Explanation-based learning (EBL) techniques have been widely researched and applied to problem solving. However, they are known to suffer from the utility problem, where the cost of utilizing the learned knowledge outweighs its benefits.
key_idea: The authors propose viewing the learning process as a sequence of transformations from a problem solving episode to a learned rule to analyze the increase in cost of a learned rule in an EBL system, specifically focusing on the Soar problem solving system which uses a chunking variant of EBL.
method: The paper analyses how the cost changes through the transformations by decomposing the chunking process into a sequence of transformations from problem solving to a chunk, then identifies sources which can make the output chunk expensive.
outcome: By analyzing these transformations of the Soar problem solving system, the authors identified a set of sources which can make the output chunk expensive.
future_impact: The resulting analysis provides a useful tool for revealing the sources of cost increase in the learning system and can guide future work in mitigating these sources, impacting how EBL systems are designed and evaluated.
title: A transformational analysis of the EBL utility problem

context: Current vision models classify objects based on features, but they haven't yet utilized taxonomical organization of class labels, making them less interpretable, especially compared to human cognition which often hierarchizes categories while identifying objects.
key_idea: The authors present a novel model that uses hierarchically organized prototypes to classify objects at multiple levels in a predefined taxonomy, providing distinct explanations for each level of predictions for an image.
method: The authors test their model on a subset of ImageNet for two tasks: 1) classification of data from familiar classes, and 2) classification of data from previously unseen classes at the appropriate level in the taxonomy.
outcome: The new model performed nearly as well as its black-box counterpart in both tasks while providing interpretable classifications.
future_impact: The hierarchical prototypes model could be used for future work in making machine vision systems more interpretable and in processing images from previously unseen classes at the level of the taxonomy to which they correctly relate.
title: Interpretable Image Recognition with Hierarchical Prototypes

context: Many computer science departments have seen a decline in enrollments. To attract students, especially non-majors, to computer science, subjects like Artificial Intelligence can be introduced early in the course curriculum.
key_idea: The authors propose two courses - an introductory course on AI and robotics for non-majors without prerequisites, and an elective course on machine learning taught in a tutorial format, with minimal prerequisites making it accessible to more students.
method: Courses are designed with ties to Cognitive Science program, enabling an extra means of advertising the courses to students who might not consider computer science. The structure and content of the courses are aimed at attracting non-majors to computer science.
outcome: The courses designed to attract non-computer science majors to AI topics resulted in students going on to enroll in more computer science courses and to consider becoming Computer Science majors.
future_impact: The proposed courses may set a precedent for the creation of future computer science coursework, potentially aiding in higher student enrollment by providing introductions to intriguing subjects like AI and robotics.
title: Artificial Intelligence for Non-Majors at Multiple Levels.

context: In decision tree learning, determining a multiple-split test based on a tree-structured attribute that maximizes Quinlan's gain-ratio measure is a challenging task due to the exponentially growing number of possible tests.
key_idea: The authors propose an efficient algorithm that can find the optimal multiple-split test, without the need to enumerate and evaluate all possibilities.
method: The efficiency and effectiveness of the algorithm are assessed by its ability to solve the problem in a time proportional to dm for a training set of m examples and an attribute hierarchy of height d.
outcome: The proposed algorithm is able to run in time proportional to dm, demonstrating its computational efficiency.
future_impact: The algorithm, due to its computational efficiency, is practical for real-world use in decision tree learning, potentially contributing to more effective learning solutions.
title: An efficient algorithm for finding optimal gain-ratio multiple-split tests on hierarchical attributes in decision tree learning

context: Existing works focusing on image description mainly emphasize on generating expressive descriptions. The few that concentrate on generating stylish (e.g., romantic, lyric, etc.) descriptions suffer from limited style variation and content digression.
key_idea: The authors propose a controllable stylish image description generation model that can learn to generate stylish descriptions more related to the image content and can be trained with any monolingual corpus without collecting new paired image and stylish descriptions. They introduce the Domain Layer Norm (DLN) to enable users to generate various stylish descriptions.
method: The authors conducted extensive experimental validation and user study on various stylish image description generation tasks to verify the effectiveness of the proposed model.
outcome: The extensive experimental validations and user studies showcase the competitive advantages of the proposed model in stylish image description generation tasks.
future_impact: The proposed model, with its ability to generate various stylish descriptions by including new style-specific parameters, can open up new possibilities for producing image descriptions with various styles, enhancing the flexibility and overall applicability of image description generation models.
title: Unsupervised Stylish Image Description Generation via Domain Layer Norm

context: In the domain of construction robots, inspired by Harvard University's TERMES project, robots are required to gather blocks from a reservoir and build structures much larger than themselves. The problem of minimizing the number of pickup and drop-off operations performed on blocks in order to build user-specified structures presents a key challenge.
key_idea: The authors propose a tree-based algorithm that heuristically solves this problem using the idea of performing dynamic programming on a spanning tree in the inner loop and searching for a good tree in the outer loop.
method: The authors test their algorithm through simulations, considering large problem instances and scalability.
outcome: It is found that their algorithm performs well in simulations and easily scales to large problem instances.
future_impact: The authors believe their algorithm offers valuable lessons for the construction domain by comparing the success of their algorithm with the failures of off-the-shelf planning technologies.
title: A Tree-Based Algorithm for Construction Robots

context: End-user interactive machine learning is a rising tool for enhancing human productivity with unstructured data. Existing work has demonstrated the creation of such systems for specific applications, but a generalized understanding of how to effectively design end-user interaction with interactive machine learning systems is lacking.
key_idea: The authors strive to understand how to design effective end-user interactions with interactive machine learning systems, with the focus on balancing the needs of end-users and machine learning algorithms.
method: The authors conduct three explorations in designing for effective end-user interaction with machine learning in CueFlik, a system developed to support Web image search.
outcome: The explorations demonstrate that interactions designed considering both the needs of end-users and machine learning algorithms can significantly improve the effectiveness of end-user interactive machine learning.
future_impact: This study may provide insights for future developments in end-user interactive machine learning systems and influence designs to better balance the needs of end-users and machine learning algorithms.
title: Effective end-user interaction with machine learning

context: Previous attempts at representing defeasible entailment and specificity in the framework of default logic may have shortcomings or room for improvement.
key_idea: The authors present a novel representation of defeasible entailment and specificity that bolsters the classical language with the language of conditionals possessing its own monotonic, internal logic.
method: The proposal's efficacy is showcased through the demonstration of how inheritance reasoning can be naturally depicted within this representative framework and then generalized to the entire classical language.
outcome: In this study, it was demonstrated that inheritance reasoning can be naturally integrated within the suggested framework and can be widely applicable to the entire classical language.
future_impact: This work has the potential to improve the understanding and application of defeasible entailment and specificity in default logic, possibly leading to more versatile and robust logical frameworks.
title: On Default Representation of Defeasible Inference and Specificity.

context: While there is an abundance of theoretical work on Qualitative Spatial Reasoning (QSR), practical application requirements of QSR for real-world problems, such as detecting physically defective parts in manufacturing, are often ignored.
key_idea: This paper discusses the use of ontologies to compare different QSR formalisms with respect to defining spatial concepts, specifically focusing on defects like cracks and holes. It identifies a set of artifacts necessary for modeling these defects as a QSR problem.
method: The ontologies are introduced and used in a conceptual analysis of the problem of detecting physically defective parts, such as cracks and holes in manufacturing. The identified set of artifacts is compared with the capabilities of existing region-based QSR approaches.
outcome: It is found that most existing region-based QSR approaches fail to distinguish defects like cracks and holes effectively.
future_impact: The proposed set of problems can be used in future work to evaluate different QSR formalisms for their adequacy in defining and distinguishing cracks and holes.
title: Detecting Physical Defects: A Practical 2D-Study of Cracks and Holes

context: Activation maximization (AM) is a technique for generating input examples that maximize the activation of a target class in a classifier. GAN-based AM methods require the image set to contain some images of the target class, a limitation when dealing with unseen classes.
key_idea: The authors propose PROBEGAN, a GAN-based AM algorithm that can generate image classes unseen in the image set, effectively separating the target class information residing in the classifier from any target class information in the image set.
method: PROBEGAN is designed with a class-conditional generator, a seen-class discriminator, and an all-class unconditional discriminator. It includes AM in its training objective, and the authors conduct experiments to compare its ability to generate unseen-class images with other algorithms.
outcome: PROBEGAN was shown to generate images with features of unseen target classes, while retaining naturalness depicted in the image set. Also, it was found to produce higher quality unseen-class images than baseline methods.
future_impact: The authors suggest that PROBEGAN might be used as a model interpretation tool, increasing the accuracy and appropriateness of model representations for unseen classes.
title: An Adversarial Framework for Generating Unseen Images by Activation Maximization.

context: Homeless youth are prone to HIV due to engaging in high-risk behavior, leading many agencies to conduct interventions. These interventions often involve selecting a group of youth to educate about HIV prevention, with the hope that they will spread this information through their social network. However, previous methods of strategically selecting participants do not accurately account for uncertainties in the social network’s structure or its evolving state, leading to potential shortcomings in the spread of information.
key_idea: The authors developed PSINET, a decision support system that addresses uncertainties in network structure and evolving network state using Partially Observable Markov Decision Processes (POMDPs) in influence maximization, thus improving the spread of information about HIV prevention.
method: PSINET was tested through simulations, and its performance was measured by comparing the amount of information spread over current state-of-the-art influence maximization methods.
outcome: In simulations, PSINET showed approximately 30% more information spread over the current state-of-the-art influence maximization methods. PSINET is currently being reviewed by officials at My Friend’s Place (a drop-in agency serving homeless youth in Los Angeles).
future_impact: Pending review and implementation, PSINET has the potential to enhance the efficiency of HIV prevention education among homeless youth by improving the spread of information through social networks, notably in real-world situations such as at My Friend's Place.
title: Preventing HIV spread in homeless populations using PSINET

context: Diagnosis of anomalies in ontology has been widely studied in the Semantic Web community. However, in ontology streams, diagnosis results are encapsulated within numerous, evolving ontologies rather than a single fixed ontology, leading to potential issues in identifying, managing, and understanding the evolution of diagnoses.
key_idea: The paper proposes a graph-based representation approach aimed at (i) organizing and linking time-evolving diagnoses effectively, and (ii) enabling scalable exploration of these diagnoses.
method: The authors implemented their graph-based representation approach to explore diagnoses in ontology streams and tested it with real and live data from Dublin City.
outcome: The authors found that their approach allowed for scalable diagnoses exploration in ontology streams, as demonstrated in the experiments using real world data from Dublin City.
future_impact: This approach has potential to improve understanding and identification of anomaly diagnoses in other evolving ontologies, particularly with large-scale, real-time data streams.
title: Towards scalable exploration of diagnoses in an ontology stream

context: The increasing problem of self-propagating code is causing intrusion attempts on the internet, with slowly propagating attacks difficult to detect because they hide within normal network traffic. Recently, anomaly-based intrusion detection systems have been able to identify quick spreading attacks, but slowly propagating attacks are still a challenge.
key_idea: The concept of collaborative intrusion detection systems is extended by incorporating probabilistic graphical models into end hosts and using random messaging to share state among peer detectors, which can boost the capabilities of weak anomaly detector D to detect significantly slower worms.
method: The authors validate their approach through theoretical analysis and evaluations, proving that their system can detect slower worms with low false positive rates by utilizing a weak anomaly detector either at the end-host or a network aggregation point.
outcome: A system imbued with probabilistic graphical models and gossiping among peer detectors is shown to be capable of detecting an order-of-magnitude slower worm than what could be achieved by using detector D alone. The system is also demonstrated to be scalable, distribute communication bandwidth uniformly, and leverage the enhanced computational power of distributed systems.
future_impact: The exploration of using probabilistic models for detection purposes indicates the potential for more robust detections compared to previous collaborative counting schemes and also allows for accounting for heterogeneous detectors in a principled manner.
title: When gossip is good: distributed probabilistic inference for detection of slow network intrusions

context: Event sequences in multidimensional data pose challenges to traditional data mining techniques due to complexity in extracting interactions from patterns of damage in objects like fuel cells or earthquake occurrence patterns.
key_idea: The authors have proposed a novel data mining method named co-occurring cluster mining (CCM) that analyses sequences of multidimensional event data, generates cluster candidates, and tests them based on clustering in the data space and co-occurrence degree in the event sequence.
method: The researchers applied CCM to two practical domains: locating damage patterns in fuel cells, using sequence of acoustic emission events, and unveiling earthquake occurrence patterns, using a hypocenter catalog.
outcome: The co-occurring cluster mining method was able to infer mechanical interactions infuel cells and extract interactions between distant earthquakes in the given applications.
future_impact: The CCM method proposed may have applications in complex data structures where interactions between different elements need to be unearthed.
title: Discovery of Damage Patterns in Fuel Cell and Earthquake Occurrence Patterns by Co-Occurring Cluster Mining

context: Forest biomass is crucial for future climate, and scalable financing schemes like carbon offsetting certifications are needed to protect and restore forests. Existing manual methods to inventory forest carbon stock are time-consuming, labor-intensive, and subjective, often leading to overestimation and distrust in forest financing.
key_idea: In this study, the authors present ReforesTree, a benchmark dataset of forest carbon stock at six carbon offsetting sites in Ecuador, and propose using a deep learning-based end-to-end model for individual tree detection from low-cost RGB-only drone imagery to accurately estimate forest carbon stock.
method: The authors used deep learning-based end-to-end models for tree detection using low cost RGB-only drone imagery. The performance of the models was validated by comparison with the accuracy of official carbon offsetting certification standards and existing satellite-based forest biomass and carbon stock estimates.
outcome: The proposed model using ReforesTree dataset was found to accurately estimate forest carbon stock within the official carbon offsetting certification standards. The baseline CNN model surpassed the performance of state-of-the-art satellite-based forest biomass and carbon stock estimates for small-scale, tropical agro-forestry sites.
future_impact: The authors anticipate the study would encourage more machine learning research in this area, potentially enhancing the transparency and responsibility of monitoring, verification, and reporting in carbon offsetting projects, as well as global reforestation financing through accurate remote sensing.
title: ReforesTree: A Dataset for Estimating Tropical Forest Carbon Stock with Deep Learning and Aerial Imagery.

context: Existing adversarial attack methods that generate adversarial examples to confuse Deep Neural Networks (DNNs) perform well in image classification and object detection. However, these methods struggle to attack video object tracking models due to their ability to handle sequential information across video frames and the uncertainty of target categories.
key_idea: To solve the problem, a Unified and Effective Network (UEN) is proposed, that is competent to attack visual object tracking models.
method: UEN is designed with several features and tested using three different loss functions. It's evaluated with extensive experiments on state-of-the-art trackers, such as SiamRPN-based networks and DiMP, using popular tracking datasets including OTB100, UAV123, and GOT10K.
outcome: The UEN successfully attacks many state-of-the-art trackers, making real-time attacks possible. The attack results of UEN outperform the introduced baseline in terms of attacking ability and efficiency.
future_impact: The ability of UEN to launch effective real-time attacks on advanced tracking models could impact the way adversarial attacks are performed and the development of defenses against them in the future.
title: A Unified Multi-Scenario Attacking Network For Visual Object Tracking

context: Growing demand is straining our existing electricity generation facilities and requires the active participation of the utility and the consumers to achieve energy sustainability through demand response (DR). This requires utilities to have reliable estimates of reduced consumption during DR for optimal planning, a problem that is under-studied.
key_idea: The authors introduce and formalize the problem of predicting reduced consumption during demand response.
method: The authors propose computational methods that use historical DR data as well as pre-DR conditions to make predictions of reduced consumption. The experiments are conducted in the real-world setting of a university campus microgrid.
outcome: The results from the experiments in a real-world setting set the foundation for more detailed modeling of reduced consumption during demand response.
future_impact: The problem of predicting reduced consumption during demand response and the methods proposed for tackling it could lead to more effective strategies for utility companies to manage peak demand.
title: Estimating Reduced Consumption for Dynamic Demand Response

context: Reclassification risk, where health shocks persist for much longer than the usual one-year health insurance contracts, is a significant concern in the health insurance sector.
key_idea: The authors propose a solution of long-term insurance contracts with one-sided commitment, and aiming to determine the optimal contracts for consumers in Utah.
method: The authors use individual-level medical information from the Utah all-payer claims database to derive the optimal consumer contracts and assess the welfare level that full implementation of these contracts could achieve compared to key benchmarks.
outcome: Dynamic contracts perform extremely well for most of the population, eliminating over 94% of the welfare loss from reclassification risk for individuals who enter the market at age 25 in good health. However, dynamic contracts provide very little benefit to those with the worst health risks before the age of 25.
future_impact: The paper suggests that dynamic contracts can provide substantial welfare benefits under certain scenarios, but complementary policies are essential to fully unlock these benefits.
title: Eliminating Latent Discrimination: Train Then Mask

context: While state-of-the-art brain-to-text systems have achieved great success decoding language directly from brain signals using neural networks, they have been limited to small, closed vocabularies, and require data from invasive devices like ECoG.
key_idea: The authors extend the problem to open vocabulary Electroencephalography (EEG)-To-Text Sequence-To-Sequence decoding and zero-shot sentence sentiment classification on natural reading tasks. They propose a novel framework leveraging pre-trained language models, hypothesizing that the human brain works as a special text encoder.
method: The proposed model is validated by performing EEG-To-Text decoding and zero-shot EEG-based ternary sentiment classification, and testing it on data from various subjects and sources.
outcome: The proposed model achieves a 40.1% BLEU-1 score on EEG-To-Text decoding and a 55.6% F1 score on zero-shot EEG-based ternary sentiment classification, significantly outperforming supervised baselines. The model demonstrated the ability to handle data from various subjects and sources.
future_impact: The proposed framework shows great potential for a high-performance open vocabulary brain-to-text system, once sufficient data is available.
title: Open Vocabulary Electroencephalography-to-Text Decoding and Zero-Shot Sentiment Classification.

context: In the field of action recognition, existing deep learning methods treat sampled frames equally and all frame-level predictions are averaged at the test stage. However, within a video, discriminative actions may occur sparsely in a few key frames while many other frames are irrelevant or misleading, potentially resulting in incorrect predictions.
key_idea: The authors propose an attention-aware sampling method for action recognition, which selectively discards irrelevant and misleading frames and preserves the most discriminative frames for action recognition.
method: The process of mining key frames from videos is formulated as a Markov decision process, and the attention agent is trained through deep reinforcement learning without the need for extra labels. The attention agent uses features and predictions from a baseline model to generate importance scores for all frames and can be applied to different deep learning based action recognition models.
outcome: The proposed attention-aware sampling method is demonstrated to achieve competitive action recognition performance on two widely used action recognition datasets.
future_impact: The authors suggest that their approach is extensible and could potentially be applied to enhance the performance of other existing deep learning action recognition models, offering a new strategy for frame selection in action recognition.
title: Attention-aware Sampling via Deep Reinforcement Learning for Action Recognition

context: AI systems are increasingly used to decide crucial matters such as loan applications. However, there are concerns they can discriminate against applicants based on sensitive attributes such as gender and ethnicity.
key_idea: The authors propose to evaluate the fairness of AI systems, specifically dealing with proxy and allowed variables. They describe fairness as a lack of discrimination based on sensitive attributes.
method: The authors formulate the decision-making process of a hypothetical regulator certifying the fairness of a bank's AI system, considering factors like the definition of fairness, dealing with proxy variables, and handling allowed variables.
outcome: The authors provide the theoretical result that the problem of deciding fairness as defined in the paper is co-NP-complete.
future_impact: The authors suggest that, despite the problem's complexity, it should be manageable in practical situations, implying potential future advancements in the method and applications for fairness testing of AI systems.
title: On Testing for Discrimination Using Causal Models.

context: The symmetric rendezvous search problem involves two robots, unaware of each other's locations, striving to meet as fast as possible. The symmetric specification requires the robots to follow the same strategy.
key_idea: The study presents a new symmetric rendezvous strategy for robots initially located on an open plane and then extends this to an unknown environment with polygonal obstacles.
method: The study involves the analysis of the competitive performance of the proposed symmetric rendezvous strategy, and quantifies its competitive complexity. The extended strategy is further analyzed for square, translating robots in terms of competitive ratio.
outcome: The researchers show that the competitive complexity of their strategy is O(d=R) where d is the initial robot distance and R is the communication radius. The competitive ratio of the extended strategy for square, translating robots is shown to be O(d=D), where D is the length of the robot sides.
future_impact: The findings of this study provide an upper limit on covering arbitrary polygonal environments, which could be valuable for independent research.
title: Symmetric rendezvous in planar environments with and without obstacles

context: Protein folding plays an essential role in protein function and stability, however, the understanding of it remains limited. The current tools and methods pose challenges in accurately identifying the folding core of proteins, essential to engineer proteins with desired functions and efficiencies.
key_idea: In this work, rigidity analysis is used to effectively sample and model the protein's energy landscape and to identify the folding core, suggesting a new way of understanding protein folding.
method: The method is validated by comparing models created using rigidity analysis of protein's energy landscape against known experimental data, and against results from other simulation tools. The proteins studied include protein G and its mutants, NuG1 and NuG2.
outcome: The results show that rigidity analysis improves the accuracy of landscape models, capturing the subtle folding differences between protein G and its mutants, and correlates well with experimental data. It could also suggest other components of structure that have not been previously identified experimentally.
future_impact: The methodology proposed in this work can offer a new perspective to improve our understanding of protein folding and potentially support the engineering of proteins with desired features and efficiencies.
title: Rigidity analysis for protein motion and folding core identification

context: Existing knowledge of causal Bayesian networks and the distributions induced by local interventions on variables they govern lacks a complete characterization.
key_idea: The authors propose a complete characterization of the set of distributions resulting from local interventions on variables dictated by a causal Bayesian network, asserting that these distributions must adhere to three norms of coherence.
method: The authors demonstrate the usage of these coherence norms as inferential tools in tasks of learning and identification. They further derive testable coherence norms for networks containing unmeasured variables.
outcome: The authors successfully demonstrate the use of the three coherence norms as inferential tools in learning and identification tasks and also derive testable coherence norms for networks with unmeasured variables.
future_impact: The characterization of the distributions and the norms of coherence presented can potentially impact the learning and identification tasks in causal Bayesian networks, especially those containing unmeasured variables.
title: A new characterization of the experimental implications of causal Bayesian networks

context: Reinforcement learning (RL) algorithms explore a domain's state space to learn optimal policies for control problems. However, the vast size of the state space in most problems inhibits RL technologies from fully exploring it to find good policies. State abstraction is one strategy used to reduce the size and complexity of a domain's state space.
key_idea: The authors propose a new approach for automatically deriving state abstractions: Evolutionary Tile Coding. This leverages a genetic algorithm for deriving effective tile codings.
method: The authors conducted an empirical analysis of the new algorithm, comparing it to another adaptive tile coding method and fixed tile coding. Testing was done on two RL benchmark problems.
outcome: Results indicated that the proposed approach can automatically derive effective state abstractions for two RL benchmark problems. It was revealed that the state space of the classical mountain car problem can be reduced to just two states, while still preserving the discovery of an optimal policy.
future_impact: This new approach for automatically deriving state abstractions may enable more efficient exploration and policy learning in reinforcement learning, notably in domains with large state spaces.
title: Evolutionary tile coding: an automated state abstraction algorithm for reinforcement learning

context: The allocation of indivisible chores, items with negative utilities, using Max-Min Share (MmS) fair allocations has been challenging due to its intractability and the non-existence of MmS allocations in some cases.
key_idea: The authors propose a new fairness concept, optimal MmS, that represents the best possible allocation. They present a polynomial-time 2-approximation algorithm for MmS fairness for chore allocation.
method: Connections to parallel machine scheduling are utilized to provide a polynomial-time approximation scheme for computing an optimal MmS allocation when the number of agents is fixed. Additionally, an effective and efficient heuristic is developed with an ex-post worst-case analysis.
outcome: A polynomial-time 2-approximation algorithm for MmS fairness for chores is developed. Also, a polynomial-time approximation scheme for computing an optimal MmS allocation when the number of agents is fixed is generated, along with an effective and efficient heuristic.
future_impact: The suggested new concept of optimal MmS and its related algorithm could offer improved fairness in the allocation of indivisible chores and provide a path for future research in fair allocation problems.
title: Algorithms for Max-Min Share Fair Allocation of Indivisible Chores

context: The challenge of enhancing consumers' health literacy through virtual health environments, particularly for those affected by chronic low back pain, has not been effectively addressed. Existing approaches do not adequately consider the complexity of health literacy components.
key_idea: The authors propose a conceptual model of health literacy that considers its complexity and apply it in the design of a website named ONESELF, using a bottom-up approach that enables users to request the information they need.
method: The authors used the proposed conceptualization of health literacy to design and develop the ONESELF website that empowers users to request all necessary information.
outcome: The outcome of this study is a working website called ONESELF for consumers dealing with chronic low back pain. The website operationalizes vital dimensions of health literacy.
future_impact: The authors anticipate that the concept of health literacy and the ONESELF website would have future implications in the design of AI systems that are capable of delivering the same level of tailored information from a human-computer interaction perspective.
title: Health Literacy and the Tailoring of Health Information. A Dialogue between Communication and (AI)Technology

context: Automated fact-checking is necessary to curb online misinformation. Current solutions verify claims by retrieving supporting or refuting evidence from related textual sources. However, these systems will need to verify claims against evidence sources that could be affected by the same misinformation.
key_idea: The authors explore the sensitivity of automated fact-checkers to synthetic adversarial evidence in two simulated settings of fabricating or altering documents in the evidence repository available to the fact-checking system.
method: They conduct a study across multiple models on three benchmarks (not detailed in the abstract) to examine the robustness of these systems against adversarial attacks.
outcome: The study demonstrates that automated fact-checkers suffer significant performance drops when faced with synthetic adversarial evidence.
future_impact: The authors raise important concerns about the increasing threat of modern Natural Language Generation systems serving as sources of disinformation and the challenges they pose to automated fact-checkers.
title: Synthetic Disinformation Attacks on Automated Fact Verification Systems.

context: The effectiveness of Serious Games (SG) hinges on their ability to blend gaming experiences and education effectively, which poses challenges in terms of intelligence and personalization. Fragmentation in research also complicates these challenges.
key_idea: The paper presents a summary of important contributions from Artificial Intelligence and Personalization to overcome research fragmentation and introduce key issues in Serious Games.
method: The paper amalgamates research insights from nine different institutions within a network of twenty-eight research labs and six game developers, aiming to identify hot topics for AI and Personalization within SG research.
outcome: The paper successfully summarizes approaches to user and learning goals modeling, user engagement, game adaptation levels, context identification through sensors and mobile technology, and content adaptation and reusability.
future_impact: This work promotes a focused research direction to establish benchmarks and metrics for the effective use of AI and Personalization in serious games design. It anticipates an impact area where research may have real benefits for SG products and the market as it matures.
title: Artificial Intelligence and Personalization Opportunities for Serious Games

context: Planning and execution systems have been used in a wide variety of systems, from scientific research to video games and military planning. However, the authors believe that most of these systems lack some key components that are present in other systems.
key_idea: The authors aim to enable future researchers to build more complete planning and execution systems by identifying the major technical problems that any implementer would have to face and citing recent solutions to each of these problems.
method: The authors review previous work on various planning and execution systems and identify the major technical problems any implementer would need to tackle.
outcome: The authors successfully identify the major technical problems faced in building a planning and execution system and propose recent solutions to these problems.
future_impact: The authors anticipate that by identifying the main technical challenges and solutions in planning and execution systems, they will assist future researchers in building more complete and efficient systems, potentially preventing serious system failure.
title: Building robust planning and execution systems for virtual worlds

context: Introducing robots as teammates in various domains raises human factors issues that do not necessarily arise in multi-robot coordination, especially when considering seamless integration with human group dynamics and the ability to robustly anticipate and adapt to other team members and the environment.
key_idea: This study proposes dynamic plan execution as a framework for explicitly modeling and efficiently reasoning on temporal information for human-robot interaction, and introduces an executive named Chaski that enables a robot to coordinate with a human to execute a shared plan under different models of teamwork.
method: The authors apply the Chaski executive to two Barrett Whole Arm Manipulators to demonstrate teamwork and describe ongoing work to demonstrate temporally fluid human-robot teaming using the Mobile-Dexterous-Social (MDS) robot.
outcome: The authors have successfully applied Chaski to two Barrett Whole Arm Manipulators and currently applying the methodology to the Mobile-Dexterous-Social robot.
future_impact: The advances in dynamic plan execution provide a potentially powerful framework for improving human-robot interaction, offering opportunities for further research. The application of these methods to robotics can open possibilities for seamless and efficient human-robot teamwork.
title: Dynamic Execution of Temporal Plans for Temporally Fluid Human-Robot Teaming.

context: In societies, agents operate under several, often contradictory, obligations and interdictions, which pose a challenge in achieving harmonious functioning.
key_idea: The authors propose an innovative solution in the form of a representation of obligations and interdictions within an organizational framework. This also includes an inference method that determines which obligations to break in situations that present contradictions.
method: The proposed solution is implemented within an operational, practically useful agent development language. The system is illustrated with a negotiated solution to a feature interaction problem in the telecommunications industry.
outcome: The system successfully supports negotiation by allowing agents to exchange deontic constraints, as evidenced by effectively solving a feature interaction problem in telecommunications.
future_impact: The approach could proactively manage the constraints imposed on agents in different societal systems, thus fostering better functionality and coordination in multi-agent applications.
title: Agents that work in harmony by knowing and fulfilling their obligations

context: Online map services like Google Maps and Open Street Maps have traditionally used pinch-to-zoom and drag-to-move gestures for map navigation on smartphones and tablets.
key_idea: This study introduces two new gestures for adjusting the zoom level of maps that allow users to identify a target area to zoom and enlarge it to cover the whole map container.
method: The proposed gestures, added to the traditional ones without overlap, were tested in comparison with the traditional pinch-to-zoom gesture in terms of time efficiency on tablets and smartphones.
outcome: Test results showed that the proposed gestures saved 30% of the time on tablets with the Two-Finger-Tap gesture and 14% on smartphones with the Tap&Tap gesture compared to the traditional pinch-to-zoom gesture.
future_impact: The key advantage of the proposed gestures, especially the Tap&Tap gesture for smartphones, is the ability to control the zoom level with just one hand, offering users more options for map navigation without altering their regular practices.
title: Two New Gestures to Zoom: Enhancing Online Maps Services

context: Millions of images on the web have been assigned latitude and longitude information but it remains challenging to effectively search and browse them due to the lack of methods to decide their geographical relevance. Collecting geographical relevance data has been attempted through game-based approaches, but the quality and utility of these data in improving applications have not been adequately demonstrated.
key_idea: This study focuses on the geographical relevance of images, defined as to what extent the main objects in an image match landmarks at the location where the image was taken. The authors propose a web-based, multiplayer game to collect geographical relevance data while providing an enjoyable experience for players.
method: The authors design and implement a multiplayer game to collect user-generated data about the geographical relevance of web images. They analyze the logs of game activity during a three week study with 147 participants and devise methods to determine image geographical relevance. A comparison experiment is conducted between the proposed methods and a commercial search engine.
outcome: The results of the study demonstrate that the proposed gaming approach and methods markedly improve image search relevance. It also enables the derivation of geographically relevant objects and their salient regions in images.
future_impact: The findings are valuable as they can be applied to other applications like image location recognition, potentially improving their performance.
title: A game based approach to assign geographical relevance to web images

context: Malicious accounts spreading misinformation in social media, particularly during the COVID-19 pandemic, has become a critical problem. Adapting fact-checking to new domains is slow and difficult to scale.
key_idea: The authors propose a framework that uses news-source credibility labels as weak labels for social media posts. The framework incorporates uncertainty sampling with self-supervision or relabeling to construct large-scale, diverse misinformation labeled datasets in new domains.
method: The proposed framework uses a detection model self-trained on the initial weak labels. Potentially inaccurate labels are identified and corrected using self-supervision or relabeling. Social context of the post in terms of the community of its associated user is considered for detecting inaccurate labels. Lastly, the framework uses a few labeled samples as class prototypes to separate high confidence samples into categories of information accuracy.
outcome: The approach has been demonstrated for providing a large-scale misinformation dataset on COVID-19 vaccines.
future_impact: This methodology could make it easier to build large-scale datasets with minimum human effort and streamline the process of fighting against misinformation in new domains, which is crucial for reliable dissemination of information.
title: Construction of Large-Scale Misinformation Labeled Datasets from Social Media Discourse using Label Refinement

context: Models of sentiment analysis in text typically require both a topic lexicon and a sentiment lexicon, with a need for mapping between these two to understand the specific emotional language used to describe certain topics.
key_idea: The paper introduces an 'affective stereotype lexicon', representing common sentiments and their most noticeable affective attributes associated with them. This qualitatively encodes how we express biases and cliches when talking about familiar topics.
method: The authors construct the affective stereotype lexicon and demonstrate its applicability via a demonstration system called MOODfinger. This system uses the lexicon for affective query expansion and summarization in a system for retrieving and organizing news content from the Web.
outcome: The affective stereotype lexicon developed is shown to be effective via MOODfinger. Though sentiments are bifurcated into simple positive and negative views, the methodology enables users to create their own nuanced moods on demand.
future_impact: While not explicitly mentioned, the successful adoption of the developed affective stereotype lexicon has the potential to enhance sentiment analysis systems, especially in terms of expressing nuanced moods on-demand.
title: In the mood for affective search with web stereotypes

context: XML-search requires a specific language to handle queries effectively, and W3C has proposed requirements for extending XQuery and XPath to manage full-text retrieval. However, problems exist in combining ranking with XML structured queries and meeting user needs.
key_idea: This study draws upon the authors' experience with INEX and evaluates how user needs can be translated into XML queries, influencing the requirements for an XML-search language.
method: The authors analyze the W3C requirements for extending XQuery and XPath with full-text search, comparing it with their experiences from INEX, with a particular focus on how to express user needs and how these needs can be translated into XML queries.
outcome: The analysis shows that the W3C requirements for extending XQuery and XPath with full-text search seem to address most of the needs identified, particularly in terms of implementing a scoring function for answer ranking. However, there are still issues regarding how structural requirements are combined with ranking.
future_impact: This paper's insights about user needs in XML queries and scoring functions could guide future enhancements in the design and implementation of XML-search language, particularly in combining structural requirements with ranking.
title: XML-search Query Language: Needs and Requirements

context: Relevant search terms for conceptual web search are traditionally generated by extracting frequently occurring key terms from retrieved documents. However, this method has limitations, including difficulties in term extraction and interference from irrelevant documents.
key_idea: We propose a semantic term suggestion function called Collective Intelligence based Term Suggestion (CITS), which provides a semantic graph of the search term without limiting to the specific query term and visualizes this graph for users.
method: CITS was compared to two popular commercial search engines through a user study involving 18 users and 50 search terms. In this user study, search results were ranked each time according to their relevance to the related terms in the entire query session.
outcome: The user study showed better user satisfaction with CITS compared to two popular commercial search engines, indicating the potential usefulness of the proposed method in real-world search applications.
future_impact: The success and potential usefulness of the CITS method in real-world search applications suggests potential for widespread adoption and further development.
title: Building term suggestion relational graphs from collective intelligence

context: Protein-protein interaction and biomolecular pathway data are scattered across many disparate, large-scale, publicly-available databases and repositories. They are described using many different taxonomies and ontologies. Sophisticated integration, manipulation, processing and analysis are required to reveal unknown interactions and pathways that can lead to the discovery of new drugs.
key_idea: The BioMANTA project proposes the use of Semantic Web technologies together with a scale-out architecture to efficiently analyse, query, and reason about protein-protein interaction data.
method: The paper introduces the architecture, basic ontology and some of the implementation details of the BioMANTA system that aim to provide efficient, scalable RDF (Resource Description Framework) storage and inferencing.
outcome: This paper presents the initial results of the BioMANTA project and initial performance evaluations, although no specific results or performance metrics are given in the abstract.
future_impact: The completed BioMANTA system will enable knowledge representation and processing that are not currently available in typical scale-out or Semantic Web databases.
title: A scale-out RDF molecule store for distributed processing of biomedical data

context: Answer extraction from discussion boards has been extensively studied, with most existing work relying on supervised methods using similarity features and forum-specific features. However, these methods tend to struggle when applied to a different domain or forum, due to differences in vocabulary and feature availability.
key_idea: The authors propose a domain adaptive answer extractor which operates in two steps: an 'answer recognizer' that identifies sentences likely to be answers, and a 'domain relevance module' that determines the identified answer's domain significance. The methodology is domain-independent for easy adaptation to any domain.
method: The method involves a two-step process: firstly, an 'answer recognizer' identifies potential answers within a post, and secondly, a 'domain relevance' module assesses the domain relevance of the identified answers.
outcome: This paper presents the initial outcomes of this approach in the poster but does not detail specific results within the abstract.
future_impact: The study suggests that its domain-independent methodology could facilitate easy adaption to any given domain for answer extraction with minimal effort, thus potentially addressing a significant existing challenge in information retrieval from discussion forums.
title: Domain adaptive answer extraction for discussion boards

context: Understanding user behavior patterns of repeat consumption in domains like video re-watches, etc., is not sufficiently explored and recency of consumption is considered the strongest predictor of repeat consumption.
key_idea: The authors develop a model predicting that an item from 't' timesteps ago gets reconsumed with a probability proportional to a function of 't'. They also introduce item quality and develop a hybrid model combining both recency and quality to predict user choice.
method: They developed algorithms to learn reconsumption likelihood as a function of 't' and studied theoretical properties of this model. The authors also introduced a method for jointly estimating the parameters of the hybrid model.
outcome: The recency-based model shows a strong fit with the inferred function. The hybrid model combining recency and quality outperforms other alternatives in predicting user choice.
future_impact: This study lays a foundation for a better understanding and modeling of repeat consumption dynamics that could significantly enhance recommendation systems and personalization algorithms.
title: The dynamics of repeat consumption

context: Users of software applications generate vast amounts of unstructured log-trace data that contain clues to their intentions and interests. However, service providers often find it challenging to uncover and exploit these clues for personalization of software and web services.
key_idea: The authors propose a framework for personalizing software and web services that leverages unstructured log-trace data, using a user-modeling technique referred to as cutilization-to-vector, or util2vec.
method: The authors use 6 months of Photoshop usage history and 7 years of interaction records from 67K Behance users to develop and validate util2vec. They demonstrate its application in three scenarios: a user-tagging system, a two-phase recommendation model, and a real-time personalized inspiration engine.
outcome: The framework is shown to be effective in predicting areas of focus for millions of Photoshop users, improving recommendation quality by 21.2% over a popularity-based recommender, and providing real-time personalized inspirations to artists.
