These components include the Performance element, instance selector, critic, earning element, blackboard, and world model.
method: The authors test this model by discussing representative AI, pattern recognition, and control systems within its framework.
outcome: The discussion and analysis of various AI, pattern recognition, and control systems under this framework support the viability of the proposed model for learning systems.
future_impact: The introduction of this model poses the possibility of a more structured and unified approach to learning system design. This will potentially lead to the creation of layered systems, with each layer operating at different levels of abstraction.
title: A model for learning systems

context: Interactive decision support in sequential decision problems often assumes the Decision Maker's preferences, which are representable by an additive utility, are initially unknown or imperfectly known. Current methods struggle with determining optimal policies when utilities are imprecisely defined.
key_idea: A new adaptive preference elicitation method is proposed that interleaves the elicitation of utilities and backward induction to incrementally determine a near-optimal policy.
method: An interactive algorithm with performance guarantees is proposed and numerical tests are conducted to verify the efficacy of the proposed method.
outcome: The numerical tests demonstrate the practical efficiency of the proposed approach, showcasing the performance of the introduced algorithm.
future_impact: The proposed approach introduces a potentially more efficient and accurate method for adaptive preference elicitation which can significantly improve interactive decision support in sequential decision problems.
title: Adaptive Elicitation of Preferences under Uncertainty in Sequential Decision Making Problems

context: Latent Dirichlet allocation (LDA) has been successful in discovering the statistical distribution of the topics over an unstructured text corpus. Recently, more document data, known as semi-structured data, have emerged with rich human-provided tag information due to the evolution of the internet. Modeling such semi-structured documents, which include both unstructured data like plain text and metadata like authorship or tags, is nontrivial.
key_idea: The authors propose a new method to model tagged documents using a topic model called Tag-Weighted Topic Model (TWTM). This leverages the tags in each document to infer the topic components for the documents.
method: The authors design an efficient variational inference method with an EM algorithm for estimating the model parameters and test their TWTM approach against baseline algorithms over three corpora in document modeling and text classification.
outcome: Experimental results show that the TWTM approach outperforms baseline algorithms in document modeling and text classification over three tested corpora.
future_impact: The authors anticipate that the TWTM, which can infer the probabilistic weights of tags for each document, not only learns document-topic distributions, but also infers the tag-topic distributions for text mining. It could impact applications such as classification, clustering, and recommendations.
title: Tag-weighted topic model for mining semi-structured documents

context: Although considerable theoretical research on lifted inference in probabilistic graphical models (PGMs) exists, there are few applications of these methods in combination with top-tier applied algorithms, especially in the field of computer vision (CV).
key_idea: The authors propose the applicability of lifted inference for CV, with the idea that a globally optimal (MAP) labeling will likely have the same label for symmetric pixels. They suggest a generic template for Coarse-to-Fine (C2F) inference in CV, which progressively refines an initial coarsely lifted PGM for different quality-time trade-offs.
method: The team applies their approach to two near state-of-the-art CV algorithms for stereo vision and interactive image segmentation to demonstrate the performance of C2F inference.
outcome: The results show that the lifted versions of the algorithms have superior anytime performance without any loss in final quality, demonstrating an efficient handling of a distinct unary potential on every node (pixel).
future_impact: The proposed lifted inference approach and C2F template could extend to a wide class of algorithms that model a computer vision problem through PGM inference, presenting a new direction for improving algorithm performance.
title: Coarse-to-Fine Lifted MAP Inference in Computer Vision

context: The process of concept formation and conjecture generation in pure mathematics typically requires significant manual effort and expertise.
key_idea: The authors proposed the HR program that automatically forms mathematical concepts, makes conjectures, and uses theorem prover OTTER and model generator MACE to prove or disprove these conjectures.
method: HR measures properties of concepts and assesses the theorems and proofs involving them to estimate each concept’s interestingness, utilizing a best-first search.
outcome: The HR program successfully discovered interesting new mathematics and was capable of building theories from only the axioms of finite algebras.
future_impact: The approach suggests potential for further automation in mathematics, specifically for concept creation, conjecture making and validation.
title: Automatic concept formation in pure mathematics

context: Before this study, there was a lack of effective systems that encouraged sharing and collaborative construction of knowledge bases describing physical domains.
key_idea: The authors introduce CDME (Collaborative Device Modeling Environment), a compositional modeling system for constructing domain theories of physical systems, composing models of devices, and simulating their behavior, with an emphasis on encouraging knowledge sharing.
method: CDME has been implemented as a collection of network services on the World Wide Web, with knowledge represented at three different levels: physical, ontological, and logical.
outcome: CDME effectively supports knowledge sharing at the physical, ontological, and logical levels as described by the authors.
future_impact: CDME, with its emphasis on sharing and collaborative construction of knowledge bases, could encourage more cooperation and synergistic knowledge advancement in the field of physical systems modeling.
title: A Web-Based Compositional Modeling System for Sharing of Physical Knowledge.

context: The Visual Dialogue task involves an agent engaging in a conversation with a human about an image, in which the ability to generate detailed and non-repetitive responses is essential for achieving human-like conversation.
key_idea: The authors propose a novel generative decoding architecture, which uses the Deliberation, Abandon and Memory (DAM) module for generating high-quality responses. This design focuses on transparency and flexibility, with word generation broken down into a series of attention-based information selection steps.
method: The proposed DAM model is applied to three different encoders and the performance is evaluated on the VisDial v1.0 dataset.
outcome: The DAM module provides more detailed and non-repetitive descriptions maintaining semantic accuracy. Experimental results show that the introduced models set a new state-of-the-art performance with high-quality responses.
future_impact: The flexibility of DAM to work with existing visual dialogue encoders and adaptability to encoder structures by constraining the information selection mode could stimulate the development of more sophisticated models for visual dialogue tasks.
title: DAM: Deliberation, Abandon and Memory Networks for Generating Detailed and Non-repetitive Responses in Visual Dialogue

context: Temporal reasoning is widely used in Computer Science and A.I., but its underlying complexity in discrete temporal logics has restricted its use to simplified formalisms such as temporal interval algebras or model checking.
key_idea: The authors propose the development of tractable sub-classes of propositional linear temporal logic based on the use of XOR fragments of the logic, as a new way to engineer tractable temporal logics by rightly combining XOR fragments.
method: The authors use XOR fragments of the logic, and via clausal temporal resolution, they test the decision ability of these fragments. Checks also extend to benefits from combining multiple XOR fragments and establishing the completeness and complexity of the resolution method as applied to such combinations.
outcome: The authors demonstrate that tractable sub-classes of propositional linear temporal logic can be developed based on XOR fragments, show that these fragments can be decided tractably, and details how this temporal language can be used in application areas such as verification of multi-agent systems.
future_impact: This new approach to temporal reasoning provides a new framework where tractable temporal logics can be engineered by rightly combining appropriate XOR fragments, which may be beneficial and influence future approaches to temporal reasoning.
title: Tractable temporal reasoning

context: Epistemic logic programming has an enhanced capacity to handle complex incomplete information reasoning and represent agents' epistemic behaviours, but it also involves much higher computational complexity than non-disjunctive and disjunctive answer set programming.
key_idea: The key idea of this paper is to investigate important properties of epistemic logic programs, and try to extend Lee and Lifschitz's result on loop formulas for disjunctive logic programs to a special class of epistemic logic programs. They also study the polysize model property for epistemic logic programs.
method: The authors extend the result on loop formulas to a special class of epistemic logic programs and study the polysize model property for these programs.
outcome: The authors identify two non-trivial classes of epistemic logic programs whose consistency checking complexity is reduced from PSPACE-complete to NP-complete and Σ2P-complete.
future_impact: The paper observes that many important applications on epistemic representation fall into these two classes of epistemic logic programs, indicating potential future impact on the application of such logic programs.
title: Epistemic reasoning in logic programs

context: Detecting and measuring objects to represent three-dimensional outdoor scenes is a crucial field of study, especially while using data obtained from stereo vision or scanning laser rangefinders.
key_idea: The paper offers a new method for object detection and measurement in three-dimensional outdoor scenes. The method relies on approximating objects using ellipsoids, segmenting them from the background and each other by fitting ellipsoids, clustering points, and adjusting the clusters as per the fit.
method: The proposed methodology involves segmentation of objects by finding the ground surface, forming a preliminary segmentation by clustering the points above the ground, fitting ellipsoids to match these clusters and avoid obscuring other points, and adjusting the clusters according to the fits. An example showing implementation of this method is provided using a stereo pair of pictures of Mars from the Viking Lander.
outcome: The proposed method is specifically useful for obstacle avoidance and navigation in exploring vehicles, with the example results reflecting its successful application on pictures from the Viking Lander.
future_impact: The method may contribute to advancements in navigation and obstacle avoidance in exploring vehicles such as a Mars rover.
title: Object detection and measurement using stereo vision

context: Metaphorical interpretation and affect detection using context profiles from open-ended text input represent challenging tasks in the field of affective language processing.
key_idea: This study explores recognition of certain affective metaphorical phenomena and context-based affect sensing by modeling speakers' improvisational mood and other participants' emotional influence in the context of loosely structured scenarios.
method: The updated affect detection module, which includes these new developments, is implemented into an AI agent.
outcome: The implementation of the updated module in the AI agent has generally increased the agent's performance in affect sensing tasks.
future_impact: This work stays aligned with conference themes relevant to affective dialogue processing, human-agent interaction, and intelligent user interfaces, implying its future usefulness in these domains.
title: Affect sensing in metaphorical phenomena and dramatic interaction context

context: Coalitional games are widely studied, but they traditionally assume full information about each agent's capabilities or types, which does not effectively capture real-world scenarios where agents have private beliefs about others.
key_idea: The paper introduces coalitional games with beliefs (CGBs), a generalization of coalitional games where agents have private beliefs about the capabilities or types of other agents.
method: The authors study coalitional stability in this new setting, introducing a notion of the core for CGBs with and without coalition structures. A characterization of the core is provided for simple CGBs without coalition structures, along with a polynomial-time algorithm to check core nonemptiness. The study also explores complexity implications in games with coalition structures.
outcome: The study finds that in games without coalition structures, the core of CGBs can be analyzed in a way that matches the full information case, and core nonemptiness can be checked in polynomial time. However, when coalitions structures are introduced, allowing for agents' beliefs increases the complexity of stability-related problems.
future_impact: The introduced model could be used to represent more complex real-world cases in coalitional games and could establish connections with other classes of coalitional games. In particular, the work on weighted voting games with beliefs could be of independent interest.
title: Simple coalitional games with beliefs

context: Inferencing for SROEL(×), a description logic that includes the main features of OWL EL, has been a topic of recent research but does not yet have efficient rule-based deduction systems for various reasoning tasks and logical sublanguages.
key_idea: The authors have developed rule-based deduction systems for various reasoning tasks and logical sublanguages within SROEL(×), a subset of OWL EL.
method: The authors review recent results on inferencing for SROEL(×) and evaluate the efficiency of the developed systems.
outcome: The study found that certain feature combinations lead to increased space upper bounds for materialisation, suggesting that efficient implementations are easier to obtain for suitable fragments of OWL EL.
future_impact: The discovery about feature combinations could guide the development of more efficient implementations for OWL EL.
title: Efficient rule-based inferencing for OWL EL

context: The current strategies deployed to solve dynamic games focus on equilibrium refinement but are limited in their scalability and applicability.
key_idea: The authors propose Temporal-Induced Self-Play (TISP), a novel reinforcement learning-based algorithm that uses belief-space representation, backward induction, policy learning, and non-parametric approximation to find strategies with good performances from any point in the game onwards.
method: The TISP-based policy-gradient-based algorithm, TISP-PG, is tested in various games, including finite repeated security games and a grid-world game.
outcome: The authors found that TISP-PG is more scalable than existing mathematical programming-based methods and significantly outperforms other learning-based methods.
future_impact: The TISP-based algorithms can find approximate Perfect Bayesian Equilibrium in zero-sum one-sided stochastic Bayesian games with finite horizon, suggesting their potential impact in constructing improved solutions for dynamic games.
title: Temporal Induced Self-Play for Stochastic Bayesian Games.

context: Previous investigations into contingent planning have explored the use of various state representations, but the relative effectiveness of Conjunctive Normal Form (CNF) and Disjunctive Normal Form (DNF) representations remains unclear.
key_idea: This study develops a new contingent planner, CNFct, which extends a previous representation of CNF for conformant planning to handle nondeterministic and sensing actions for contingent planning, and also proposes a new heuristic function for both CNF and DNF based contingent planners.
method: The researchers conduct experiments using the new planner, CNFct, along with DNFct. Then, they analyze their performance on a series of benchmarks.
outcome: The study found that both CNFct and DNFct offer very competitive performance across a range of benchmarks, though neither definitively outperforms the other. The paper identifies certain properties of the representation schemes that can influence their performance on diverse problems.
future_impact: The insights gained on the effect of representation schemes on planner performance could guide the design of more effective contingent planning systems in the future.
title: On the effectiveness of CNF and DNF representations in contingent planning

context: Modern machine learning algorithms, which rely on several design decisions, render the problem of Hyperparameter Optimization (HPO) crucial, necessitating an efficient approach to handle it.
key_idea: The authors propose DEHB, a novel HPO method that combines the advantages of Hyperband and Differential Evolution.
method: The authors conduct comprehensive experiments on a wide range of HPO problems and tabular benchmarks from neural architecture search to assess the efficacy of DEHB.
outcome: DEHB outperforms previous HPO methods, especially for high-dimensional problems with discrete input dimensions, and is up to 1000 times faster than random search.
future_impact: DEHB's robust performance, efficiency, simplicity, and easy implementation positions it well to become a new default HPO method in machine learning.
title: DEHB - Evolutionary Hyberband for Scalable, Robust and Efficient Hyperparameter Optimization.

context: Most research on narrative text summarisation has been conducted within the paradigm of experimental psychology, but recent language processing research in artificial intelligence suggests that the predominant theory of text summarisation requires further examination.
key_idea: This paper interrogates whether the story grammar model, stemming from psychology, or the plot unit model, developed within AI, offers a better framework for text summarisation.
method: Summary data from 72 subjects is presented and analyzed in terms of two summarization models: the story grammar model of psychology and the plot unit model developed in artificial intelligence. The predictions of the two models are compared for short term summarization.
outcome: The authors identify two complicating factors that have a significant impact on summarisation behavior, indicating that neither model alone fully explains the experimental data.
future_impact: The findings call for further exploration of the impacts of the two identified factors and refinement of existing models to better understand text summarization.
title: Summarizing narratives

context: The concept of composing tuples from two relations to derive additional tuples of one of these relations is an existing approach, but the determination of when the composition is plausible and for which relation the new tuples are derived is not clearly defined.
key_idea: The authors introduce an extended composition approach to inferencing, that involves a formal definition of composition and an extension to the existing concept of composition.
method: The authors define conditions on the domains and ranges of the relations that are necessary for extended composition to occur, and propose an algebra that combines primitives to determine plausible composition. The method for extended composition is then applied to a representative group of semantic relations.
outcome: The authors successfully developed a methodology for determining plausible composition in the context of the composition of tuples from two relations. This method was evaluated by applying it to a representative group of semantic relations but the specific results are not mentioned.
future_impact: The authors anticipate that their method for extended composition may influence future inferencing approaches involving the composition of tuples from two relations, though they do not explicitly state future studies or impacts.
title: Plausible inferencing using extended composition

context: The research work addresses the challenging task of video-language segmentation, where the goal is to segment the object or actor described by a sentence in video frames. The description often refers to multiple attributes, including nearby objects with spatial relations, making the task complex.
key_idea: The paper proposes a novel mechanism, Polar Relative Positional Encoding (PRPE), that represents spatial relations in terms of direction and range, allowing for a more direct interaction between sentence features and positional embeddings.
method: The authors employ the PRPE to design a Polar Attention Module (PAM), a basic module for vision-language fusion, and test it on the A2D Sentences dataset and the J-HMDB Sentences dataset.
outcome: The proposed method outperforms the previous best method by a large margin, with an 11.4% absolute improvement in Mean Average Precision (mAP) on the A2D Sentences dataset. It also achieves competitive performances on the J-HMDB Sentences dataset.
future_impact: While not explicitly mentioned by the authors, the significant improvement in video-language segmentation obtained by the proposed method could potentially influence future research and applications in the field of video processing and vision-language tasks.
title: Polar Relative Positional Encoding for Video-Language Segmentation

context: Despite the success of Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) in graph representation learning, adapting GNN-variants to hypergraphs, which allow for better modelling of higher-order correlations among entities, remains a challenge due to the lack of a suitable framework.
key_idea: This paper proposes UniGNN - a unified framework which interprets the message passing process in both graph and hypergraph neural networks, enabling the generalization of established GNN models to hypergraphs.
method: The authors conduct extensive experiments on multiple real-world datasets, and also compare the distinguishing capacities of UniGNN models to the 1-dimensional Generalized Weisfeiler-Leman (1-GWL) algorithm.
outcome: The UniGNN framework, applied to multiple datasets, outperforms state-of-the-art approaches, particularly increasing accuracy from 77.4% to 88.8% in semi-supervised hypernode classification on the DBLP dataset. It is further demonstrated that UniGNN models based on message passing are at most as powerful as the 1-GWL algorithm in distinguishing non-isomorphic hypergraphs.
future_impact: This work provides a modality for better understanding and adapting GNN models to hypergraphs; the extension of GNNs to hypergraphs could be instrumental in more efficiently addressing problems requiring the modeling of higher-order correlations among entities.
title: UniGNN - a Unified Framework for Graph and Hypergraph Neural Networks.

context: Random Forests (RFs) are widely used in Machine Learning but are not interpretable, and there are no dedicated non-heuristic approaches for explaining RFs. Additionally, while recent work has proposed polynomial algorithms for explaining other ML models, it is unclear if explanations for RFs can be solved in polynomial time.
key_idea: The thesis of this paper is twofold; firstly, it proves that finding a PI-explanation for RFs is D^P-complete, thereby making it non-trivial. Secondly, it proposes a propositional encoding method aimed at finding PI-explanations with a SAT solver, presenting an alternative to previous methods that rely on SMT/MILP encodings.
method: The authors use a SAT solver alongside a propositional encoding to find explanations for RFs. They carry out experiments on a variety of publicly available data sets to assess the scalability and effectiveness of their proposed approach.
outcome: The SAT-based method was shown to scale well with commonly used RF sizes and significantly outperform existing heuristic methods in most considered examples.
future_impact: The results of this study indicate that the SAT-based approach could improve the interpretability of RFs in practical applications.
title: On Explaining Random Forests with SAT.

context: The doctrine of double effect (DDE) is a long-studied ethical principle that governs when actions that have both positive and negative effects are to be allowed. However, the automation of this doctrine remained unaddressed.
key_idea: The authors present an attempt to automate the DDE using a first-order modal logic, the deontic cognitive event calculus. They extend this to stronger versions of the principle and aim to use this approach for building DDE-compliant autonomous systems or verifying DDE compliance in existing AI systems.
method: The authors formalize the DDE and present its formalizations in the form of increasingly stronger versions, including the doctrine of triple effect. They then simulate scenarios that have been used to test for the presence of the principle in human subjects and sketch initial work on applying their DDE layer to the STRIPS-style planning model and a modified POMDP model.
outcome: The authors successfully use their framework to simulate scenarios to test for DDE presence and provide initial application sketches of the DDE layer to STRIPS-style planning model and a modified POMDP model, which show the feasibility of the intended use.
future_impact: The presented work can be useful for other researchers in incorporating DDE in their own frameworks, ultimately allowing the creation of AI systems that comply with DDE or verifying DDE compliance in existing AI systems.
title: On automating the doctrine of double effect

context: Online stochastic multiple vehicle routing with time windows, where requests arrive dynamically and the goal is to maximize the number of serviced customers, has typically involved moving vehicles only to known customers.
key_idea: This paper proposes investigating waiting and relocation strategies for vehicle routing, in which vehicles may wait at their current location or relocate to arbitrary sites, as opposed to only moving to known customers.
method: The paper uses an experimental approach to test the efficacy of these proposed waiting and relocation strategies in improving customer service in highly dynamic problems with many late requests.
outcome: Experimental results show that waiting and relocation strategies may dramatically improve customer service, especially for problems that are highly dynamic and contain many late requests.
future_impact: The proposed waiting and relocation strategies could set a foundation for developing more effective online algorithms for vehicle routing, without the need to exploit any problem-specific features.
title: Waiting and relocation strategies in online stochastic vehicle routing

context: Prior knowledge acquisition systems typically relied on rule-based representations, which may not be optimal for capturing domain-familiar concepts or facilitating easily-understood debugging techniques.
key_idea: The authors introduce TEST (Troubleshooting Expert System Tool), an architecture that utilizes a schematic representation, leading to a knowledge base characterized by the use of domain-familiar concepts.
method: The methodology of this study mainly involves the development of TDE (TEST Development Environment), which is characterized by features such as facilitating knowledge base development through interviews and direct icon manipulation, multiple knowledge-based browsing strategies, heuristic error analysis, and easily-understood debugging techniques.
outcome: TEST has led to a more efficient development of TDE, exhibited by its multiple features, such as direct interviews, heuristic error analysis, and debugging techniques.
future_impact: The novel schematic representation in the TEST architecture can facilitate more user-friendly knowledge acquisition systems development and analysis techniques in the future.
title: From application shell to knowledge acquisition system

context: Learning for kernel machines with differentiable loss functions is still a time-consuming process, and the optimization problem conditioning is not ideal, while existing techniques do not provide satisfactory performance.
key_idea: The authors propose the Kernel Conjugate Gradient (KCG), a novel variant of the conjugate gradient algorithm that aims to both streamline learning for kernel machines with differentiable loss functions and condition the optimization problem better.
method: The effectiveness of KCG is evaluated by applying it to various differentiable kernel learning problems and comparing its performance with existing techniques.
outcome: It is observed that Kernel Conjugate Gradient consistently and significantly outperforms existing techniques in differentiable kernel learning problems.
future_impact: Data-structure techniques recently used to speed up kernel machine approaches are compatible with this algorithm, offering potential for future efficiency improvements in training, particularly in function evaluation and RKHS inner product computation.
title: Kernel conjugate gradient for fast kernel machines

context: The Knuth-Bendix completion procedure was introduced as a means of deriving canonical term-rewriting systems to serve as decision procedures for given equational theories.
key_idea: The authors propose using the Knuth-Bendix completion procedure to synthesize both logic programs and functional programs from specifications and domain knowledge expressed as equivalence-preserving rewrite rules.
method: The authors plan to implement their proposed technique on specifications and domain knowledge provided in the form of equivalence-preserving rewrite rules.
outcome: An implementation of the proposed idea has begun, but no specific outcomes or results are reported.
future_impact: The research may establish a novel way to use term-rewriting systems for programming tasks, although this potential is not explicitly addressed in the abstract.
title: Synthesis by completion

context: Testing embedded software systems on control units of vehicles is an essential and safety-relevant task, however, developing test suites for these tests is a time-consuming process.
key_idea: The authors propose an automation process for generating tests for control software based on a specification of requirements in terms of finite state machines. They describe converting these state machine representations into relational models for the application of test generation algorithms.
method: The authors apply the test generation algorithm to a real example of control software for vehicle control units and analyze the results.
outcome: The authors successfully present the transformation of a finite state machine representation into a relational model and the application of the test generation algorithm to a real-world example. However, the abstract does not provide specific numerical results.
future_impact: The paper hints at specific challenges regarding software testing, indicating that further research may focus on addressing these challenges.
title: Fault-model-based test generation for embedded software

context: The focus on algorithmic recommendation process for children in both research and industries is growing, and a diverse community around this topic has started to form.
key_idea: The purpose of the 2nd Workshop of the International and Interdisciplinary Perspectives on Children & Recommender Systems (KidRec 2018) was to gather a diverse group of participants to continue to build community around this important topic and to facilitate discussions on salient research questions and the next steps for this area.
method: The workshop invited a diverse group of participants from K-12 teachers, educators, computer science researchers, and industry participants, and organized discussions.
outcome: The workshop resulted in building community around the topic, further discussing and outlining the salient research questions and identifying the next steps for promoting more research in this area.
future_impact: The community’s efforts will promote more research in the area of children's recommendation systems.
title: Building Community: Report on the 2nd International and Interdisciplinary Perspectives on Children & Recommender Systems (KidRec) at IDC 2018

context: Image retrieval by text query is a challenging problem and current methods might not be providing satisfactory performance.
key_idea: This paper formulates image retrieval by text query as a vector space classification problem, creating a high-dimensional visual vocabulary to represent image documents in great detail.
method: The authors apply well-known text retrieval techniques such as Rocchio tf-idf and naive Bayes to the semantic image retrieval problem, and test these methods on a subset of Corel images.
outcome: The proposed approach achieved state-of-the-art retrieval performance on a subset of Corel images.
future_impact: The proposed methods have the potential to advance the field of image retrieval using text queries.
title: High-dimensional visual vocabularies for image retrieval

context: The problem of systematically identifying anomalies in music datasets in an unsupervised manner remains unresolved.
key_idea: The authors present an unsupervised method for anomaly detection in music datasets integrating categorical regression and robust estimation techniques designed to infer anomalous scores in music clips.
method: The authors apply the method to a music genre recognition dataset to test its ability to detect corrupted, distorted, or mislabeled audio samples based on commonly used features in music information retrieval.
outcome: Evaluation results show the algorithm surpasses other anomaly detection methods and is capable of finding problematic samples that were identified by human experts.
future_impact: The proposed method provides a preliminary framework for anomaly detection in music data, potentially serving as a useful tool for improving data integrity in future.
title: An Unsupervised Approach to Anomaly Detection in Music Datasets

context: Accurate skill retrieval is a key factor for the success of modern conversational AI agents, but the major challenges lie in the ambiguity of human spoken language and the wide spectrum of candidate skills.
key_idea: The authors propose a self-adaptive dialogue system (AdaDial) for conversational AI agents that implements a user feedback enhanced reranking strategy.
method: The authors use a scalable schema for user feedback estimation and a feedback enhanced reranking model with customized feature encoding, target attention based feature assembling, and multi-task learning.
outcome: Online experimental results indicate that AdaDial can retrieve desired skills for different users in different scenarios and correct its regular strategy according to negative feedback. AdaDial is deployed on a large-scale conversational AI agents with tens of millions daily queries, enhancing user experience.
future_impact: The method brings continued positive impacts on user experience of large-scale conversational AI agents, and potentially further studies could improve the self-adaptive capability.
title: User Feedback and Ranking in-a-Loop: Towards Self-Adaptive Dialogue Systems

context: Currently, fulltext indexing is extensively used in information retrieval systems.
key_idea: The authors propose the use of generic summaries for indexing in information retrieval, indicating that they can be as effective as fulltext indexing for precision-oriented search of highly relevant documents.
method: The study investigates the effectiveness of a summary index with or without pseudo-relevance feedback and compare it with the corresponding fulltext index. Additionally, it investigates the combination of using a summary index at the initial search and a fulltext index at the final search.
outcome: The authors find that a summary index, ideally using a compression ratio of 10-30%, can be as effective as fulltext indexing for precision-oriented searches. Moreover, the combination of a summary index at initial search and a fulltext index at final search proves effective, likely better than just using the summary index.
future_impact: This research suggests that the strategy of combining summary and fulltext indexing could potentially improve precision-oriented search outcomes in information retrieval.
title: Generic summaries for indexing in information retrieval

context: The development of entity-relationship (E-R) search techniques has been hindered because of a shortage of test collections, particularly for queries that involve multiple entities and relationships.
key_idea: The authors present a method for creating E-R test queries from content available in tabular form where columns symbolize entity types and the structure implies one or more relationships among the entities, and the creation of the RELink(test collection).
method: Queries and relevance judgments are formulated from table contents. Editorial labor involves the creation of natural language queries based on relations represented by table entries. The authors create the RELink Framework that includes Apache Lucene indexing and search specifically tailored to E-R retrieval.
outcome: A new test collection, called RELink, comprising 600 queries and relevance judgements was created from a sample of Wikipedia List-of-lists-of-lists tables. The authors also developed the open-source RELink Framework, which provides specific Apache Lucene indexing and search for E-R retrieval.
future_impact: The creation of the 'RELink' framework can expedite entity-relationship research by providing ready-to-use search resources and a comprehensive test collection.
title: RELink: A Research Framework and Test Collection for Entity-Relationship Retrieval

context: ECIR, the European Conference on Information Retrieval, is a main forum for the presentation of research results in information retrieval and related areas. Since 1998, it has alternated between the UK and continental Europe, but this rule was removed starting from 2012.
key_idea: The 35th ECIR conference took place in Moscow, Russia, marking the first time it was held in the east, introducing new features like a two-tier program committee, a redesigned mentoring program, and a session for poster presentations.
method: The conference received submissions of full papers, posters, and demonstrations. All submissions were reviewed by members of an international two-tier Program Committee. Selection for oral presentation and poster/short presentation was also conducted.
outcome: ECIR 2013 attracted a high number of participants and accepted papers, leading to a 900-page proceedings volume. It received a total of 287 submissions across three categories (191 full papers, 78 posters, and 18 demonstrations) and accepted 30 for oral presentation, 25 for poster/short presentation, 38 posters and 10 demonstrations.
future_impact: The successful organization and increased number of participants of ECIR 2013, as well as the introduction of new features in the conference, signals a potential for further development and expansion in the future.
title: ECIR 2013: 35th european conference on information retrieval

context: The explosion of information on the World Wide Web has resulted in an ongoing challenge of efficiently accessing this vast amount of data. Information Retrieval (IR) tackles this challenge by exploring approaches to obtain relevant information items from a large collection of textual data. Recently, the potential contribution of entities extracted from large volumes of free text to retrieval effectiveness has become an active area of exploration in the research community.
key_idea: This thesis investigates leveraging entities to improve retrieval in several ways. It proposes a new paradigm of finding entities with certain semantic relations to directly meet the user's information needs, unlike the traditional document retrieval. The thesis also introduces a novel probabilistic framework that uses supporting documents to model the relevance between queries and entities.
method: The research includes retrieval experiments such as entity-centric query expansion, where related entities of a query are identified and query expansion is performed using the names and relations of these entities. It also includes entity-centric relevance modeling, where the Latent Entity Space (LES) retrieval approach is proposed that uses entity profiles to represent semantic content of documents and queries.
outcome: The study shows significant improvements over several state-of-the-art feedback models on multiple data collections in entity-centric query expansion. In entity-centric relevance modeling, LES effectively captures latent semantic content and improves the search accuracy of several state-of-the-art retrieval models for entity-bearing queries.
future_impact: The thesis reveals the potential benefits of using entities to improve retrieval effectiveness. With the fast curation of high-quality knowledge bases, it is expected that more information about entities could be easily integrated into retrieval models and applied to more applications. This work could serve as guidance for future research leveraging entities to improve information retrieval.
title: Entity Centric Information Retrieval

context: The process of remembering and entering query terms for information retrieval from TV watching activities can be burdensome.
key_idea: The researchers conduct a study involving a one-button search interface named Video Bookmarking Search, which utilizes closed captions from watching TV to estimate query terms through named-entity recognition and sentence labeling techniques, alleviating the need to manually enter queries.
method: The researchers conducted an empirical evaluation with 1,138 search queries from 206 bookmarks using seven actual TV shows on city life, travel, health, and cuisine.
outcome: The results demonstrated that the one-button search resulted in a wider variety of queries and search results, even though the number of directly relevant results was not high.
future_impact: While not directly stated, this research may inform future development of more user-friendly information retrieval interfaces that can interpret and respond to user interests beyond specific query terms.
title: One-button search extracts wider interests: an empirical study with video bookmarking search

context: The goal of search result diversification is to select a subset of documents from the candidate set to satisfy as many different subtopics as possible. Existing methods often handle this challenging NP-hard problem by ranking the documents with greedy sequential document selection, often leading to suboptimal rankings.
key_idea: The authors propose Monte Carlo tree search (MCTS) enhanced Markov decision process (MDP), referred to as M$^2$Div, which formalizes diverse ranking construction as an MDP, and uses a recurrent neural network to guide document selection and predict ranking quality.
method: The proposed M$^2$Div approach, including the use of a recurrent neural network and MCTS for document selection and predicting ranking quality, is tested using the TREC benchmarks.
outcome: Experimental results using TREC benchmarks showed that the proposed M$^2$Div approach can significantly outperform the state-of-the-art baselines based on greedy sequential document selection.
future_impact: The demonstrated effectiveness of the exploratory decision-making mechanism in M$^2$Div could inspire new approaches in the subset selection and document ranking problem space.
title: From Greedy Selection to Exploratory Decision-Making: Diverse Ranking with Policy-Value Networks

context: Entity disambiguation, which is the task of mapping ambiguous terms in natural-language text to its entities in a knowledge base, is crucial in applications like extraction of structured data from textual documents and in facilitating AI applications such as Semantic Search, Reasoning and Question & Answering.
key_idea: The authors propose a novel collective, graph-based disambiguation algorithm utilizing semantic entity and document embeddings for robust entity disambiguation, which is able to achieve better results over a wide range of data sets.
method: The authors evaluate their proposed algorithm on 9 different datasets, demonstrating its performance without dataset-specific tuning.
outcome: Their evaluation indicates that their approach achieves significantly (>5%) better results than all other publicly available disambiguation algorithms on 7 of 9 datasets.
future_impact: The authors discuss the influence of the quality of the knowledge base on the disambiguation accuracy, suggesting that the proposed algorithm has potential to achieve better results than non-publicly available state-of-the-art algorithms as the quality of the knowledge base improves.
title: Robust and Collective Entity Disambiguation through Semantic Embeddings

context: Neural approaches that use pre-trained language models are effective at various ranking tasks. However, there is a gap in comparing the effectiveness of these neural approaches and feature-based Learning-to-Rank (LtR) methods, due to differences in how these methods are evaluated: LtR benchmarks contain feature vectors but no raw text, while neural models are evaluated on text but no feature vectors.
key_idea: The paper introduces Istella22, a novel dataset that bridges this gap by including both query-document text and query-document feature vectors, enabling a fair comparison of both traditional LtR and transfer ranking techniques on the same data.
method: The authors conducted preliminary experiments on Istella22, a dataset consisting of a comprehensive corpus of 8.4M web documents, relevance judgments, and a set of 2,198 textual queries used for testing purposes.
outcome: Preliminary experiments on Istella22 found that neural re-ranking approaches were less effective than LtR models, but that LtR models considered the scores from neural models as strong signals.
future_impact: Istella22, with its combination of query-document text and feature vectors, provides a platform to more fairly evaluate traditional learning-to-rank and transfer ranking techniques, and further our understanding of their strengths and weaknesses.
title: The Istella22 Dataset: Bridging Traditional and Neural Learning to Rank Evaluation

context: In evidence-based medicine, PICO (Patient, Intervention, Comparator, and Outcome) annotations in medical literature are used for automatic relevant document filtering. However, defining boundaries for PICO elements in text is challenging due to diverse interpretations.
key_idea: This paper focuses on analyzing the agreement of PICO annotations made by multiple human annotators, both experts and non-experts, using a standard span agreement method (matching both labels and boundaries of text spans) and two types of relaxed span agreement methods (matching labels without guaranteeing matching boundaries).
method: The authors performed an analysis on the agreement of PICO span annotations made by different human annotators using standard and relaxed span agreement methods.
outcome: The study found that boundaries of PICO span annotations by individual annotators are very diverse, and despite the disagreement in span boundaries, general areas of the span annotations are broadly agreed by annotators. The results also revealed that using standard agreement alone may undermine the agreement of PICO spans.
future_impact: This study suggests that adopting both standard and relaxed agreements may be more suitable for PICO span evaluation, which can potentially improve the quality and reliability of PICO annotations in evidence-based medicine.
title: A Study on Agreement in PICO Span Annotations

context: Most major application (app) marketplaces rank and recommend apps based on search relevance features or marketplace popularity statistics, such as similarity between app descriptions and user search queries, or the number of downloads and user ratings. However, these rankings do not capture the dynamics of the app ecosystem, including the dependencies between apps.
key_idea: In this paper, the authors propose the concept of interoperability ranking for mobile applications. It ranks apps based on their importance to other apps in the ecosystem and can answer questions such as which app is more likely to be launched in a particular user context and whether one app provides complementary functionality to another.
method: The authors outline a set of methods for computing interoperability ranks, and validate these approaches using real data from the Windows Phone app marketplace.
outcome: The paper does not provide specific outcomes or results of the analysis performed on the real data from the Windows Phone app marketplace.
future_impact: The authors anticipate that the notion of interoperability ranking could contribute to solving problems attracting the attention of both researchers and industry, such as building personalized real-time app recommender systems or intelligent mobile agents.
title: Interoperability ranking for mobile applications

context: The current signature file organizations employ either key-based or bit-sliced partitioning strategies, respective performance of which is quite bad for handling queries having various number of query terms.
key_idea: A new signature file organization is proposed that combines key-based and bit-sliced partitioning strategies for a more efficient search performance for queries with an arbitrary number of terms.
method: The design of the new organization is based on theoretical analysis of key-based and bit-sliced approaches, taking into account an abstract storage structure model.
outcome: The proposed approach achieves high search performance for queries containing an arbitrary number of terms, implying an improvement over the limitations of bit-sliced or key-based organization individually.
future_impact: Discussion of update performance and a generalization of the method show potential for future research to further adjust the trade-off between search efficiency and maintenance costs.
title: Key-based partitioned bit-sliced signature file

context: Web search engines, which millions of people use daily, employ ranking algorithms that greatly influence which pages users visit. However, there is limited understanding of how these algorithms favor different sites or points of view.
key_idea: The authors present PAWS, a platform to analyze differences among web search engines by measuring content emphasis i.e., the correlation between differences in search engine rankings and features of the ranked content (like point of view and advertisements). They also propose a novel technique to identify orientations in search results at scale, minimizing the expected number of human judgments required.
method: PAWS was applied to analyze news searches on Google and Bing, assessing the engines' emphasis on results expressing different orientations and containing different types of advertisements.
outcome: The authors found no evidence that Google or Bing emphasize results expressing positive orientation towards the engine company's products. However, they found that these engines do emphasize particular news sites and favor pages containing their company's advertisements rather than competitor advertisements.
future_impact: PAWS could help users gain more transparent access to the Web's information by informing them when different engines favor certain sites or points of view.
title: Analyzing the content emphasis of web search engines

context: Customers find useful tips extracted from product reviews helpful for informed purchase decisions and better product usage. However, the validity of these tips has not been thoroughly examined based on the degree of support or opposition they receive from all product reviews.
key_idea: The authors propose a classifier to determine the degree to which product tips are supported or contradicted by review sentences, creating aggregated global support and contradiction scores that reflect the overall support-level of all reviews for a specific tip.
method: By analyzing a large set of tips extracted from product reviews, the classifier assigns them to one of the proposed categories: highly-supported, highly-contradicted, controversial (both supported and contradicted), and anecdotal (neither supported nor contradicted).
outcome: The system's classification provides a global support score and a global contradiction score, improving customer confidence in the validity of a given tip.
future_impact: With this method, customers could make more informed purchase decisions and better use of products while potentially influencing future e-commerce platforms to incorporate similar features.
title: Analyzing the Support Level for Tips Extracted from Product Reviews

context: While the World Wide Web provides a large amount of text in many languages, cross-lingual parallel data is difficult to obtain. It is however crucial for a variety of tasks in natural language processing with applications in machine translation, cross-lingual information retrieval, and document classification, as well as learning cross-lingual representations.
key_idea: The authors propose the end-to-end process of searching the web for parallel cross-lingual text. They motivate obtaining parallel text as a retrieval problem and introduce techniques for searching for cross-lingual parallel data based on language, content, and other metadata.
method: The authors introduce multilingual sentence embeddings as a core tool, demonstrating techniques and models that leverage them for identifying parallel documents and sentences as well as techniques for retrieving and filtering this data.
outcome: The authors describe several large-scale datasets curated using these techniques and show how training on sentences extracted from parallel or comparable documents mined from the Web can improve machine translation models and facilitate cross-lingual NLP.
future_impact: This process of retrieving and curating cross-lingual parallel data may impact the performance of future machine translation models and cross-lingual NLP applications.
title: Searching the Web for Cross-lingual Parallel Data

context: Previous studies mainly extract set names for a group of entities from knowledge bases which offer high-quality entity relations but struggle with a limited range of entities and set names representing wide semantic classes.
key_idea: The authors propose AutoName, an unsupervised framework that generates set names for a set of query entities from a large-scale text corpus. It generates candidate labels by examining a pre-trained language model and the entities' context in documents.
method: Candidate phrases are clustered to find those describing common concepts among entities. AutoName then ranks the refined phrases based on the co-occurrences of their words with the query entities and the conceptual integrity of their clusters. A new benchmark dataset consisting of 130 entity sets with name labels was also built for testing purposes.
outcome: The experimental results reveal that AutoName can create coherent and meaningful set names, significantly surpassing all baseline methods.
future_impact: AutoName would be beneficial in various tasks related to natural language processing and information retrieval such as session-based and conversational information seeking.
title: AutoName: A Corpus-Based Set Naming Framework

context: Internet memes, known for their non-standard writing and network vocabulary, have become a communicating medium for users worldwide. As most existing research largely ignores the rich metaphorical information in memes, this poses a tricky challenge in natural language processing.
key_idea: This paper introduces MET-Meme, a novel multimodal meme dataset specifically enriched with metaphorical features to facilitate better analysis of Internet memes when it comes to sentiment analysis and semantic understanding tasks.
method: MET-Meme, consisting of 10045 text-image pairs, is manually annotated with the occurrence of metaphors, sentiment categories, intentions, and degree of offensiveness. The authors propose a range of strong baseline models to showcase the importance of integrating metaphorical features for meme sentiment analysis and semantic understanding.
outcome: The authors have publicly released the MET-Meme dataset and its corresponding code for research purposes.
future_impact: The introduction of the MET-Meme dataset could significantly enhance research in the area of meme analysis, especially in the context of sentiment analysis and semantic understanding tasks.
title: MET-Meme: A Multimodal Meme Dataset Rich in Metaphors

context: Query suggestion mechanisms are widely used by search engines, but there is a lack of a commonly accepted evaluation methodology and metrics for this area. The metrics used often lack proper justification and it is unclear if reported improvements result in an actual improvement in the user experience.
key_idea: The paper addresses the evaluation issue by creating a new family of user models based on users' interaction with search engines' query log. They also propose two novel metrics, pSaved and eSaved, for evaluating query suggestions based on a query log-based evaluation approach.
method: The authors propose to study the users' behaviour from a search engine's query log to develop their new user models and metrics. The effectiveness of pSaved and eSaved was evaluated by comparing with pre-existing metrics on a dataset of 6.1M sessions.
outcome: The experimental results showed that the newly proposed metrics, pSaved and eSaved, show the best alignment with the users' satisfaction compared to other metrics considered.
future_impact: The new family of user models and the proposed metrics could establish a more reliable standard for evaluating query suggestion mechanisms, potentially leading to more meaningful improvements in users' experience.
title: User model-based metrics for offline query suggestion evaluation

context: Metasearch is a process that involves combining the ranked lists of documents returned by multiple search engines for a given query to optimize the performance of the combination. Existing metasearch strategies don't always achieve best performance.
key_idea: The paper presents three contributions to metasearch: a model based on the Borda Count, a model based on Bayesian inference, and a model for obtaining upper bounds on the performance of metasearch algorithms.
method: The authors investigated these new metasearch models with rigorous experiments, comparing them with the performance of the best input system and existing metasearch strategies.
outcome: The experimental results showed that metasearch algorithms based on the proposed models (Borda count and Bayesian inference) frequently outperform the best input system and are competitive with existing metasearch strategies.
future_impact: The initial upper bounds demonstrate that there is much to be learned about the limits of metasearch performance, possibly leading to better future strategies or methods.
title: Models for metasearch

context: Current user models for evaluating metrics for search engine results fail to account for time spent by the user and various user behaviors when scanning a ranked result list.
key_idea: The authors propose a family of new evaluation measures, called Markov Precision (MP), that utilize continuous-time and discrete-time Markov chains to inject user models into precision and account for both time spent and different behaviors in scanning a ranked result list.
method: Through the use of Markov models, the authors recreate average precision using specific user models. The reliability of MP is tested with a thorough experimental evaluation on standard TREC collections and an example of calibration of MP's time parameters based on click logs from Yandex.
outcome: MP is found to be as reliable as other measures in the TREC collections experiment, and an example of successful calibration of time parameters was demonstrated with the Yandex click logs data.
future_impact: The flexibility of the proposed Markov Precision can lead to more realistic user models in evaluating the effectiveness of search engines, improving precision considering different user behaviors and time spent on search results.
title: Injecting user models and time into precision via Markov chains

context: Despite the growth of the Web, user bases, and query traffic, current research lacks in quantifying the performance and quality gains that can be achieved by distributed search engines based on geographical partitioning of a central Web index.
key_idea: The paper proposes various cost models to evaluate the performance benefits of a geographically distributed search engine architecture based on partial index replication and query forwarding.
method: The authors focus on performance gains in query processing and Web crawling processes in a distributed environment, and examine whether improved response time can be used to enhance search relevance. They also evaluate if distributed Web crawling leads to better Web coverage and enhances search quality. The claim is validated through simulations on large, real-life datasets.
outcome: The findings show that response time gain achieved by distributed query processing can be utilized to improve search relevance, and distributed Web crawling can lead to better Web coverage.
future_impact: The application of this study can help enable the use of complex but more accurate algorithms for document ranking in distributed search engine architectures.
title: Quantifying performance and quality gains in distributed web search engines

context: Query expansion, either as pseudo-relevance feedback or relevance feedback, is widely used for enhancing retrieval performance. However, most of the previous approaches overlooked the role of features and the significance of modelling term dependencies.
key_idea: The authors propose a robust query expansion technique called 'latent concept expansion', which is based on the Markov random field model for information retrieval. This technique allows for modeling term dependencies during the expansion phase.
method: The new technique is evaluated against relevance models, an existing advanced language modeling query expansion technique. The comparative evaluation is performed across multiple TREC datasets.
outcome: The proposed model shows consistent and significant improvements in retrieval performance across several TREC datasets.
future_impact: Besides boosting retrieval effectiveness, the proposed technique can also aid in generating meaningful multi-term concepts, which is useful for tasks such as query suggestion or reformulation.
title: Latent concept expansion using markov random fields

context: Despite significant improvements in Web search over the last decade, finding required answers for many user needs is still a challenge, as they can be spread across multiple documents or may not exist on the Web. Yet, many of these needs could be addressed by leveraging Community Question Answering (CQA) services, such as Baidu Knows, Quora, or Yahoo! Answers.
key_idea: The authors carry out a large-scale analysis of how searchers on a major web search engine turn into askers by posting questions on a popular CQA site when their web search fails to yield satisfactory results.
method: The study involves analyzing search engine logs, tracing the transformation of numerous unsuccessful searches into questions posted on a CQA site. The analysis focuses on query characteristics, search behavior patterns preceding the posting of a question, the relationship between the attempted searches and the posted questions, and the subsequent actions the users took on the CQA site.
outcome: This research provides novel insights into searcher intent and behavior regarding the transition to posing questions to a community, when web search fails.
future_impact: The findings of this paper provide a foundation for more effectively integrating automated web search and social information seeking in the future.
title: When web search fails, searchers become askers: understanding the transition

context: Previous studies involving information retrieval have not fully considered the cognitive abilities of end-users.
key_idea: The authors studied the effects of various cognitive abilities on the performance of university students searching for references using a standard computerized index.
method: The cognitive abilities of fifty university students were assessed using eight tests from the Kit of Factor-Referenced Cognitive Tests, and then they were asked to search for references using a standard computerized index. The performance in the searches was analysed using various measures, and effects for demographic characteristics and knowledge were also considered.
outcome: It was found that perceptual speed affected the quality of searches, and logical reasoning, verbal comprehension, and spatial scanning abilities influenced search tactics.
future_impact: This finding suggests that information retrieval systems could be improved to accommodate users with different levels of cognitive abilities, which can assist users to scan lists of terms, choose appropriate vocabulary for searching, and select useful references.
title: Cognitive differences in end user searching of a CD-ROM index

context: In the training of large-scale recommender systems with dynamic sparse features, conventional distributed training frameworks are plagued by high communication costs and slow convergence due to the need to transmit large sparse weights across the network.
key_idea: The authors propose Distributed Equivalent Substitution (DES) training, which implements fully synchronous training in large-scale recommendation systems for the first time and reduces communication overhead by substitifying weight-rich operators with computationally equivalent sub-operators, and aggregating partial results instead of transmitting huge sparse weights directly.
method: The DES system was applied to multiple popular Deep Learning Recommendation Models (DLRMs) and its performance compared with state-of-the-art PS-based training frameworks in terms of communication efficiency and throughput.
outcome: Experiments demonstrated that DES training outperforms the state-of-the-art PS-based training framework, achieving up to 68.7% communication savings and delivering higher throughput compared to other PS-based recommender systems.
future_impact: The DES training framework will likely streamline the training of commercial recommender systems, enabling them to converge faster and achieve better click-through rates.
title: Distributed Equivalent Substitution Training for Large-Scale Recommender  Systems

context: Collecting, organizing and utilizing language specific resources from the Web is a challenging task, especially for minority languages.
key_idea: The authors propose CorpusBuilder, an automatic method for generating Web-search queries to collect documents in a minority language. It uses an automatic language classifier to label retrieved documents, and a subset of these documents is used to generate new queries.
method: The authors experiment with various query-generation methods and query-lengths to find inclusion/exclusion terms and use the odds-ratio scores calculated over the documents acquired so far to generate queries. They also substitute initial documents with a handful of words elicited from a user to compare the performance.
outcome: Using odds-ratio scores calculated over the documents acquired so far was found to be one of the most consistently accurate query-generation methods. The authors also found that the performance of the system is similar even when they use a handful of words elicited from a user instead of initial documents.
future_impact: The generalizability of the proposed system to multiple languages suggests its potential to aid in processing and performing tasks in various language contexts.
title: Automatic web search query generation to create minority language corpora

context: Search engines typically present results in ranked lists, but due to the unprecedented scale of the Web and diversity of search results, this approach has become increasingly inadequate. Clustering, or dividing search results into topic-coherent clusters, is seen as a promising alternative.
key_idea: The authors propose ClusteringWiki, the first prototype and framework for personalized clustering that allows users to directly edit clustering results for a more personalized presentation of search results.
method: The authors developed ClusteringWiki with a Wiki interface, enabling users to edit and annotate the membership, structure and labels of clusters for personalized presentations.
outcome: The authors did not provide specific quantitative outcomes in the abstract.
future_impact: The authors suggest that users' edits and annotations can be shared among users to collaboratively improve the organization of search results and overall utility of search engines.
title: ClusteringWiki: personalized and collaborative clustering of search results

context: Query-Focused Summarization (QFS) aims to extract essential information from long documents and organize it into a summary that can answer a query. Transformer-based summarization models in QFS have been widely used, but they can't directly use the relationships between distant words and information from a query.
key_idea: The proposed QSG Transformer is a novel QFS model leveraging structure information on Query-attentive Semantic Graph (QSG) to address the issue of distant word and query information utilization.
method: A query-attentive graph attention network is proposed for QSG node representation advancement, dispersing the query node's information into QSG using Personalized PageRank, which is then used to generate a more accurate summary. The proposed method is evaluated on two QFS datasets.
outcome: The QSG Transformer model demonstrates superior performance over the state-of-the-art models on the two evaluated QFS datasets.
future_impact: This new transformer model could potentially enhance the quality of the Query-Focused Summarization task by onboarding the structure information of Query-attentive Semantic Graph.
title: QSG Transformer: Transformer with Query-Attentive Semantic Graph for Query-Focused Summarization

context: The problem of finding nearest neighbors to a query in a document collection is a special case of associative retrieval, in which searches are performed using more than one key. Existing solutions involve sequential search and clustered search, with the latter failing to guarantee the retrieval of the absolute nearest neighbors.
key_idea: The paper proposes a novel associative retrieval algorithm suitable for document retrieval using similarity matching. The algorithm operates based on a binary tree structure, where the selection of the most promising branch is determined by testing a set of keys (concepts) at each node.
method: The paper evaluates the proposed retrieval algorithm using a series of experiments with a small collection and compares the results with those from sequential search and clustered search algorithms.
outcome: The results show that under certain conditions, the proposed algorithm achieves a search time of log2N * k, where N is the number of documents and k is a system-dependent parameter (approximated as 4 in this context). The average search time of this algorithm for large collections is less than that of a sequential search but greater than that of a clustered search.
future_impact: The proposed algorithm could be utilized and further optimized for nearest neighbor searching in document retrieval systems, offering a balance between search time and result accuracy.
title: A tree algorithm for nearest neighbor searching in document retrieval systems

context: On social media, users send millions of microblogs on varied topics and predicting which topics a user will join in the future can provide insights into prospective popular topics and the types of users they may attract.
key_idea: This study introduces a novel deep convolutional neural network with external neural memory and attention mechanism to predict whether a user will join a topic based on their posting history.
method: The authors use the proposed deep convolutional neural network to model user posting history and topics with an external neural memory architecture. Relations between users and topics are constructed using convolutional neural network based matching methods, and decisions are made based on these matching results. The method is trained and tested using a large-scale Twitter dataset.
outcome: The experimental results show that the proposed method outperforms other methods, achieving an 18.2% improvement in F1-score and 28.9% improvement in MAP@10 compared to state-of-the-art deep neural networks.
future_impact: The proposed method for predicting the topic engagement of users could potentially inform interest prediction applications, and help in the identification of rising popular topics on social media.
title: Predicting Which Topics You Will Join in the Future on Social Media

context: Graphic processors are high-parallel, high-performance shared-memory architectures originally designed for graphical problems. While these architectures are being broadly repurposed to solve a range of issues, sorting is a key but challenging problem in computer science that still can benefit from novel technologies.
key_idea: The authors present a new fast sorting algorithm implementing an efficient bitonic sorting network that is highly suitable for information retrieval applications.
method: The authors design their algorithm to exploit graphic processors as co-processors, using a memory-efficient data access pattern to limit unecessary memory access. They introduce an efficient instruction dispatch mechanism to improve overall sorting speed while also presenting a cache-based computational model for graphics processors.
outcome: Experimental results show marked improvements over both previous CPU-based methods and GPU-based sorting algorithms, indicating faster sorting speed.
future_impact: While not explicitly mentioned, it can be inferred that the proposed method can potentially improve the efficiency of information retrieval applications and other use cases reliant on quick sorting of large volumes of data.
title: Sorting using BItonic netwoRk wIth CUDA

context: Most research in full-text information retrieval focuses on automated and semi-automated methods of query expansion to improve the effectiveness of user queries. However, constraints in the computer troubleshooting domain, where user queries are short and contain a mix of natural language terms with technical sublanguages terminology, present unique challenges.
key_idea: The authors consider the specific challenges of computer troubleshooting and propose using several heuristic techniques for domain knowledge acquisition that exploit both query log data and corpus analysis.
method: The authors discuss and design heuristic techniques for domain knowledge acquisition by exploiting query log data and corpus analysis in the computer troubleshooting domain.
outcome: The paper identifies the necessity of domain-specific adaptation of full-text information retrieval system, and concludes that conventional devices for more purely “natural language” domains may be inadequate for computer troubleshooting.
future_impact: The study emphasizes the need for implementing domain-specific adaptations to improve query expansion tools and document indexing, offering potential directions for future research in improving full-text information retrieval system.
title: Adapting a full-text information retrieval system to the computer troubleshooting domain

context: LinkedIn is the world's largest professional network where one of the primary activities is people search. The role network distance plays in search behavior wasn't previously clear.
key_idea: This paper unveils insights about people search behavior on LinkedIn, particularly the role that network distance plays in name searches and non-name searches.
method: The study conducts a log analysis and a user study to examine the role of network distance in LinkedIn search behavior.
outcome: For name searches, users primarily click on one of the results, and closer network distances lead to higher click-through rates. As for non-name searches, users are likely to click on multiple results that are not in their existing connections, but with whom they have shared connections.
future_impact: The revelation that network distance plays a significant role in LinkedIn search engagement, albeit varying with the type of search query, could guide the development of improved search algorithms for social and professional networks.
title: The role of network distance in linkedin people search

context: Learning to rank for document retrieval can be evaluated with performance measures such as MAP and NDCG, which existing methods only loosely related to due to their focus on minimizing loss functions on instance pairs.
key_idea: AdaRank has been proposed as a boosting algorithm to address this issue; it is designed to minimize a loss function directly defined on the performance measures.
method: AdaRank constructs 'weak rankers' repeatedly based on reweighted training data and finally linearly combines the weak rankers to make ranking predictions. Experiments were performed on four benchmark datasets to compare AdaRank's performance with baseline methods such as BM25, Ranking SVM, and RankBoost.
outcome: AdaRank significantly outperforms baseline methods of BM25, Ranking SVM, and RankBoost on tested benchmark datasets.
future_impact: The AdaRank learning algorithm could potentially help improve document retrieval by better optimizing performance measures during the training process.
title: AdaRank: a boosting algorithm for information retrieval

context: Information Retrieval (IR) practitioners involved in TREC-like campaigns have to use multiple different software tools and scripts for tasks like building test collections, evaluating systems, or analysing results from empirical experiments, often needing to implement their own ad-hoc scripts.
