method: The paper explores the usage of CRFs for extraction of formulaic metadata from the title page and free text fields from the body text of the articles, but does not provide specifics of the dataset or experimental setup.
outcome: The preliminary results show an acceptable level of performance for formulaic metadata extraction and high precision for those found in the free text.
future_impact: Automated extraction of such information can benefit readers by allowing deep semantic search of articles and aid policy makers and sociologists in tracking macro level trends in research.
title: Extracting Formulaic and Free Text Clinical Research Articles Metadata using Conditional Random Fields

context: Facial expressions are a key nonverbal communication cue and they can provide useful feedback in conversations, including in human-robot interaction. However, interpreting these expressions in the context of success or failure feedback has been a challenge, especially in comparison to human recognition performance.
key_idea: The key idea of this paper is evaluating three standard pattern recognition techniques -- active appearance models, gabor energy filters, and raw images -- for facial feedback interpretation in terms of valence (success and failure), and comparing these results with human performance.
method: The authors conducted an evaluation using a database that contains videos of people interacting with a robot by teaching it the names of several objects. The robot's task was to identify the objects correctly and the researchers assessed the subjects' spontaneous facial expressions in response to the robot's answers.
outcome: Their results showed that an automatic classification of facial expressions in terms of valence using standard pattern recognition techniques is possible, with an accuracy that is comparable to the average human classification rate. However, there was a high variance between different subjects, similar to human performance.
future_impact: The results point to the potential of using standard pattern recognition techniques in interpreting facial feedback, which could be applied in enhancing human-robot interactions or other applications that involve automatic recognition and response based on facial cues.
title: Facial expressions as feedback cue in human-robot interaction—a comparison between human and automatic recognition performances

context: Background detection is a common problem in computer vision and has traditionally used models that simply record each pixel's historical background values.
key_idea: This paper presents a new background detection algorithm that not only records each pixel's historical background values, but also estimates the efficacy of these values based on occurrence statistics, allowing for selective adaptation to background changes with different timescales and minimizing the generation of ghosts.
method: The authors carried out evaluations of their proposed algorithm using the ChangeDetection.net database.
outcome: The results show that the proposed algorithm outperforms most earlier state-of-the-art algorithms not only in terms of accuracy, but also in terms of processing speed.
future_impact: The algorithm, with its ability to quickly adapt to different timescales and minimize ghosts, could shape future approaches to pixel-level adapting background detection.
title: A Fast Self-Tuning Background Subtraction Algorithm

context: Detecting and tracking multiple moving targets from airborne videos and audio data are crucial, but require complex architecture and computations often beyond the capabilities of a single machine.
key_idea: This paper introduces a Cloud-based Audio-Video (CAV) fusion system. This system innovatively combines a user-based voice-to-text color feature descriptor track matching with automated hue feature extraction from image pixels.
method: The authors developed a method that employs Cloud computing to allow for real-time performance. The method involves testing with the tracking of multiple moving targets using airborne videos and assessing frame rate, detection, tracking, and classification performance under realistic conditions.
outcome: The results demonstrate that the CAV approach provides improved frame rate, enhanced detection, real-time tracking, and classification performance under realistic conditions, compared to a single machine workflow.
future_impact: The CAV system is general-purpose, potentially allowing for the detection and tracking of different valuable targets' movement and suspicious behavior recognition through multi-intelligence data fusion.
title: A cloud infrastructure for target detection and tracking using audio and video fusion

context: Prior work has not been able to estimate a human's anthropometric measurements and pose from a single image simultaneously.
key_idea: The novel approach of the study is the four-step technique that combines feature selection, statistical human body information, joint limit constraints, and optimization to estimate anthropometry and pose from an image.
method: The authors select image points as projections of selected landmarks and generate plausible length estimates. They then generate plausible poses using geometric methods and perform optimization under certain constraints. They apply this method to both synthetic and real input data.
outcome: The results showcase the accuracy, advantages, and limitations of the novel method in estimating anthropometry and pose from a single image.
future_impact: The study opens up the ability to estimate both anthropometry and pose from a single image, which may have broad applications in fields reliant on image-based human body analysis.
title: Estimating anthropometry and pose from a single image

context: Vision and sound are basic sources through which humans understand the world and there is no existing method to generate sound given visual input.
key_idea: This work introduces the task of generating sound based on visual input. This could be used for creating sounds in virtual reality or providing additional accessibility for people with visual impairments.
method: The authors apply learning-based methods to generate raw waveform samples given input video frames and evaluate on a dataset of videos containing a variety of sounds.
outcome: The experiments demonstrate that the generated sounds are fairly realistic and have good temporal synchronization with the visual inputs.
future_impact: This research could lead to applications in virtual reality where sound is automatically generated for virtual scenes. Also, it could be used to provide additional accessibility to images or videos for people with visual impairments.
title: Visual to Sound: Generating Natural Sound for Videos in the Wild

context: This paper reviews a second challenge on spectral reconstruction from RGB images which involves the recovery of whole-scene hyperspectral (HS) information from a 3-channel RGB image. There has been a previous challenge in this area.
key_idea: The challenge provides two tracks - a 'Clean' track, which involves estimation of hyperspectral images from noise-free RGBs, and a 'Real World' track, which involves recovery of hyperspectral images from noisy JPEG-compressed RGB images.
method: The challenge uses a natural hyperspectral image dataset containing a total of 510 HS images. The Clean and Real World tracks had 103 and 78 registered participants respectively, with 14 teams competing in the final testing phase.
outcome: The paper does not detail specific outcomes, only mentioning that the challenge scores of proposed methods were evaluated and a state-of-the-art gauge in spectral reconstruction from an RGB image was established.
future_impact: The creation of new benchmarks for spectral reconstruction from RGB images, and insights from the challenge can lead to improved methods in this field.
title: NTIRE 2020 Challenge on Spectral Reconstruction from an RGB Image

context: Matching and registration of shapes is a crucial area within Computer Vision, Pattern Recognition, and Medical Image Analysis.
key_idea: The paper presents a shape representation framework that is based on Gaussian curvature and Markov random fields (MRFs) for shape matching.
method: The method projects a surface mesh model in R3 into a two-dimensional space, modeling it as an extended boundary closed Markov random field. Correspondence between two surface meshes is then established by performing probabilistic inference on the MRF via Gibbs sampling.
outcome: The technique successfully combines geometric, topological, and probabilistic information, producing an effective representation for shapes in three dimensional space.
future_impact: The representation is generalizable to higher dimensional spaces and can be utilized for shape matching, registration, and statistical shape analysis in future studies.
title: An MRF and Gaussian Curvature Based Shape Representation for Shape Matching

context: Large detection datasets often have a 'long tail' of lowshot classes with very few bounding box annotations. There is a need for more effective detection for lowshot classes, ideally that can leverage weakly labelled web-scale datasets that only have image-level labels.
key_idea: The authors propose a modification to the FRCNN model that can automatically infer label assignment for object proposals from weakly labelled images during training. This label assignment is posed as a Linear Program with constraints on the number and overlap of object instances in an image.
method: The authors compare their proposed model to training with just a few annotated examples, and examine the effect of the amount of weakly labelled and fully labelled data needed to train the detection model. They test their model on the Low Visibility (LVIS) dataset and different lowshot variants of the COCO dataset.
outcome: Their framework significantly improves performance when augmenting with weakly labelled examples. It achieves a 3.5 gain in average precision (AP) on the LVIS dataset, outperforming self-supervised baselines like omni-supervision for lowshot classes.
future_impact: This work introduces a detection framework for lowshot classes using weakly labelled web-scale data, leading to potential improvements in object detection, especially for lowshot classes with limited bounding box annotated images.
title: DLWL: Improving Detection for Lowshot Classes With Weakly Labelled Data

context: Temporal Action Localization (TAL) has progressed significantly under the supervised learning paradigm, but current methods function under the closed set assumption, which is inadequate for dealing with unknown actions in open-world scenarios.
key_idea: The paper introduces the Open Set TAL (OSTAL) problem and proposes a general framework, OpenTAL, based on Evidential Deep Learning (EDL) which can manage uncertainty-aware action classification, actionness prediction, and temporal location regression.
method: The framework, OpenTAL, is developed using an importance-balanced EDL method for learning classification uncertainty and it also incorporates positive-unlabeled learning for actionness. The classification uncertainty is further calibrated with guidance from the temporal localization quality.
outcome: Experiments on THUMOS14 and ActivityNet1.3 benchmarks demonstrate the effectiveness of the OpenTAL method.
future_impact: OpenTAL is designed to be a general framework that can equip existing TAL models for tackling open set scenarios, potentially broadening their applicability and utility.
title: OpenTAL: Towards Open Set Temporal Action Localization

context: Calibrating a small field of view central perspective non-frontal camera is a difficult task. Existing techniques suffer from over-parameterization issues, needing heuristic initialisation of a few calibration parameters, and have limitations in handling arbitrary lens-sensor tilt. Approaches based on rotation parameterization of sensor non-frontalness/tilt suffer from these drawbacks and approaches based on decentering distortion modeling can only handle small tilts and cannot explicitly estimate the sensor tilt.
key_idea: The paper proposes a new rotation based non-frontal camera calibration method that focuses on improving the limits of existing techniques. It includes a generalized pupil-centric imaging model for arbitrary axis lens-sensor tilt and an analytical solution that estimates calibration parameters, including sensor rotation angles and pupil-centric parameters.
method: The authors present an analytical technique and computational calibration parameter estimates. They initialize non-linear calibration optimization for a set of synthetic and real data captured from a non-frontal camera.
outcome: The proposed method shows reduced pixel re-projection and undistortion errors compared to state of the art techniques in rotation and decentering based approaches to non-frontal camera calibration.
future_impact: The successful implementation of this method has the potential to improve non-frontal camera calibration processes significantly, reducing errors and handling arbitrary lens-sensor tilt.
title: Generalized Pupil-centric Imaging and Analytical Calibration for a Non-frontal Camera

context: Browsing activities is important for various applications and consumes a large amount of viewing time for longer videos, making summarization of these videos crucial.
key_idea: The authors propose a method for the selection of salient activities in longer videos based on the motion of feature points, where the saliency of a frame is dependent on the total motion and specified time for summarization, and the motion information is modeled as a Gaussian mixture model (GMM).
method: The proposed method utilizes GMM to model the motion information in a video in order to estimate key motion frames. The salient frames are then detected based on the strength of the motion and user-specified time, contributing to the summarization whilst keeping the chronology of activities.
outcome: Applications of the proposed method in the summarization of surveillance videos, movies, TV serials etc. are demonstrated and yield comparable results with the stroboscopic approach and maintaining an average retention ratio of 95%.
future_impact: The proposed method could have a wide impact on applications that require browsing activities in long-duration videos, from surveillance use-cases to entertainment like TV serials and movies.
title: Time driven video summarization using GMM

context: Existing visual grounding (VG) methods that align the correct regions of an image with a natural language query about the image are constrained by a single-stage process, with performance depending on the density and quality of candidate regions. They also lack the ability to optimize located regions continuously.
key_idea: The paper proposes a new approach to the VG challenge that models the process as a progressively optimized visual semantic alignment operation. They introduce a new model, Multi-modal Dynamic Graph Transformer (M-DGT), that builds upon a dynamic graph structure with regions as nodes and their semantic relations as edges.
method: The M-DGT makes sustainable adjustments to the nodes and edges of the graph based on multi-modal information and the graph feature. This approach efficiently shrinks the graph to approach ground truth regions. The model's performance was tested on the Flickr30k Entities and RefCOCO datasets.
outcome: Experiments show that M-DGT achieves superior results over existing state-of-the-art methods using an average of 48 boxes as initialization, it outperforms existing methods in terms of both accuracy and Intersect over Union (IOU) scores. Notably, incorporating M-DGT to optimize the predicted regions of existing methods improved their performance even further.
future_impact: The model may pave the way for future advancements in visual grounding and related areas of computer vision and natural language processing, and impact the performance of existing models when used for optimization.
title: Multi-Modal Dynamic Graph Transformer for Visual Grounding

context: Contrastive learning for unsupervised visual representation learning has traditionally relied on static dictionaries, which may not facilitate efficient learning due to their static nature.
key_idea: The paper introduces Momentum Contrast (MoCo) for unsupervised visual representation learning that uses a dynamic dictionary with a queue and a moving-averaged encoder to enable efficient contrastive unsupervised learning.
method: The authors tested MoCo under the common linear protocol on ImageNet classification, and on several downstream detection/segmentation tasks on the PASCAL VOC, COCO, and other datasets.
outcome: MoCo provided competitive results on ImageNet classification and outperformed supervised pre-training in 7 detection/segmentation tasks on various datasets, sometimes by large margins.
future_impact: These findings suggest that the gap between unsupervised and supervised representation learning has been largely closed in many visual tasks, paving the way for more effective and efficient unsupervised learning in future.
title: Momentum Contrast for Unsupervised Visual Representation Learning

context: The digitization of printed documents is commonplace due to technological advancements, but it comes with an increased risk of fraudulent and criminal activities due to the ease of manipulation of these digital scans.
key_idea: The authors propose a source identification method for scanned documents that utilizes local tetra patterns to capture unique, device-specific signatures from images of the printed documents.
method: The proposed method uses all characters to train a single classifier, reducing the amount of training data required. The method is tested for font size independence on an existing scanner dataset and for font shape independence on a smartphone dataset of comparable size.
outcome: The authors indicated the proposed method depicts font size independence when tested on an existing scanner dataset and a novel step towards font shape independence when tested on a smartphone dataset.
future_impact: The suggested method can provide critical information for investigation agencies and help in building secure communication systems, helping to combat fraudulent and criminal activities.
title: Source Classification Using Document Images from Smartphones and Flatbed Scanners

context: The currently available optical flow datasets are restricted in size and not diverse enough, this limits the testing of performance of methods on non-photorealistic images.
key_idea: The team presents the Creative Flow+ Dataset, a diverse multi-style artistic video dataset which is richly labeled with various parameters such as per-pixel optical flow, occlusions, correspondences, segmentation labels, normals, and depth, aimed at testing optical flow methods on non-photorealistic images.
method: The dataset includes 3000 animated sequences rendered using styles randomly selected from 40 textured line styles and 38 shading styles, spanning the range between flat cartoon fill and wildly sketchy shading.
outcome: The Creative Flow+ dataset poses a new challenge in generalizing real-world Computer Vision techniques to stylized content. Learning-based optical flow methods have been shown to fail to generalize to this data and struggle to compete with classical approaches.
future_impact: This dataset can stimulate new research in the area of learning-based optical flow methods and their application to stylized data. Additionally, they release the complete dataset creation pipeline, allowing the community to generate and stylize their own data on demand.
title: Creative Flow+ Dataset

context: Mobile food recognition systems require sending images to a server for recognition, which can result in delays and potential privacy concerns.
key_idea: The authors propose a real-time mobile food recognition system, conducted on a smartphone, that estimates both the calorie and nutritious content of the food, as well as records the user's eating habits. This is used to recognize food items within user-indicated bounding boxes.
method: For food recognition, the system segments each food item region by using GrabCut, then extracts a color histogram and SURF-based bag-of-features, and classifies it into one of fifty food categories using linear SVM and fast 2 kernel. Also, a system was implemented as an Android smartphone application leveraging multiple CPU cores for real-time recognition.
outcome: The proposed system achieved an 81.55% classification rate for the top five category candidates when the ground-truth bounding boxes were present. User study indicated positive evaluation over food recording systems without object recognition.
future_impact: This real-time mobile food recognition system has the potential to further enhance nutritional tracking by combining easy to use interface with efficient food recognition mechanisms and calorie estimation.
title: Real-Time Mobile Food Recognition System

context: Computer vision algorithms often make mistakes in human-centric applications, and some errors are more frustrating for users than others. An annoyance or cost matrix that quantifies the frustration of each type of mistake is not readily accessible.
key_idea: The authors propose an approach to predict the annoyance created by unseen mistakes by learning from example mistakes and their relative annoyance. This approach involves the use of attribute-based representations to transfer the knowledge of annoyance.
method: The authors tested this approach on faces and scenes, comparing this method with different baselines and applying it to a real-world image retrieval application.
outcome: The experimental results confirmed that the proposed approach can predict annoyance more accurately than baselines and results in less annoying mistakes in a real-world image retrieval application.
future_impact: This new approach can aid in designing computer vision algorithms that minimize user annoyance, particularly handy for a wide spectrum of human-centric applications where annoyance is closely linked to human perception.
title: Predicting User Annoyance Using Visual Attributes

context: In visual surveillance, event rules are often manually defined for trajectory analysis, which involves analysing patterns of moving objects. This manual rule definition poses challenges in terms of scalability, efficiency and human effort.
key_idea: The paper proposes a generic rule induction framework based on trajectory series analysis to automate the learning of event rules. It involves mapping trajectories into primitive events and using a minimum description length principle based grammar induction algorithm to infer meaningful rules.
method: The authors carry out experiments in a traffic crossroad scenario to validate the effectiveness of the proposed method.
outcome: Experimental results show that the grammar rules obtained by the proposed algorithm are consistent with the actual traffic events in the crossroad. Additionally, the algorithm is capable of correctly learning the traffic lights rule in the crossroad by eliminating irrelevant trajectories.
future_impact: This study introduces an automatic event rule learning method that can reduce human effort, improve scalability and efficiency in visual surveillance systems that are reliant on trajectory analysis.
title: Trajectory Series Analysis based Event Rule Induction for Visual Surveillance

context: Handheld projectors are a new type of display modality that provide a larger display area than handheld devices with fixed screens, but they are not tied to a physical screen or a fixed projection area.
key_idea: The authors review a prototype handheld projector and introduce interaction using a cursor that can be tracked across the projection, aiming to support web-browsing applications and explore potential novel applications not available with a physical screen or a fixed projection.
method: The authors present their prototype handheld projector and discuss its interaction design. They also show examples of potential applications, illustrating both conventional uses such as web browsing, and novel uses that interact with the physical world.
outcome: The authors successfully demonstrate that their handheld projector can be used for typical applications, like web-browsing, and potentially novel applications that provide a more natural interaction with the physical world.
future_impact: The introduction of handheld projector and its interaction method may inspire new types of applications that aren't possible with regular screens or fixed projections, creating more natural ways to interact with the digital world.
title: Handheld Projectors for Mixing Physical and Digital Textures

context: Existing domain adaptation methods aim at learning features that can be generalized among domains, often requiring an update to the source classifier to adapt to the target domain and struggling to properly balance performance between source and target domains.
key_idea: Instead of training a classifier to adapt to the target domain, the study proposes using a separable component called a data calibrator to help the fixed source classifier recover discrimination power in the target domain, whilst preserving the source domain's performance.
method: The proposed method is evaluated in situations where the difference between two domains is small, and in cases where it is larger, it leverages synthetic images generated by GANs.
outcome: When domain differences are small, the source classifier's representation performs well in the target domain, outperforming GAN-based methods in digits. For larger domain differences, the proposed method boosts performance and hits state-of-the-art performance in digits datasets and driving scene semantic segmentation.
future_impact: Empirical results from this study reveal that certain intriguing hints, which can be mitigated by adversarial attack to domain discriminators, are sources of performance degradation under domain shift, and possibly providing a new research direction to alleviate this impact.
title: Light-weight Calibrator: a Separable Component for Unsupervised Domain  Adaptation

context: Detecting and tracking multiple people in spaces such as stores is a necessary component of effective surveillance in shopping environments. However, identifying and grouping individuals who are part of a shopping group and monitoring specific activities, such as transactions at a checkout, within these environments remain challenging.
key_idea: The authors present a monocular real-time computer vision system capable of identifying shopping groups by accurately detecting and tracking multiple individuals as they wait in line at a checkout or service counter area.
method: The proposed system segments each frame into foreground regions containing multiple individuals, leveraging temporal segmentation of foreground and motion cues to further segment these regions into individual persons. An appearance model based on color and edge density is used to track each person's movements, then analysing interbody distances to group people into shopping groups. The system also monitors the activities of the cashier to determine when shopping transactions start and end.
outcome: The system successfully demonstrated real-time tracking and group detection, illustrating its robust performance.
future_impact: The proposed system holds potential for delivering improved surveillance in shopping environments, thereby leading to enhanced monitoring and management of such retail spaces.
title: Detection and tracking of shopping groups in stores

context: Domain generalization algorithms are designed to use data from multiple domains to learn models that generalize well to unseen domains. Current evaluation methods cannot effectively expose the impact of various factors contributing to the lackluster performance of existing algorithms.
key_idea: The authors propose an evaluation framework that decomposes the error into components capturing distinct generalization aspects. This work specifically focuses on assessing domain-invariant representation learning and identifying potential failure modes.
method: The proposed evaluation framework is used to assess the performance of different domain generalization algorithms on Colored MNIST and Camelyon-17 datasets.
outcome: The authors found that the most significant contributor to generalization error could change depending on method, dataset, regularization strength, and training length. On Colored MNIST, domain generalization algorithms failed because they reached domain-invariance only on the training domains, while on Camelyon-17, domain-invariance degraded the quality of representations on unseen domains.
future_impact: This study hints towards shifting the focus to tuning the classifier on top of a rich representation as a potentially promising direction in domain generalization.
title: Failure Modes of Domain Generalization Algorithms.

context: The performance of local appearance-based face recognition schemes can be affected by various factors, but the effects of feature selection and feature normalization have not been assessed thoroughly in past research.
key_idea: The paper investigates how feature selection and feature normalization are affecting the performance of a local appearance-based face recognition schema which uses local features extracted using block-based discrete cosine transform.
method: Three different feature sets are extracted from local vectors and then normalized in two ways: making them unit norm and dividing each coefficient by its standard deviation learned from the training set. The processed test face images are classified using four different distance measures: L1 norm, L2 norm, cosine angle, and covariance between feature vectors, on the AR and CMU PIE face databases.
outcome: The experiments demonstrated the importance of using appropriate feature sets and properly normalizing the feature vector in order to enhance the performance of appearance-based face recognition schemes.
future_impact: The findings could guide the development of more effective face recognition schemes that take into account the critical factors of feature selection and normalization.
title: Analysis of Local Appearance-Based Face Recognition: Effects of Feature Selection and Feature Normalization

context: The Naive Bayes Nearest Neighbor (NBNN) is an image classification algorithm, but its accuracy and scalability to large numbers of object classes can be improved.
key_idea: The authors propose an improvement to the NBNN algorithm, termed Local Naive Bayes Nearest Neighbor (Local NBNN), which maintains all of the reference data in one search structure and bases posterior probability estimates on the local neighborhood of a descriptor, thereby ignoring distant classes.
method: The authors tested their algorithm, comparing it to the original NBNN as well as other spatial pyramid methods, using datasets like Caltech 256.
outcome: The Local NBNN provided a 100 times speed-up over the original NBNN on the Caltech 256 dataset and outperformed all previous NBNN-based methods and the original spatial pyramid model. However, it did not outperform state-of-the-art spatial pyramid methods that use local soft assignment and max-pooling.
future_impact: While not explicitly mentioned in the abstract, an implied future impact could be revisions to the Local NBNN algorithm to potentially outperform state-of-the-art spatial pyramid methods using local soft assignment and max-pooling.
title: Local Naive Bayes Nearest Neighbor for image classification

context: Existing video co-segmentation methods struggle to separate complex foregrounds and backgrounds using low-level feature representations.
key_idea: The authors introduce a category-independent object proposal based video co-segmentation method called ObMiC, which can extract multiple foreground objects in a video set, overcoming the limitations of separating foregrounds and backgrounds using low-level representations.
method: The authors formulate object-based co-segmentation as a co-selection graph, favoring regions with foreground-like characteristics, while accounting for intra-video and inter-video foreground coherence. To handle multiple foreground objects, they propose a multi-state selection graph model (MSG) that optimizes the segmentations of different objects jointly.
outcome: Experiments demonstrate that the object-based multiple foreground video co-segmentation method (ObMiC) compares favorably with related techniques on both single and multiple foreground cases.
future_impact: The proposed MSG model could potentially be applied to standard graph models to turn them into a multi-state selection solution optimizable by existing energy minimization techniques.
title: Object-Based Multiple Foreground Video Co-segmentation

context: Existing models for image segmentation struggle with fitting diverse region shapes and are sensitive to initial shape and position.
key_idea: The authors propose fully 3D active surface models for image segmentation that are capable of fitting a diverse range of region shapes and have low sensitivity to initial shape and position. The models are designed with self-inflation/deflation forces that permit the active surface to travel long distances without any external forces.
method: The proposed models are tested using synthetic and real images, taking into account accuracy, robustness to image noise and imperfect image data, and the ability to converge to the correct boundary even with incorrect initial estimates.
outcome: The proposed models demonstrated accurate segmentation in tests with synthetic and real images, with results indicating they are robust to noise and imperfect data and can converge to the correct boundary, even when the initial estimate is off.
future_impact: The authors anticipate that the proposed models, with their robustness and versatile fitting capabilities, can significantly improve image segmentation tasks with a wide range of region shapes.
title: Fully 3D active surface models with self-inflation and self-deflation forces

context: Current action recognition techniques have achieved great success on public benchmarks, but their performance in real-world applications requiring fine-grained action understanding, such as sport analysis, is unsatisfactory.
key_idea: The authors propose the FineGym dataset developed from gymnastic videos to take action recognition to a new level. Unlike existing datasets, FineGym provides temporal annotations at both action and sub-action levels with a three-level semantic hierarchy.
method: The authors use the FineGym dataset to systematically investigate representative methods of action recognition.
outcome: Investigation on the FineGym dataset results in a number of interesting findings, though specific details are not provided in the abstract.
future_impact: The authors hope that the FineGym dataset could advance research towards action understanding.
title: Finegym: A Hierarchical Video Dataset For Fine-Grained Action Understanding

context: The problem of semantic segmentation based on RGB-D data, focusing on cluttered indoor scenes containing many visual categories and instances, is a challenging task. The effectiveness of automatic descriptors obtained using deep learning on this problem is still in question.
key_idea: The authors propose a method combining a generalization of parametric max flow figure-ground proposal methodology using intensity and depth information, new region description methods with second-order pooling, and a search-based structured prediction inference and learning process that can resolve conflicts in overlapping spatial partitions.
method: The proposed method was extensively evaluated on the challenging NYU Depth Dataset V2, extended for the RMRC 2013 and RMRC 2014 Indoor Segmentation Challenges, and a scene classification benchmark. Different descriptors, both pre-designed and automatically obtained using deep learning, were used in the experiments.
outcome: The proposed model ranks first in the RMRC 2014 Indoor Segmentation Challenges. With second-order and deep learning features combined, there can be over a 15% relative accuracy improvement. The method further improves the state of the art by 24% on a scene classification benchmark.
future_impact: The proposed parametric figureground intensity and depth-constrained proposal process and the principled search-based structured prediction inference and learning process have the potential for advancing semantic segmentation based on RGB-D data.
title: Second-order constrained parametric proposals and sequential search-based structured prediction for semantic segmentation in RGB-D images

context: Image style transfer is an underdetermined problem with large number of potential solutions, and most current methods cannot produce diverse outputs. Recently, diversity losses were introduced to train feed-forward networks that can produce diverse outputs, but these still face issues.
key_idea: The authors propose a new method for diversified style transfer by incorporating the whitening and coloring transforms (WCT) with a novel deep feature perturbation (DFP) process. The DFP uses an orthogonal random noise matrix to perturb the deep image features while keeping the original style information intact.
method: The authors perform experiments to test the proposed method and its ability to increase diversity in style transfer outcomes. The method is also evaluated in user studies, where users assess the results obtained through diversified approaches based on the new method.
outcome: The results of the experiments indicate that the new method enhances the diversity while maintaining the quality of stylization. User studies also reveal that users find results obtained using the new method more satisfying.
future_impact: The authors anticipate that this learning-free method, which can be easily integrated into existing WCT-based methods, will make these current methods more capable of generating diverse results.
title: Diversified Arbitrary Style Transfer via Deep Feature Perturbation

context: Computerized sketch-face recognition is a crucial tool for law enforcement and has been intensively studied in recent years. The problem is that the existing CUFS face-sketch dataset is not realistic as the sketches are drawn while looking at the photograph to be matched later, leading to nearly perfect results and obscuring the true challenges of the task.
key_idea: This study poses doubts about the validity of the popular CUFS face-sketch dataset and introduces an off-the-shelf face recognition system with simple shape and edge features for photo-sketch and sketch-photo matching without requiring training data.
method: The authors compare the performance of their system to existing state-of-the-art approaches examining how different features (such as the hair region) contribute to recognition rates.
outcome: The authors find that their off-the-shelf system outperforms more sophisticated methods, even without using training data, achieving a recognition rate of 85.22% using only the hair region.
future_impact: The authors suggest that the existing dataset in this field is not appropriate for research and needs to be replaced with a more realistic one to further advance sketch-face recognition.
title: Data insufficiency in sketch versus photo face recognition

context: Synthesizing complex images from text descriptions using existing models often results in poor quality synthesized images.
key_idea: The authors propose the Object-driven Attentive Generative Adversarial Networks (Obj-GANs), which allow attention-driven, multi-stage refinement for synthesizing complex images from text descriptions.
method: The authors implement the Obj-GAN with a novel object-driven attentive generative network and an object-wise discriminator based on the Fast R-CNN model. They then test its performance using the large-scale MS-COCO benchmark.
outcome: The proposed Obj-GAN significantly outperforms the previous state of the art in various metrics, increasing the inception score by 27% and decreasing the FID score by 11% on the MS-COCO benchmark.
future_impact: The insights provided through a comparison between the classic grid attention and the new object-driven attention could shed light on how future models may generate complex scenes with higher quality.
title: Object-Driven Text-To-Image Synthesis via Adversarial Training

context: The problem of reconstructing an image from a bag of square, non-overlapping image patches, the jigsaw puzzle problem, is challenging even for humans and is known to be NP-complete. Prior approaches treated this problem as a constraint satisfaction problem.
key_idea: This paper proposes a departure from previous methods by developing a graphical model where each patch location is a node and each patch is a label at nodes in the graph. This model requires a pairwise compatibility term, which measures an affinity between two neighboring patches, and a local evidence term.
method: The paper discusses ways to obtain these terms for the jigsaw puzzle problem, evaluates several patch compatibility metrics, compares two forms of local evidence for the graphical model and estimates low resolution images from bags of patches.
outcome: It is demonstrated that the dissimilarity-based compatibility gives the best results. It is shown that sparse-and-accurate evidence, fixing as few as 4 – 6 patches at their correct locations, is enough to reconstruct images consisting of over 400 patches, which is reportedly the largest puzzle solved in the literature to date. Additionally, coarse estimation of the low resolution image from a bag of patches is made possible.
future_impact: The work may pave the way for further innovations in image reconstruction by suggesting that a bag of image patches encodes some geometric information about the original image.
title: A probabilistic image jigsaw puzzle solver

context: Current methods for learning visual categories depend on a large amount of labeled data and can face severe difficulties when the number of labeled examples is limited.
key_idea: The paper proposes a method for learning representations from large amounts of unlabeled images which have associated captions with the aim to improve future image classification tasks.
method: The effectiveness of the proposed method was evaluated and compared to a fully-supervised baseline model, a model that does not utilize the captions and learns a visual representation by performing PCA on the unlabeled images alone, and a model that uses the output of word classifiers trained using captions and unlabeled data.
outcome: The experiments show that the proposed method significantly outperforms the fully-supervised baseline model, the model that ignores the captions, and the model that uses the output of word classifiers trained on captions and unlabeled data.
future_impact: The study opens up the opportunity to use other types of meta-data for learning visual representations besides captions.
title: Learning Visual Representations using Images with Captions

context: Correctly matching feature points in a pair of images is an important preprocessing step for many computer vision applications, which usually requires explicitly computing them.
key_idea: The authors propose an innovative method to estimate the number of correct feature matches and the overlapping region between images without explicitly computing them. This method leverages the spatial order of the features as projected onto the image's x-axis, transforming the match analysis into a permutation analysis between sequences.
method: The proposal is based on the use of the Kendall distance metric between permutations, along with assumptions on the correct and incorrect matches distribution. This method is validated through its application in otwo scenarios: a new halting condition for RANSAC-based epipolar geometry estimation methods, and discarding spatially unrelated image pairs in the Structure-from-Motion pipeline.
outcome: The experiments with both synthetic and real data demonstrate the proposed method's effectiveness, significantly reducing the running time of the image matching stage in the Structure-from-Motion pipeline by about 99% while preserving approximately 80% of the correctly matched feature points.
future_impact: The proposed method can be applied to other computer vision applications, impacting efficiency in these areas. Furthermore, it may fundamentally shift approaches toward feature matching, as it allows for the calculation of the likelihood that a given match is correct based on its estimated number and the rank of the features within the sequences.
title: Using Spatial Order to Boost the Elimination of Incorrect Feature Matches

context: The problem of pose transfer, i.e., transferring the pose of a given person to a target one, has been previously approached using various generative adversarial networks (GANs). However, maintaining appearance consistency and shape consistency is a challenge.
key_idea: This paper proposes a new GAN composed of a sequence of Pose-Attentional Transfer Blocks that each transfers certain regions it attends to, while producing the person image progressively.
method: The proposed network's efficiency and efficacy are validated both qualitatively and quantitatively on the Market-1501 and DeepFashion datasets, and the generated person images are compared with results from previous studies.
outcome: The generated images possess better appearance consistency and shape consistency with the input images, making them appear more realistic compared to those produced by previous methods. The proposed network also demonstrates the capability to generate training images for person re-identification.
future_impact: The proposed network architecture can be used to generate training images for person re-identification activities, helping to mitigate issues around data insufficiency in this field.
title: Progressive Pose Attention Transfer for Person Image Generation

context: Generative models of 3D human motion are often restricted to a small number of activities and therefore do not generalize well to novel movements or applications. Most work on deep learning for sequence prediction focuses on video and speech, not taking into account the structure of skeletal data.
key_idea: The authors propose a deep learning framework for human motion capture data that learns a generic representation from a large corpus of motion capture data and can generalize well to new and unseen movements.
method: The authors use an encoding-decoding network that learns to predict future 3D poses from the most recent past, then extract a feature representation of human motion. They present and evaluate different network architectures that make different assumptions about time dependencies and limb correlations. The learned features are quantified, used for action classification and the receptive fields of the network units are visualized.
outcome: The proposed method outperforms the recent state of the art in skeletal motion prediction, even those that use action-specific training data. They demonstrate that deep feedforward networks trained from a generic motion capture (mocap) database can be used for feature extraction from human motion data.
future_impact: The learned representation can be used as a foundation for classification and prediction in the application of human motion data.
title: Deep Representation Learning for Human Motion Prediction and Classification

context: The existing approaches for object recognition through the matching of invariant local image features are based on matching to individual training images.
key_idea: This paper presents a new method for combining multiple images of a 3D object into a single model representation, capable of recognizing 3D objects from any viewpoint and generalizing models to non-rigid changes.
method: The authors devise a system to cluster training images into an existing view representation or treat it as a new view based on the geometric accuracy of the match to previous model views. They also develop a new probabilistic model to reduce the false positive matches.
outcome: The proposed system was able to robustly recognize 3D objects in cluttered natural images in sub-second times.
future_impact: The new method could lead to improved robustness in object recognition by combining features acquired under a range of imaging conditions.
title: Local feature view clustering for 3D object recognition

context: In late fusion, each modality is separately processed in a unimodal Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) stream and the scores of each modality are fused at the end. Due to its simplicity, late fusion is the predominant approach in many state-of-the-art multimodal applications.
key_idea: The authors introduce the Multimodal Transfer Module (MMTM), a neural network module that leverages knowledge from multiple modalities in convolutional neural networks and permits slow modality fusion.
method: Using squeeze and excitation operations, the authors use the MMTM to recalibrate the channel-wise features in each CNN stream. This method is tested on four datasets spanning dynamic hand gesture recognition, speech enhancement, and action recognition with RGB and body joints.
outcome: Experimental results show that the proposed framework improves the recognition accuracy of well-known multimodal networks, demonstrating state-of-the-art or competitive performance on the tested datasets.
future_impact: The authors propose that the MMTM could be added among unimodal branches with minimum changes in their network architectures, allowing each branch to be initialized with existing pretrained weights. This implies potential for versatile application in multimodal research.
title: MMTM: Multimodal Transfer Module for CNN Fusion

context: There is a lack of theoretical analysis for characterizing the shadows cast by a point light source in relation to its position to the camera and the complexities of handling unusual camera-light configurations.
key_idea: This paper provides a mathematical characterization of the shadows cast by a point light source considering the epipolar geometry of camera-light pairs and including unusual and convenient camera-light configurations.
method: The developed theory is applied to compute a lower bound on the number of lights needed to extract all depth discontinuities from a general scene using a multiflash camera. Experiments with depth edges computed using two-flash setups, a four-flash setup, and a configuration with a flash at the camera's center of projection are used to illustrate the theory.
outcome: Theoretical analysis successfully provides a characterization of which discontinuities are missed and which are accurately detected by the algorithm. Experimental results validate the theory and its applicability for choosing an optimal light placement.
future_impact: The theoretical groundwork presented will provide a solution for some degenerate cases, and it could potentially be used to guide optimal light placement in the context of multiflash cameras and similar applications.
title: Characterizing the shadow space of camera-light pairs

context: Many computer vision challenges require continuous outputs, but are solved by discrete classification due to its natural containment within a probability n-simplex as defined by the softmax activation function. Regular regression lacks this closed geometry, leading to unstable training and suboptimal local minima.
key_idea: The authors propose a new continuous output method, spherical regression. This leverages the fact that many continuous output problems in computer vision are naturally contained in closed geometric manifolds, such as n-spheres. The authors introduce a spherical exponential mapping on n-spheres at the regression output to obtain well-behaved gradients for stable training.
method: The authors experimented on several computer vision challenges, including viewpoint estimation, surface normal estimation and 3D rotation estimation to validate the spherical regression method.
outcome: The experiments demonstrated the benefits of spherical regression in all tested scenarios - viewpoint estimation, surface normal estimation, and 3D rotation estimation.
future_impact: The spherical regression method, by providing stable training and solving continuous output problems in a geometrically intuitive way, could offer significant improvements to a variety of computer vision tasks.
title: Spherical Regression: Learning Viewpoints, Surface Normals and 3D Rotations on N-Spheres

context: Metrics for evaluating generative models measure the discrepancy between real and generated images. The commonly-used Fréchet Inception Distance (FID) metric, extracts “high-level” features using a deep network from both sets. However, variations induced by low-level preprocessing including image resizing and compression have not been properly investigated.
key_idea: The paper shows that commonly overlooked low-level image processing steps, such as image resizing with a fixed-width prefilter and lossy compression like JPEG, can lead to variations and unforeseen consequences in feature extraction and algorithm performance.
method: The authors investigate the effect of image resizing methods and lossy compression on the performance of generative models and on the FID metric used to evaluate them. They also release a reference implementation to facilitate future comparisons.
outcome: The paper finds that improperly implemented resizing can introduce aliasing artefacts, affecting downstream feature extraction. It also shows that if compression is used on training images, FID scores might actually improve if the generated images are also subsequently compressed.
future_impact: This paper aims to draw attention to the underappreciated role of low-level image processing in generative modeling. By characterizing variations in generative modeling development pipelines and providing recommendations based on signal processing principles, future work can better account for these subtleties and improve comparative analyses.
title: On Aliased Resizing and Surprising Subtleties in GAN Evaluation

context: Cross-country navigation presents significant perception challenges due to the variable terrain.
key_idea: The authors propose an operational perception system for cross-country navigation that transforms laser range data into a Cartesian Elevation Map (CEM), which a detailed vehicle model uses to produce traversability information along selected trajectories.
method: The authors demonstrate their approach by running it on the autonomous land vehicle at Martin Marietta Aerospace Corporation in Denver.
outcome: The authors successfully demonstrated their obstacle detection and avoidance algorithms in both simulated and real-world environments.
future_impact: The authors suggest that enhancements to their current system can be made, but they do not specify what these enhancements may be.
title: An operational perception system for cross-country navigation

context: The status quo in human motion prediction includes models that specialize in either short-term or long-term prediction, usually involving significant computation.
key_idea: The study introduces novel neural temporal models for predicting and synthesizing human motion featuring a two-level processing architecture, easily computable features with derivative information, and a new multi-objective loss function. It also presents a new metric, Normalized Power Spectrum Similarity (NPSS), for evaluating the long-term predictive ability of motion synthesis models.
method: The proposed system was tested for its ability to model long-term motion trajectories. Also, a user study was conducted to compare NPSS's correlation with human evaluation of long-term motion to that of the mean-squared error measure.
outcome: The proposed system demonstrated improved modeling of long-term motion trajectories. The user study found that the NPSS metric correlated more strongly with human evaluation of long-term motion than the mean-squared error measure.
future_impact: The proposed model with the new NPSS metric might set a new standard for evaluating the long-term predictive ability of motion synthesis models.
title: A Neural Temporal Model for Human Motion Prediction

context: The conventional approach to video captioning is to learn from offline-extracted dense video features usually obtained at a fixed frame rate and often trained on image/video understanding tasks without adaptation to video captioning data.
key_idea: The authors propose SwinBERT, an end-to-end transformer-based model for video captioning, which accepts video frame patches directly as inputs and outputs a natural language description. The model uses a video transformer to encode spatial-temporal representations that can adapt to variable lengths of video input without designed for different frame rates. The authors also propose adaptively learning a sparse attention mask to reduce redundancy in consecutive video frames and improve task-specific performance.
method: The authors conducted extensive experiments on five video captioning datasets to test the SwinBERT model and its effectiveness when using a learned sparse attention mask.
outcome: SwinBERT demonstrated significant across-the-board performance improvements over previous methods, often by a large margin. The learned sparse attention masks additionally helped achieve new state-of-the-art results and showed adaptability between different video lengths and datasets.
future_impact: The proposed model and its inherent adaptive learning of a sparse attention mask could redefine the state-of-the-art standard for video captioning tasks, and the masks' adaptability may enhance transfer learning viability across different video lengths and datasets in future applications.
title: SwinBERT: End-to-End Transformers with Sparse Attention for Video Captioning

context: For intelligent transportation systems to operate in complex physical and social environments, they need to understand and learn how humans drive and interact with traffic scenes. However, sufficient real-life data for such learning is lacking.
key_idea: The paper introduces the Honda Research Institute Driving Dataset (HDD), a dataset consisting of 104 hours of real human driving in the San Francisco Bay Area, collected for the purpose of studying driver behavior in real-life environments.
method: An instrumented vehicle equipped with various sensors is used to collect data, which is then analyzed in comparison with other driving datasets. Additionally, the authors introduce a novel annotation methodology for untrimmed data sequences and employ baseline algorithms for driver behavior detection.
outcome: The paper provides a detailed analysis of the HDD dataset in comparison to other driving datasets. The feasibility of using the HDD dataset for studying driver behavior is established via testing baseline algorithms.
future_impact: The provided dataset and the new annotation methodology are expected to stimulate further research in understanding driver behavior from real-world driving situations, contributing to advancements in intelligent transportation systems.
title: Toward Driving Scene Understanding: A Dataset for Learning Driver Behavior and Causal Reasoning

context: The problem of estimating structure and motion from long continuous image sequences has not been effectively addressed in prior research.
key_idea: The authors propose an approach to estimate structure and motion from long continuous image sequences, by applying the expectation maximization algorithm based on an extended Kalman smoother to impose time-continuity of the motion parameters.
method: The authors' solution involves repeatedly estimating the state transition matrix of the dynamic equation and the parameters of noise processes in dynamic and measurement equations for a real image sequence.
outcome: This approach gives maximum likelihood estimates of the motion and structure parameters for a long video-rate image sequence with partially unknown system equation and noise.
future_impact: This research is vital for dealing with long video-rate image sequences with partially unknown system equations and noise.
title: Structure and motion estimation with expectation maximization and extended Kalman smoother for continuous image sequences

context: Sparse coding, which decomposes a vector using a few basis elements, is a common practice in machine learning and image processing. Its effectiveness is largely determined by the basis set or dictionary which is typically learned from specific data. Traditional dictionaries are unstructured flat sets of atoms, with no particular structure connecting the atoms.
key_idea: The proposed idea is to leverage structured dictionaries obtained from an epitome, meaning that the atoms are all patches of a chosen size within this epitome image. This leads to a substantial reduction in the number of parameters that need to be learned, as well as providing sparse image decompositions with shift-invariance properties.
method: The authors introduced a new formulation and an algorithm for learning structured dictionaries associated with epitomes and validated it in the context of image de-noising tasks.
outcome: The proposed method enables a considerable reduction in the number of parameters that need to be learned and allowed to de-noise images effectively.
future_impact: The impact envisioned by the authors is the use of epitomes and the corresponding structured dictionaries in various image processing tasks such as image de-noising.
title: Sparse image representation with epitomes

context: There is a growing interest in understanding document content with novel deep learning architectures. However, document understanding tasks require dense information annotations, which are costly to scale and generalize. Active learning techniques have been proposed to reduce the overall cost of annotation while maintaining the performance of the underlying deep learning model.
key_idea: OPAD, a novel framework using reinforcement policy for active learning in content detection tasks for documents is proposed. This framework learns the acquisition function to pick samples, while also optimizing performance metrics typically associated with the tasks.
method: The OPAD framework is applied to various tasks related to document understanding like layout parsing, object detection and named entity recognition. Additionally, weak labeling scenarios are considered, along with novel rewards to account for class imbalance and user feedback in the annotation interface. Ablation studies for human feedback and class imbalance rewards are presented.
outcome: The proposed OPAD framework showed superior performance for active learning for various tasks related to document understanding. A comparison of annotation times for different approaches is also provided.
future_impact: The OPAD framework can potentially reduce the cost of annotation significantly, while improving the active learning method in document understanding tasks.
title: OPAD: An Optimized Policy-based Active Learning Framework for Document Content Analysis

context: In medical image segmentation, models trained on specific types of images (e.x., MR images) often perform poorly when asked to segment different types of images (e.x., CT images). The cross-modality segmentation problem represents a significant challenge in domain adaptation.
key_idea: The authors propose a dual-normalization model for generalizable cross-modality image segmentation which leverages source-similar and source-dissimilar images augmented through nonlinear transformation in unknown target domains.
method: The proposed method utilizes independent batch normalization layers for separate normalization and a style-based selection scheme to choose the right processing path in the test stage. The approach was validated through experiments on three publicly available datasets: BraTS, Cross-Modality Cardiac, and Abdominal Multi-Organ datasets.
outcome: Experiments on multiple datasets show that this method outperforms other state-of-the-art domain generalization methods in cross-modality image segmentation tasks.
future_impact: This novel dual-normalization model could make significant strides in cross-modality image segmentation, showing vast clinical potential for improving patient care and outcomes.
title: Generalizable Cross-modality Medical Image Segmentation via Style Augmentation and Dual Normalization

context: Recent research is focusing on automatic 3D reconstructions of urban environments from video acquired at street level. These systems record vast amounts of video, requiring a stereo matcher capable of processing data at speeds comparable to the recording frame rate. Urban environments exhibit mostly planar surfaces, often imaged at oblique angles, and pose a challenge for many window-based stereo matchers that perform poorly with slanted surfaces.
key_idea: The authors propose a multi-view plane-sweep-based stereo algorithm that correctly handles slanted surfaces. The designed algorithm identifies the scene's principle plane orientations, estimates depth for each direction, and combines the results of each sweep.
method: The proposed algorithm incorporates priors on the locations of planes in the scene to enhance the quality of reconstruction and reduce computation time, especially for uniform textureless surfaces. The team demonstrate the algorithms efficacy on a variety of scenes.
outcome: The paper shows improved accuracy in handling slanted surfaces by demonstrating the effectiveness of the proposed algorithm in a variety of scenes.
future_impact: The ability to handle slanted surfaces correctly and in real-time could improve 3D reconstruction of urban environments, specifically benefiting applications needing rapid processing of massive video data.
title: Real-Time Plane-Sweeping Stereo with Multiple Sweeping Directions

context: Interacting naturally with a computer-generated display through the use of gestures is a growing field. An issue to this mode of interaction, particularly in unrestricted setups, is tracking the human arm robust in video sequences captured via cameras.
key_idea: This study suggests a new approach integrating a multi-cue based localization scheme with a tracking framework to reliably track the human arm dynamics in unrestricted environments. The cues fused are motion, shape, and color for identifying key image features.
method: The authors test their system using an Extended Kalman Filter, modified to utilize the articulated structure of the arm. They propose an interaction scheme between tracking and localization to improve the estimation process while reducing computational requirements.
outcome: The proposed tracking system shows improved performance, as validated through extensive experiments and simulations.
future_impact: The system proposed in this paper could bring significant improvements in natural human-computer interaction through realistic and efficient gesture recognition in unrestricted environments.
title: Reliable tracking of human arm dynamics by multiple cue integration and constraint fusion

context: Analysis of human eye fixations on natural images revealed that human attention is sparsely distributed and usually deployed to locations with abundant structural information. However, the current framework for modeling saccadic eye movements and visual saliency fails to adequately represent these findings.
key_idea: This study proposes a unified statistical framework inspired by novel observations on human attention distribution for modeling both saccadic eye movements and visual saliency based on Super Gaussian Component (SGC) analysis.
method: The model sequentially obtains SGC using projection pursuit and generates eye-movements by selecting the location with maximum SGC response. Its effectiveness and robustness over state-of-the-arts is demonstrated by carrying out dense experiments on psychological patterns and human eye fixation benchmarks.
outcome: The results demonstrate the superior effectiveness and robustness of the proposed model over existing state-of-the-art techniques in saccadic behavior simulation and stimulation of human eye fixations.
future_impact: The results show promising potential for the use of statistical approaches in human behavior research.
title: What are we looking for: Towards statistical modeling of saccadic eye movements and visual saliency

context: Traditional image search methods rely on the user providing binary relevance feedback, which may not always accurately reflect their preferences or provide an efficient search.
key_idea: A novel feedback mode for image search is introduced, where the user can adjust properties of exemplar images according to their needs. An offline approach is implemented that learns a set of ranking functions, each predicting the relative strength of a nameable attribute ('sportiness', 'furriness', etc.) in an image.
method: The system presents an initial set of reference images at query time, and the user provides relative attribute feedback. This feedback is used to update the relevance function, re-rank the pool of images, and iterate until the top ranked images closely match the user's envisioned target.
outcome: The proposed technique performs well in refining image searches for people, products, and scenes and outperforms binary relevance feedback in terms of search speed and accuracy.
future_impact: The method introduced allows users to 'whittle away' irrelevant portions of the visual feature space and use semantic language to communicate more accurately and efficiently with the search system, thereby improving the precision of search results.
title: WhittleSearch: Image search with relative attribute feedback

context: Recent successes in single image super-resolution (SISR) have been driven by deep convolutional neural networks (CNNs). However, existing CNN-based SISR methods make assumptions about the degradation process of the low-resolution image, leading to poor performance when these assumptions are inaccurate, and they lack scalability to handle multiple degradations.
key_idea: The authors introduce a general framework with a dimensionality stretching strategy that allows a single convolutional super-resolution network to account for the blur kernel and noise level in the SISR degradation process, which enables it to handle various degradations.
method: The authors conduct experiments on synthetic and real low-resolution images using the proposed convolutional super-resolution network that intakes two key factors of the SISR degradation process as input.
outcome: The proposed super-resolution network shows favorable results on multiple degradations and proves to be computationally efficient.
future_impact: The proposed method could provide a highly effective and scalable solution for practical SISR applications.
title: Learning a Single Convolutional Super-Resolution Network for Multiple Degradations

context: The classical problem in computer vision is determining the pose of a calibrated perspective camera given the image projections of three known world points, assuming a central perspective projection, for which up to four pairs of solutions exist.
key_idea: The authors tackle a generalized variant of this problem, which doesn't assume a central perspective projection, instead dealing with rays sampled from the camera in an arbitrary, known fashion, with the task of finding the camera pose making these rays meet three known world points.
method: The authors propose an efficient numerical algorithm, which reduces the problem to finding the intersections between a circle and a ruled quartic surface (corresponding to the up to eight possible solutions), expressed as the roots of an octic polynomial.
outcome: The proposed algorithm has been designed to solve the pose of any type of calibrated camera or camera rig, in the classical case allowing up to four pairs of solutions to be obtained in closed form by exploiting a reflection symmetry that causes the odd order terms of the octic polynomial to vanish.
future_impact: The proposed algorithm is intended to be used in a hypothesize-and-test architecture, expanding its applicability beyond the traditional central perspective projection scenarios.
title: A minimal solution to the generalised 3-point pose problem

context: Existing text detection systems in natural scenes have limitations in accuracy, relying mainly on a single type of feature.
key_idea: The authors propose a novel, data-driven system that incorporates cascaded classification using coarse-to-fine detection of character pixels with convolutional features (Text-Conv), connected component extraction using edge and color features, and a graph-based segmentation of connected components into words (Word-Graph).
method: The authors use the ICDAR 2015 Robust Reading Focused Scene Text dataset to train their system. The detection stages are trained using different definitions for foreground text regions, some based on bounding box intersection, and others on bounding box and pixel intersection.
outcome: The proposed system achieves pixel, character, and word detection f-measures of 93.14%, 90.26% and 86.77% respectively on the ICDAR 2015 Robust Reading Focused Scene Text dataset, outperforming state-of-the-art systems.
future_impact: The proposed approach has the potential to be applied to other detection targets with homogenous color in natural scenes.
title: A Text Detection System for Natural Scenes with Convolutional Feature Learning and Cascaded Classification

context: The problem of recovering motion parameters and point correspondences in computer vision, specifically within nonrigid motion analysis, is an area that has only recently begun to be addressed, despite its wide application potential.
key_idea: A novel method is proposed for estimating motion parameters and point correspondences between surfaces under small nonrigid deformations. The method utilizes the changes in differential geometric properties of a surface undergoing motion.
method: Simulations are performed using nonrigid motion on ellipsoidal data to test the proposed algorithms, with further testing conducted on a sequence of facial range images. The algorithms are also applied to detect abnormalities in cardiac images.
outcome: The simulations demonstrated the effectiveness and accuracy of the proposed algorithms in estimating motion parameters and point correspondences under small nonrigid deformations.
future_impact: The proposed method could see applications in a wide range of areas requiring nonrigid motion analysis, including the detection of abnormalities in cardiac images.
title: Determination of motion parameters and estimation of point correspondences in small nonrigid deformations

context: Face verification methods utilize deep convolutional neural networks (DCNNs) to extract low dimensional, discriminative, and high-level abstracted features. However, the training of DCNNs can be a challenge when there is insufficient training data.
key_idea: A new face verification method is proposed that employs multiple DCNNs and a deep ensemble, trained with triplet-based loss function using sets of reference, positive, and negative images. Each DCNN extracts two types of features from stacked multi-scale convolutional layer blocks, which are combined into a descriptor and used for training using the joint Bayesian learning method and its transfer learning variant.
method: The method is tested on the LFW face dataset, with four different types of networks, and using only 198,018 images. An additional check is performed by combining the proposed method with a high-dimensional LBP-based joint Bayesian method.
outcome: The proposed method, using the joint Bayesian learning and its transfer learning method, achieves an accuracy of 98.33% on the LFW. By augmenting this with the high-dimensional LβP-based joint Bayesian method, the accuracy reached 99.08%.
future_impact: The proposed methodology demonstrates the potential to significantly improve the accuracy of face verification, especially when there is insufficient training data to train DCNNs.
title: Deep Convolutional Neural Network Using Triplets of Faces, Deep Ensemble, and Score-Level Fusion for Face Recognition

context: Deep Metric Learning (DML) methods learn metric spaces but only solve binary class assignments and thus ignore higher-level semantic relations. As a result, these methods often encode incomplete semantic context and misrepresent the semantic relation between classes, impacting the model's ability to generalize.
key_idea: The authors propose a language guidance objective for visual similarity learning. By leveraging language embeddings of expert- and pseudo-classnames, they aim to provide more meaningful language semantics to enhance the semantic consistency of the visual representation space.
method: The authors conduct extensive experiments and ablations to validate their approach of integrating language guidance into deep metric learning.
outcome: Language guidance in Deep Metric Learning results in significant, model-agnostic improvements and achieves competitive and state-of-the-art results on all benchmarks.
future_impact: The use of language guidance for enhancing visual similarity learning opens up new possibilities for improving the contextual representation and generalizability of DML models. Its model-agnostic nature means it can be applied to various DML models for better performance.
title: Integrating Language Guidance into Vision-based Deep Metric Learning

context: The merit of online ensemble learning for classification problems is under exploration, and the importance of variables is usually estimated using batch training methods such as Gini index, ReliefF, and gain ratio.
key_idea: The authors propose an online random forests algorithm that estimates variable importance incrementally based on correlation ranking. They further introduce an 'incremental hill climbing' algorithm, where features are added in a 'forward step (FS)' and removed in a 'backward step (BE)', combined in implementations called CorrFS and CorrBE respectively.
method: The authors test their method using UCI public databases and compare their performance with classifiers constructed from batch training.
outcome: The CorrFS and CorrBE implementations have shown to achieve comparable performance to classifiers constructed from batch training.
future_impact: This online random forests algorithm that uses CorrFS and CorrBE can be used for online ensemble learning for classification problems, providing a new perspective on feature selection approaches in comparison to batch mode methods.
title: Online random forests based on CorrFS and CorrBE

context: Multilinear algebra is a powerful theoretical tool for visual geometry. However, the widespread use of traditional typographical notation often makes its inherent simplicity and conceptual elegance less accessible.
