key_idea: The authors propose to use standard tensor diagrammatic techniques adapted to the specific requirements of visual geometry, in order to provide a simpler and more intuitive understanding of geometric relations, which are represented by circuits that can be manipulated using simple rules.
method: The proposed approach is illustrated through several constructions, including straightforward derivations of the standard multiview relations (Fundamental Matrix, Trifocal and Quadrifocal Tensors), and nearly mechanical procedures for camera extraction.
outcome: The authors show that through the use of tensor diagrammatic techniques, multiview geometric relations can be represented more intuitively and manipulated more easily, enhancing their understanding and ease of use.
future_impact: This new approach in handling multilinear algebra and visual geometry carries the potential to facilitate further research in this field or similar fields that require understanding and manipulation of complex geometric relations.
title: Diagram techniques for multiple view geometry

context: The process of accurate indoor 3D reconstruction involves scene layout estimation and global registration problems. Traditional methods tackle these challenges separately, possibly losing certain inter-dependent information which could be valuable for improving reconstruction results.
key_idea: The paper proposes a novel method that jointly solves scene layout estimation and global registration problems, which works by alternating between layout estimation and layout-based global registration in an iterative fashion.
method: The authors experimentally test their method with both synthetic and real-world datasets. They build scene fragments using KinectFusion, register them through pose graph optimization, extract the scene layout through hierarchical agglomerative clustering and energy-based multi-model fitting, and register all the range data through the global iterative closest point algorithm.
outcome: The authors' method demonstrated successful indoor 3D reconstruction performance, but specific quantitative or qualitative results are not detailed in the abstract.
future_impact: The proposed method could potentially improve the accuracy of indoor 3D reconstruction tasks and inspire integrated approaches in solving inter-dependent problems in computer vision.
title: Joint Layout Estimation and Global Multi-view Registration for Indoor Reconstruction

context: Articulated hand pose estimation is traditionally challenged by noisy data and occlusions. Existing approaches that primarily use synthetic data in training also face performance issues due to discrepancies between realistic and synthetic pose data.
key_idea: This study presents the first semi-supervised transductive algorithm for real-time articulated hand pose estimation, known as Semi-supervised Transductive Regression (STR) forest, which learns the connection between a small labelled realistic dataset and a larger synthetic dataset, and a new data-driven pseudo-kinematic technique is proposed for refining noisy or occluded joints.
method: The authors create the STR forest and use it to learn relationships between datasets. They also implement a pseudo-kinematic technique to refine articulations, specifically targeting noisy and occluded joints.
outcome: Experimental results suggest that the proposed STR forest and pseudo-kinematic technique outperform state-of-the-art approaches for hand pose estimation in terms of accuracy, robustness, and speed. It also effectively deals with noise and occlusions.
future_impact: This work suggests potential for improving real-time articulated hand pose estimation through the use of transductive learning, unlabelled data, and pseudo-kinematic techniques for refining articulations.
title: Real-Time Articulated Hand Pose Estimation Using Semi-supervised Transductive Regression Forests

context: Frame quality deterioration is a challenge in video understanding and to alleviate the information loss due to deteriorated frames, current techniques use complex transformer-based integration modules. However, these models are specifically tailored towards a single task, making it difficult to generalize.
key_idea: This paper introduces a new framework dubbed Spatio-Temporal Prompting Network (STPN) that dynamically adjusts the input features in the backbone network to efficiently extract robust and accurate video features by predicting video prompts that contain spatio-temporal information.
method: The STPN prepends predicted video prompts to the patch embeddings of the current frame as the updated input for video feature extraction. Its robustness and accuracy is validated on three varied video understanding tasks: video object detection, video instance segmentation, and visual object tracking.
outcome: Without making any application-specific modifications, STPN demonstrated state-of-the-art performance on ImageNetVID for video object detection, YouTubeVIS for video instance segmentation, and GOT-10k for visual object tracking.
future_impact: The introduced Spatio-Temporal Prompting Network, being not task-specific, has the potential to be effectively applied to a variety of video-based tasks, simplifying the feature extraction process in video understanding.
title: Spatio-temporal Prompting Network for Robust Video Feature Extraction.

context: Semantic labelling is highly associated with geometry and radiance reconstruction, with similar shapes and appearances more likely to derive from similar classes. However, self-supervised approaches are not applicable to semantics due to the requirement of human-defined labels despite recent advances in implicit neural reconstruction techniques.
key_idea: The authors expand neural radiance fields (NeRF) to jointly encode semantics with appearance and geometry, allowing accurate 2D semantic labels to be obtained using minimal in-place annotations specific to the scene.
method: The authors use the intrinsic multi-view consistency and smoothness of NeRF to allow sparse labels to efficiently propagate. They test this approach in scenarios where labels are either sparse or very noisy in room-scale scenes.
outcome: The novel approach proves advantageous in various applications. These include efficient scene labelling tools, novel semantic view synthesis, label denoising, super-resolution, label interpolation and multi-view semantic label fusion in visual semantic mapping systems.
future_impact: Given its versatility across multiple applications, this approach promises to contribute significantly to the field of semantic labelling and present a variety of future research opportunities in areas requiring efficient and accurate semantic labelling.
title: In-Place Scene Labelling and Understanding with Implicit Scene Representation.

context: While large-scale Deep Neural Networks (DNNs) have proven successful in various computer vision tasks, their high computational intensity presents challenges for deployment on resource-limited systems. Existing low-rank basis approximations of filters have been used to quicken testing without sacrificing performance. However, the effective training of DNNs toward lower-rank space for more efficient DNNs remains an open area of investigation.
key_idea: To address these challenges, the authors propose Force Regularization. This technique enforces filters to coordinate more weight information into a lower-rank space, theoretically and practically demonstrating that standard Low-Rank Approximations (LRAs) can reconstruct filters using much lower bases, resulting in faster DNNs.
method: The authors comprehensively evaluate the effectiveness of their approach in ResNets, AlexNet, and GoogLeNet. They also assess Force Regularization in terms of both the speed of the DNNs and the stability of the fine-tuning process.
outcome: Force Regularization results in ResNets, AlexNet, and GoogLeNet seeing significant speed improvements, for example, a 2× speedup on modern GPUs without accuracy loss and 4:05× speedup on CPU, albeit with minor accuracy degradation. Also, Force Regularization improves the initialization of low-rank DNNs, allowing for faster convergence toward higher accuracy.
future_impact: The lower-rank DNNs obtained through this method can be further sparsified, thereby proving that Force Regularization can be integrated with state-of-the-art sparsity-based acceleration methods, potentially opening up new avenues for future research.
title: Coordinating Filters for Faster Deep Neural Networks

context: In many computer vision applications, modeling and synthesizing image noise is crucial. The traditional additive white Gaussian and heteroscedastic (signal-dependent) noise models offer only a rough approximation of actual sensor noise.
key_idea: The paper introduces Noise Flow, a powerful and precise noise model based on recent normalizing flow architectures. Noise Flow merges basic parametric noise models with the versatility and expressiveness of normalizing flow networks.
method: The authors use a normalizing flow network to create a compact, comprehensive noise model capable of representing multiple cameras and gain factors.
outcome: Noise Flow significantly outperforms existing noise models, improving the likelihood of sampled noise by 52% and providing a 0.42 nats/pixel improvement over the camera-calibrated noise level functions.
future_impact: Noise Flow's first application of deep learning and data-driven noise distributions to go beyond simple parametric models may pave the way for more advanced noise models in the future.
title: Noise Flow: Noise Modeling With Conditional Normalizing Flows

context: Conventional unsupervised feature representation methods assign high similarity to close instance pairs in the feature space, typically causing incorrect pairwise relationships for large neighborhoods because the Euclidean distance doesn't effectively represent true semantic similarity on the feature manifold.
key_idea: The authors propose an instance similarity learning (ISL) method that mines the feature manifold in an unsupervised way, discovering the semantic similarity among instances to gain discriminative representations. Generative Adversarial Networks (GAN) are specifically employed to mine the underlying feature manifold.
method: Generated features are used as proxies to progressively explore the feature manifold, allowing the acquisition of semantic similarity among instances as reliable pseudo supervision. This method's effectiveness is evaluated through extensive experiments on image classification.
outcome: The experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method outperforms the state-of-the-art methods in unsupervised feature representation for image classification.
future_impact: With the code available for use, this work could enable further advancements in developing discriminative feature representations for various unsupervised learning tasks.
title: Instance Similarity Learning for Unsupervised Feature Representation.

context: RANSAC-type robust estimators and their variants have been primarily used for hypothesis verification in two-view geometry but have limitations in efficiency and accuracy, including a high incidence of incorrect models and significant computational overhead.
key_idea: The paper intoduces VSAC, a novel RANSAC-type robust estimator which distinguishes by its unique concept of independent inliers for more effective dominant plane handling and error-free rejection of incorrect models, and its sophisticated local optimization process that runs on average only once.
method: The efficacy, speed, and accuracy performance of VSAC were validated through experiments on four standard datasets: EVD, HPatches, PhotoTourism, and Kusvod2.
outcome: VSAC performed significantly faster than existing estimators, with an average speed of 1-2ms on a CPU, two orders of magnitude faster than MAGSAC++, the most accurate estimator of two-view geometry to date. It also demonstrated near error-free performance with no failures in repeated runs across tested datasets.
future_impact: Notably exhibiting great efficiency and precision, VSAC could provide significant improvements in applications relating to two-view geometry estimations.
title: VSAC - Efficient and Accurate Estimator for H and F.

context: Vision Transformers (ViTs), especially the Fully Attentional Network (FAN), have shown robustness against out-of-distribution scenarios and have achieved state-of-the-art robustness.
key_idea: The authors propose an improved pre-training method for FAN models using a Self-emerging Token Labeling (STL) framework, which includes a two-stage training process. The process first generates semantically meaningful patch token labels using a FAN token labeler, followed by a student model training stage that uses both token labels and original class labels.
method: A FAN model based on FAN-L-Hybrid was trained using the STL framework. The performance of this model was tested on ImageNet-1K, ImageNet-C, and ImageNet-A datasets and compared with the original FAN model. Additionally, the performance of the model was evaluated on downstream tasks such as semantic segmentation.
outcome: With the STL framework, the FAN-L-Hybrid model achieved a new state-of-the-art performance for ImageNet-A, significantly outperforming the original FAN counterpart. The framework also improved performance on downstream tasks such as semantic segmentation, with up to a 1.7 margin compared to the counterpart model.
future_impact: The proposed STL framework could potentially lead to an improvement in the generalization and robustness of Vision Transformers, particularly in out-of-distribution scenarios and semantic segmentation tasks.
title: Fully Attentional Networks with Self-emerging Token Labeling

context: The problem of tracking a face and its facial features in an input video sequence necessitates an effective solution.
key_idea: The authors propose a face and facial feature tracking system using the active appearance algorithm that adapts a wireframe model to the face in each frame.
method: The adaptation parameters derived from the wireframe model are converted to MPEG-4 facial animation parameters in the proposed system.
outcome: The early results of implementing this system are promising.
future_impact: The authors suggest that this work should be continued to aim for creating a real-time model-based coder.
title: Using the active appearance algorithm for face and facial feature tracking

context: Existing methods to generate textual descriptions of videos are typically limited to specific categories of events and actions, and there's a need for automatically describing a wider range of video events.
key_idea: A novel method is proposed comprising of an action classifier and a description generator. The action classifier detects and classifies actions in videos to be used as verbs in descriptions, while the description generator finds the actors and generates sentences based on the verb, subject, and direct and indirect objects.
method: The proposed method exploits the discriminative power of a bag-of-features action detector coupled with the generative power of a rule-based action descriptor. It is then compared against a homogeneous setup with a rule-based action detector and action descriptor.
outcome: The proposed hybrid method, that integrates a discriminative action detector and a generative descriptor, outperforms a homogeneous setup that uses rule-based action detector and descriptor.
future_impact: This work opens up possibilities for generating textual descriptions for a wider range of video content based on detected human actions, resulting in substantial improvements to video explanation, video search, and accessibility applications.
title: Automated textual descriptions for a wide range of video events with 48 human actions

context: Explainable artificial intelligence (XAI) seeks to understand the inner workings of complex deep neural models. However, XAI lacks ground-truth explanations, making its automatic evaluation a challenging task.
key_idea: The authors introduce a novel synthetic vision dataset, FunnyBirds, and corresponding automated evaluation protocols. This dataset facilitates semantically meaningful image interventions, such as the removal of individual object parts.
method: Using their proposed synthetic dataset and protocols, they carry out semantically meaningful image interventions, such as removing specific object parts, and evaluate the explanations of 24 different combinations of neural models and XAI methods.
outcome: Through the use of their tools, the authors demonstrate the strengths and weaknesses of the evaluated methods comprehensively and automatically, marking a significant step forward in the automatic evaluation of XAI methods.
future_impact: This new dataset and accompanying evaluation protocols will facilitate a better understanding of explainability methods on a deep level, potentially leading to improved transparency in machine learning models.
title: FunnyBirds: A Synthetic Vision Dataset for a Part-Based Analysis of   Explainable AI Methods

context: The application of modern deep networks in medical imaging is still rudimentary primarily due to the large size of three-dimensional images, requiring huge convolutional or fully connected layers. The situation worsens when dealing with longitudinal analysis of 3D image volumes through recurrent structures and when a reliability measure, rather than a point estimate of model parameters, is necessary.
key_idea: The authors propose the use of the tensor train decomposition, specifically the 'orthogonal' tensor train, for constructing networks with significantly fewer parameters. This approach allows for effective training of powerful recurrent networks on whole brain image volume sequences.
method: The authors utilize the 'orthogonal' tensor train to express a standard network layer both theoretically and empirically. They test its ability to effectively reconstruct whole brain volumes and compare its performance, in terms of faster convergence and stronger confidence intervals, to the standard tensor train decomposition.
outcome: The 'orthogonal' tensor train demonstrates the ability to effectively reconstruct whole brain volumes, showing faster convergence and stronger confidence intervals than the standard tensor train decomposition.
future_impact: The proposed 'orthogonal' tensor train method can enhance the application of deep learning in medical imaging by enabling effective training of powerful recurrent networks on whole brain image volume sequences. In addition, the method provides a direction for further research on how to handle voluminous data in the realm of scientific applications.
title: Scaling Recurrent Models via Orthogonal Approximations in Tensor Trains

context: Nearest Neighbor (NN) search is important in computer vision algorithms. However, conducting NN search on the immense amount of image data available on the Internet is becoming an issue because the main memory of a single PC becomes insufficient.
key_idea: The authors propose an Approximate Nearest Neighbor (ANN) search on Hard Disk Drive (HDD) in order to handle large amounts of data, based on recently proposed Principal Component Hashing (PCH). In this solution, the hash bins are represented by the leaf nodes of a B+ tree to allow dynamic addition and deletion of data.
method: The authors validate the method through experiments using a standard PC and 10,000 stored images, measuring memory consumption, the first search time including the cold start-up time and successive search times.
outcome: The memory consumption is 42 times smaller, the first search time including the cold start-up time is 4.3 times faster and the mean search time decreases from 7.4 seconds to 0.64 seconds for successive searches. The authors also demonstrate the ability of the algorithm to perform NN search on 1 million image datasets with only 193MB memory consumption.
future_impact: The properties of this algorithm indicate it would be suitable for non-time-critical NN search applications and NN search engines used by web servers, where the search engine starts in response to occasional queries.
title: Approximate nearest neighbor search on HDD

context: Recent years have seen the use of contextual models that exploit maps for various recognition and localization tasks. However, these models could be further improved with additional information.
key_idea: The paper proposes to enhance freely available world maps using aerial images, formulating the problem as inference in a Markov random field parameterized in terms of the location of the road-segment centerlines and their width.
method: The authors use OpenStreetMap for the experiments and the efficiency of their inference method enables them to segment all OSM roads in the entire world in a single day using a small cluster of 10 computers.
outcome: Their approach, which was trained using only 1.5 km2 aerial imagery, was able to produce accurate results across the globe and outperformed the state-of-the-art in two new benchmarks collected by the authors.
future_impact: The enhanced maps produced by this approach can be of high utility in the future for semantic segmentation of ground images, suggesting further applications in related areas.
title: Enhancing Road Maps by Parsing Aerial Images Around the World

context: 2D electrophoresis gel image processing is a widely used and affordable technology in biomedical research. However, there are challenges in the current methods leading to a need for improvements in the final software applications.
key_idea: The authors propose a comprehensive algorithm for gel image registration that covers all the steps, including robust and meaningful detection of spots, improvements on the computation of the distance between spots using shape contexts, and an iterative random sampling process for dealing with spot differences between images.
method: The algorithm for gel image registration is formulated and implemented, following the aforementioned steps, and the results are evaluated in the context of their meaningfulness.
outcome: The proposed algorithm successfully covers all the steps for gel image registration, providing a meaningful detection of spots, improved computation of distances between spots using shape contexts, and an effective iterative random sampling process for handling spot differences across images.
future_impact: The advanced image processing algorithm developed in this study can significantly improve the process of 2D electrophoresis gel image processing, making it easier and more cost-effective for researchers in biomedical sciences, particularly those operating under budget constraints.
title: Processing of 2D Electrophoresis Gels

context: The accuracy of the visual tasks for top-view fisheye cameras is currently limited due to the spatial distortion created by poses of objects
key_idea: The authors propose a Deformable Convolution based on the Poincaré Ball (DCPB), an analogy between the fisheye model and the Poincaré ball, which helps to alleviate the issue of spatial distortion in images.
method: The authors use DCPB to conduct Graph Convolutional Networks (GCN) in the Poincaré ball, calculating the geodesic distances to Poincaré hyperplanes as offsets and modulation scalars. Experiments are conducted using a public dataset called THEODORE.
outcome: The experimental results show that DCPB markedly improves the performance of the neural network and obtains higher accuracy.
future_impact: The efficiency of DCPB demonstrates potential for using temporal information in fisheye videos, possibly informing further research and advances in visual tasks involving distorted images.
title: DCPB: Deformable Convolution based on the Poincaré Ball for Top-view Fisheye Cameras.

context: Camera relocalization, i.e, determining the position and orientation of a camera within a reference frame given an image taken by the camera, has been a challenging problem in computer vision. Existing methods often require scene-specific training, which limits their scalability and ability to generalize to unseen scenes.
key_idea: The authors propose a new deep learning approach for camera relocalization. It involves using a convolutional neural network (CNN) to retrieve similar database images and predict the relative pose between the query and the database images. It then obtains the camera location for the query image via triangulation from two relative translation estimates using a RANSAC based approach.
method: The proposed system was trained using training image pairs. Evaluation of the approach was done using the authors' own dataset and the standard 7 Scenes benchmark.
outcome: The results show that the proposed approach generalizes well to previously unseen scenes and compares favorably to other recent CNN-based methods.
future_impact: This work could improve scalability of camera relocalization methods and their ability to extend to scenes not available during the training of the network. It would be interesting to see further applications of the proposed method in other types of visual localization tasks.
title: Camera Relocalization by Computing Pairwise Relative Poses Using Convolutional Neural Network

context: Falls are a major risk for the elderly, especially those suffering from dementia wherein they are not able to react properly to such emergency situations. Current state-of-the-art fall detection approaches need to be improved.
key_idea: The authors suggest a vision-based approach for fall detection which incorporates 3D data obtained from a Kinect device and fuzzy logic to improve the robustness and effectiveness of detection.
method: The proposed approach is evaluated using 72 video sequences which consist of 40 falls and 32 activities of daily living.
outcome: The proposed method outperforms current state-of-the-art algorithms in terms of fall detection.
future_impact: The study contributes to improving elderly care by providing a more robust and effective automated fall detection system.
title: Robust fall detection by combining 3d data and fuzzy logic

context: Conventionally, the motion of a driving car is highly constrained, and no efficient predictors existed that could 'learn' typical egomotion statistics to support tasks such as feature matching, tracking, and egomotion estimation.
key_idea: The authors propose a powerful predictor that learns the typical egomotion statistics based on the 'ground truth' data from KITTI odometry benchmark sequences and suggests that a coordinated turn motion model with moderate vibrations is realistic.
method: The authors analyze the statistics of the 'ground truth' data in the KITTI odometry benchmark sequences and develop a predictor that reduces uncertainties about relative motion when a new image frame comes in, effectively steering the matching process.
outcome: The proposed predictor significantly reduces uncertainty about the relative motion when a new image frame comes in and can also be used to detect outliers in the temporal sequence of egomotion parameters.
future_impact: Predictors like the one proposed in the study can be used to steer the process of matching from one frame to the next, bringing about a potential revolution in feature matching, tracking, and egomotion estimation.
title: The Statistics of Driving Sequences -- And What We Can Learn from Them

context: Previous work on Structure from Motion (SFM) has investigated parameter uncertainties by imposing gauge constraints on the solution before considering covariance estimation.
key_idea: This paper explores how covariance-based uncertainty can be represented under inherent indeterminacies in SFM, termed gauge freedoms, and examines the effect of selecting a particular gauge on parameter uncertainties.
method: The authors derive a Geometric Equivalence Relationship to enable comparisons of covariances under different parametrizations and gauges based on their geometric uncertainty, and propose a fast method for covariance estimation.
outcome: They demonstrate that gauge choice can dramatically affect parameter uncertainties, but the inherent geometric uncertainty remains the same. They show that the uncertainty of gauge invariants accurately captures the geometric uncertainty of the solution.
future_impact: The findings and methods proposed offer useful measures for evaluating solution uncertainty in SFM, which may guide future research and applications in this field.
title: Uncertainty Modeling for Optimal Structure from Motion

context: Most previous visual recognition systems assume ideal inputs without real-world degradations, such as low resolution, motion blur, and out-of-focus blur. Conventional approach first resorts to blind image restoration and then feeds the restored image into a classifier, leading to defective output due to the ill-posed nature of blind image restoration.
key_idea: This paper presents a joint blind image restoration and recognition method based on the sparse representation prior. It handles the challenging problem of face recognition from low-quality images, where the degradation model is unknown. The method states that the degraded input image, if correctly restored, will have a sparse representation in terms of the training set, indicating the identity of the test image.
method: The proposed algorithm is evaluated by solving the blind image restoration iteratively in pursuit of the sparsest representation for recognition. Extensive experiments are carried out on face datasets under various degradations.
outcome: The joint model demonstrated significant improvements over conventional methods that treat the two tasks - image restoration and recognition, independently.
future_impact: The study indicates that the image restoration task and the recognition task can benefit greatly from each other, which might lead to the development of enhanced visual recognition systems exploiting this interdependence.
title: Close the loop: Joint blind image restoration and recognition with sparse representation prior

context: The effects of errors in estimates of the image center and focal length on pose refinement and other related three-dimensional (3D) inference from two-dimensional (2D) images problems have not been thoroughly explored.
key_idea: The authors examine the effect of incorrect knowledge of the camera center and incorrect estimates of the focal length on the determination of the location of the camera and other 3D inference tasks, and consider the impact of these errors on the pose refinement algorithm.
method: They use experiments with synthetic and real data to evaluate the effect of errors in the estimates of the image center and focal length on pose refinement.
outcome: The study finds that incorrect camera center knowledge does not significantly impact camera location determination for 'small' field of view systems. However, incorrect focal length estimates considerably affect the determination of the z-component of translation in camera coordinates. New points are located to an average accuracy of 1.5 mm and 0.3 ft for the two real image sequences respectively.
future_impact: This study improves understanding of the sensitivity of pose refinement to camera parameter estimation errors, which may motivate future research on improving these estimations or developing methods robust to such errors.
title: Sensitivity of the pose refinement problem to accurate estimation of camera parameters

context: The light transport matrix (LTM) is an instrumental tool in line-of-sight (LOS) imaging. It describes how light interacts with the scene and enables applications such as relighting or separation of illumination components.
key_idea: The authors introduce a framework for estimating the LTM in non-line-of-sight (NLOS) scenarios. The authors couple recent virtual forward light propagation models with the LOS light transport equation and introduce specific illumination functions to overcome the challenging wide-aperture conditions of NLOS setups.
method: The authors design computational projector-camera setups, and use these virtual imaging systems to estimate the transport matrix of hidden scenes.
outcome: The introduced NLOS light transport matrix allows to (re)illuminate specific locations of a hidden scene, and separate direct, first-order indirect, and higher-order indirect illumination of complex cluttered hidden scenes.
future_impact: The proposed technique could extend the applications of NLOS scenarios by enabling the separation of different types of illuminations and enabling relighting of specific scene locations in ways similar to existing line-of-sight techniques.
title: Virtual light transport matrices for non-line-of-sight imaging.

context: High-quality computer vision models typically address the problem of understanding the general distribution of real-world images. However, most cameras observe only a very small fraction of this distribution, creating a possibility for more efficient inference by specializing compact, low-cost models to specific frames observed by a single camera.
key_idea: The paper proposes to use model distillation to specialize accurate, low-cost semantic segmentation models to a target video stream, training the ‘student’ model in an online fashion on the live video.
method: The approach intermittently runs a high-cost 'teacher' model to provide a learning target during student model training. The model performance was compared with solutions based on flow or video object segmentation, and temporal stability with the original teacher model. A new video dataset was produced for evaluating the efficiency of inference over long-running video streams.
outcome: Online model distillation yields semantic segmentation models that closely approximate their Mask R-CNN teacher with 7 to 17 times lower inference runtime cost or 11 to 26 times lower in FLOPs, even when the target video's distribution is non-stationary.
future_impact: The method could improve efficiency in video segmentation tasks because it does not require offline pre-training on the target video stream, and can potentially offer better temporal stability than the original teacher model.
title: Online Model Distillation for Efficient Video Inference

context: Visual categorization problems such as object classification or action recognition traditionally train subwindow classifiers on a large collection of manually annotated examples with masks or bounding boxes. This approach relies on time-consuming human labeling and is limited to very few categories. Also, the human selection of masks introduces potentially suboptimal biases in terms of window size and location.
key_idea: A novel method is proposed for learning a discriminative subwindow classifier from examples annotated with binary labels indicating the presence of an object or action of interest, but not its location. During training, the method simultaneously localizes the instances of the positive class and learns a subwindow SVM to recognize them.
method: The authors present an algorithm that extends this method to the classification of time series by localizing the most discriminative set of temporal segments in the signal. The method is evaluated on several datasets for object and action recognition.
outcome: The proposed method achieves results similar to, and in many cases superior to, those obtained with full supervision on several datasets of object and action recognition.
future_impact: The proposed method presents a new direction in machine learning, with potential implications in visual categorization problems. It could lead to decrease dependence on extensive manual labelling and help to address a wider range of categories.
title: Weakly supervised discriminative localization and classification: a joint learning process

context: Human action can be recognised from a single still image by modelling Human-object interaction (HOI), which infers the mutual spatial structure information between human and object as well as their appearance. Existing approaches are sensitive to large variations of human poses, occlusion, and unsatisfactory detection of small objects, due to the reliance on accurate detection of human and object, and estimation of human pose.
key_idea: A novel exemplar based approach is proposed to overcome the limitation of existing approaches. This approach learns a set of spatial pose-object interaction exemplars, which are density functions that describe how a person is interacting with a manipulated object for different activities spatially in a probabilistic way.
method: The authors create a new framework which includes its proposed exemplar based HOI descriptor and an activity-specific matching model that learns the parameters. They validate this by carrying out experiments on two benchmark activity datasets.
outcome: The proposed exemplar based approach was able to obtain state-of-the-art performance in experiments conducted on two benchmark activity datasets.
future_impact: The new approach to human activity recognition based on Human-object interaction exemplars has the potential to be robust to errors in human/object detection and pose estimation.
title: Recognising Human-Object Interaction via Exemplar Based Modelling

context: Previous methods for autonomous mobile robot navigation involved using images captured by a monocular omnidirectional camera system. These methods, however, have not fully utilized the geometric properties of the images from the camera system.
key_idea: The paper introduces a novel algorithm for circle-marker detection in spherical images captured by an omnidirectional camera system, and leverages the geometrical properties of the images, utilizing them for the positioning and navigation of autonomous mobile robots.
method: The authors develop a voting method for the extraction of images of planar circle markers on a spherical image, using a spatial-quadric detection strategy. They also derive a positioning algorithm based on the assumption of the geometrical configuration of the camera system and the circle markers on the plane on which the robot moves.
outcome: The paper includes numerical examples, both for synthetic and real images, demonstrating the application of the proposed circle-marker detection method and positioning algorithm.
future_impact: The proposed method enabling robot navigation using the circle-detection algorithm, when mounted on a monocular omnidirectional camera system, could facilitate more efficient autonomous mobile robot operations in the future.
title: Circle-Marker Detection Method for Omnidirectional Images and its Application to Robot Positioning

context: In video recognition, the most informative region in each frame is usually a small image patch, which shifts smoothly across frames. However, recognising this informative patch efficiently is a challenging problem.
key_idea: The authors propose a reinforcement learning based approach, AdaFocus, for efficient spatially adaptive video recognition. The model uses a light-weighted ConvNet to process the full video sequence and a recurrent policy network to localize the task-relevant regions.
method: Experiments are conducted on five benchmark datasets, i.e., ActivityNet, FCVID, Mini-Kinetics, Something-Something V1&V2, to evaluate the performance and efficiency of the proposed model.
outcome: The proposed model proves to be significantly more efficient than the competitive baselines.
future_impact: AdaFocus' ability to improve computational efficiency opens up the possibility of its application in real-time video recognition tasks. Additionally, its extendability to consider temporal redundancy may inspire future research on dynamically skipping less valuable frames for video recognition.
title: Adaptive Focus for Efficient Video Recognition.

context: Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) is prevalent, affecting 1.5% of people in the US. The lack of clinical resources for early diagnoses has been a long-lasting issue.
key_idea: The research introduces a novel, data-driven method for diagnosing ASD. This approach combines eye tracking and deep neural networks to analyse differences in eye movement patterns between healthy individuals and those with ASD.
method: The authors apply an image selection method based on Fisher scores for feature learning with the most discriminative contents. They leverage the recent advances in deep neural networks for both prediction and visualization.
outcome: Experimental results show the superior performance of the proposed method in terms of multiple evaluation metrics used in diagnostic tests.
future_impact: The data-driven aspect of this method, which is free of assumptions, could be important for new discoveries in understanding ASD as well as other neurodevelopmental disorders.
title: Learning Visual Attention to Identify People with Autism Spectrum Disorder

context: Deep CNNs have made great progress in image semantic segmentation, but they require numerous densely-annotated images for training and struggle to generalize to unseen object categories. Few-shot segmentation has been developed to perform segmentation from only a few annotated examples.
key_idea: The authors propose a novel prototype alignment network called PANet, which learns class-specific prototype representations from a few support images within an embedding space and then performs segmentation over the query images by matching each pixel to the learned prototypes.
method: The authors approach the few-shot segmentation problem from a metric learning perspective. Their PANet employs non-parametric metric learning to generate high-quality prototypes that are both class representative and discriminative for different classes. They further introduce a prototype alignment regularization between the support and the query in PANet.
outcome: The proposed PANet achieves the mIoU score of 48.1% and 55.7% on PASCAL-5i for 1-shot and 5-shot settings respectively, surpassing the state-of-the-art method by 1.8% and 8.6%.
future_impact: The authors suggest that PANet fully harnesses knowledge from the support and provides better generalization on few-shot segmentation, leading to potential improvements in this field.
title: PANet: Few-Shot Image Semantic Segmentation With Prototype Alignment

context: Deep Neural Networks for 3D point cloud recognition are vulnerable to adversarial examples, making them challenging to defend against due to the diverse ways attackers can generate these adversarial examples such as by adding, shifting, or removing points.
key_idea: The authors propose to establish a comprehensive point cloud adversarial robustness benchmark and propose a hybrid training augmentation method that considers various types of point cloud adversarial examples to adversarial training.
method: The authors conduct extensive and systematic experiments to evaluate adversarial robustness and to identify effective combinations of existing defense tricks in point cloud adversarial defenses.
outcome: By combining these tricks, a more robust defense framework is constructed with an average accuracy of 83.45% against various attacks, demonstrating its capability to enable robust learners.
future_impact: This work establishes a benchmark and proposes a method that could potentially improve robustness against adversarial examples in 3D point cloud recognition.
title: Benchmarking and Analyzing Robust Point Cloud Recognition: Bag of Tricks   for Defending Adversarial Examples

context: Low-cost monocular 3D object detection is crucial in autonomous driving, and yet the accuracy of current solutions is still not satisfactory.
key_idea: The paper proposes the Dynamic Feature Reflecting Network (DFR-Net) for 3D object detection by reformulating the task into sub-tasks of object localization and appearance perception, and leveraging the reciprocal information between these sub-tasks.
method: The DFR-Net comprises two novel modules: (i) the Appearance-Localization Feature Reflecting module (ALFR) that separates task-specific features and reflects the reciprocal features; (ii) the Dynamic Intra-Trading module (DIT) that adaptively adjusts the training processes of various sub-tasks. This method was tested on the KITTI dataset.
outcome: Extensive experiments showed the effectiveness and generalization of DFR-Net, ranking first among all monocular 3D object detectors in the KITTI dataset as of March 16th, 2021.
future_impact: The proposed method is easily integrated into many cutting-edge 3D detection frameworks with little cost to boost performance, therefore it could contribute to advancements in the field of 3D object detection.
title: The Devil is in the Task - Exploiting Reciprocal Appearance-Localization Features for Monocular 3D Object Detection.

context: Anomaly detection in videos is a critical research area with real-world applications. Current video anomaly detection (VAD) methods are constrained due to the lack of large-scale annotated anomaly events and typically focus on learning the distribution of normal samples to spot anomalies. They often rely on auxiliary networks to extract foreground object or action information, yet performance of these methods is significantly affected by the capability of the semantic models used.
key_idea: The authors propose a novel method based on the Diffusion Model (DM) to predict the features of video frames for anomaly detection. The method is designed to learn the distribution of normal samples without the need for any additional high-level semantic feature extraction models.
method: The authors develop two denoising diffusion implicit modules to predict and refine the features: the first module is dedicated to learning feature motion, whilst the latter focuses on feature appearance learning. The performance of the proposed method is then assessed by conducting extensive experiments.
outcome: The proposed method shows significantly improved performance in accurately predicting normal features over non-DM-based feature prediction-based VAD methods and is demonstrated to substantially outperform state-of-the-art competing methods in experiments.
future_impact: The proposed approach, being the first of its kind to use DM for feature prediction in VAD, could drive new advancements in the field of video anomaly detection. More effective and accurate anomaly detection in videos could have wide-reaching implications in real-world applications.
title: Feature Prediction Diffusion Model for Video Anomaly Detection.

context: Human pose estimation (HPE) is integral to scene understanding in numerous safety-critical domains involving human-machine interaction. Many models in this domain often fall prey to overconfidence issues common in deep probabilistic models, presenting the problem of inaccurate prediction.
key_idea: The paper proposes a human pose regression framework to examine the behavior of two established methods for simultaneous aleatoric and epistemic uncertainty estimation: maximum a-posteriori (MAP) estimation with Monte-Carlo variational inference and deep evidential regression (DER). They also introduce additional recalibration step to extract reliable confidence intervals.
method: They evaluate both approaches on the quality of their predicted variances and whether these truly capture the expected model error. They specifically take a closer look at deep evidential regression, which is applied comprehensively for the first time to the HPE problem.
outcome: The experimental results indicate that DER behaves as expected in challenging and adverse conditions, and that the predicted uncertainties match their purported aleatoric and epistemic sources. Notably, DER achieves smooth uncertainty estimates without the need for a costly sampling step.
future_impact: The findings show that DER could be a suitable candidate for uncertainty estimation in resource-limited platforms, thus benefiting the domain of human pose estimation.
title: Plausible Uncertainties for Human Pose Regression.

context: Updating a global 3D model with live RGB-D measurements, such as through a Truncated Signed Distance Function (TSDF) volumetric model and a fusion algorithm, has been successful for 3D reconstruction of indoor scenes. However, this method is expensive in memory, limiting its scalability for large scenes.
key_idea: This paper proposes a new flexible 3D scene representation which uses a set of planes, aiming to decrease memory usage while maintaining accurate reconstruction of indoor scenes from RGB-D image sequences.
method: The authors project the scene onto different planes to reduce the size of the scene representation, and this updated model was tested with sets of RGB-D measurements.
outcome: Experimental results show that the proposed flexible 3D scene representation method achieves accurate reconstruction, while supporting scalability for large indoor scenes.
future_impact: The proposed method's lower memory requirement could allow global textured 3D models to be updated more easily with live RGB-D measurements, possibly impacting the field with its increased capacity for large-scale indoor 3D reconstructions.
title: A Flexible Scene Representation for 3D Reconstruction Using an RGB-D Camera

context: Current deep learning architectures, like Deep CNNs, rely heavily on learnable operators and layers, yet, they may not always provide the best results nor the most efficient use of resources.
key_idea: This study proposes the use of scattering networks as the first layers of a supervised hybrid deep network, with the idea that the early layers don't necessarily need to be learned and can leverage predefined representations.
method: To validate this key idea, the authors experimented with a shallow cascade of 1 × 1 convolutions, and combining scattering networks with a modern ResNet. These networks were tested on large-scale image recognition tasks like the ImageNet ILSVRC2012 dataset, and smaller datasets like subsets of the CIFAR-10 and the STL-10 dataset.
outcome: The hybrid scattering deep networks achieved AlexNet accuracy on ImageNet ILSVRC2012, and a single-crop top 5 error of 11.4% on the same data set, comparable to the ResNet-18 architecture. The hybrid models also demonstrated excellent performance in small sample regimes, surpassing their end-to-end counterparts demonstrated on subsets of the CIFAR-10 dataset and on the STL-10 dataset.
future_impact: This work implies that learning invariance and geometrical priors in the architecture of machine learning models is beneficial and that incorporating scattering networks as predefined first layers in deep learning models could be a promising direction for future performance improvements and resource efficiency.
title: Scaling the Scattering Transform: Deep Hybrid Networks

context: The generation of event models typically requires tedious manual work based on the analysis of visual input such as video frames. Current systems apply traditional machine learning techniques to attain a pseudo-automatic approach.
key_idea: The researchers propose a technique that fully automates the generation of event models using qualitative reasoning and statistical analysis of video input. The technique leverages a tracking program, semantically partitions the view from a fixed camera based on moving objects' paths, and builds event models describing the behaviour of object pairs.
method: The view from a fixed camera is partitioned into semantically relevant regions based on the paths of moving objects. Using a notion of proximity and qualitative spatial reasoning techniques, event models are built using statistical methods. The system has been tested in a traffic domain.
outcome: The automated system was successful in learning various event models, expressed in the qualitative calculus, that represent human observable events. Furthermore, the system is capable of recognizing subsequent selected event occurrences or unusual behaviours.
future_impact: The proposed technique for automatic event model generation based on qualitative reasoning and statistical analysis of video input could be used to automatically recognize subsequent selected event occurrences or unusual behaviours in a variety of domains.
title: Building qualitative event models automatically from visual input

context: Vergence methods in computer vision could not overcome problems created by occlusion and specular highlights, issues that are inherent in the visual process.
key_idea: The authors describe an active exploratory vergence method based on concurrent cross-correlation of multi-scale stereo images, aiming to concurrently detect occlusion and specular highlights during the vergence process.
method: An efficient parallel implementation of the multi-scale cross-correlation algorithm is used in the proposed active exploratory vergence method.
outcome: The proposed method demonstrated its robustness against occlusion and specular highlights.
future_impact: The proposed method's ability to efficiently detect occlusion and specular highlights concurrently during the vergence process could lead to the exploration of a better viewing direction and position in computer vision.
title: Robust vergence with concurrent detection of occlusion and specular highlights

context: The relationship between the appearance of an outdoor scene and the ambient temperature has not been extensively explored until now.
key_idea: The authors identify two interactions between image sequences from outdoor cameras and temperature measurements, namely, semantically meaningful regions such as foliage and reflective oriented surfaces and small camera motions, both being indicative of the temperature.
method: The authors study statistical correlations between image sequences from outdoor cameras and temperature measurements. They propose simple scene-specific temperature prediction algorithms which turn a camera into a crude temperature sensor.
outcome: It was found that simple features like local pixel intensities outperform sophisticated, global features from semantically-trained convolutional neural networks for temperature estimation.
future_impact: The findings and proposed simple scene-specific temperature prediction algorithms can make cameras function as simple temperature sensors, which can have distinct applications in various fields.
title: Hot or Not: Exploring Correlations between Appearance and Temperature

context: Existing architectures for semantic segmentation rely on a single encoder-decoder structure, but can be computationally burdensome and are unable to balance speed and high accuracy efficiently.
key_idea: The authors propose ShelfNet, an architecture with multiple encoder-decoder branch pairs and skip connections at each spatial level. This architecture appears as a shelf with multiple columns and serves as an ensemble of multiple deep and shallow paths, aiming to improve accuracy while reducing computational burden.
method: The authors compared ShelfNet with popular non real-time methods like PSPNet and real-time segmentation models such as BiSeNet, on the PASCAL VOC and Cityscapes datasets.
outcome: ShelfNet demonstrated 4x faster inference speed than PSPNet with similar accuracy on the PASCAL VOC dataset. On the Cityscapes Dataset, the proposed model achieves higher accuracy at similar speed as BiSeNet. Lastly, ShelfNet with ResNet34 backbone achieves 79.0% mIoU on Cityscapes Dataset, outperforming both PSPNet and BiSeNet with larger backbones like ResNet101.
future_impact: With its balance of speed and accuracy, ShelfNet has potential applications in tasks which require speed, such as street-scene understanding for autonomous driving.
title: ShelfNet for Fast Semantic Segmentation

context: Current approaches to the detection and 3D pose estimation of objects in color images rely heavily on extensive training phases and require large datasets, often needing hours or training time and hundreds of registered images for new objects.
key_idea: The authors propose a novel methodology for object detection and 3D pose estimation that eliminates the need for training data for new objects. This method focuses on objects with prominent corners and relies solely on their geometries. It uses object corners of various shapes and predicts their 3D poses using a small set of training images from existing objects.
method: The authors utilize a RANSAC-like algorithm that robustly detects and estimates the object's 3D pose by matching its corners on the CAD model with their detected counterparts in the image. A final check exploiting the full 3D geometry of the objects is also introduced to handle cases where multiple objects have the same corner spatial arrangement.
outcome: The proposed methodology is demonstrated to be effective on the challenging T-LESS dataset.
future_impact: The paper's methodology could be particularly valuable in industrial contexts where there is a constant introduction of new objects and retraining models frequently is not feasible.
title: CorNet: Generic 3D Corners for 6D Pose Estimation of New Objects without Retraining

context: Quantizing deep neural network models for efficient inference on modern deep learning hardware typically leads to either significant performance reduction or increased engineering time spent on training a network to be suitable for quantization.
key_idea: The authors propose a data-free quantization method for deep neural networks that does not require fine-tuning or hyperparameter selection. This is obtained by equalizing the weight ranges in the network using a scale-equivariance property of activation functions and correcting biases in the error introduced during quantization.
method: The authors apply their proposed weight equalization and bias correction method to common computer vision architectures and tasks such as the MobileNet family, semantic segmentation and object detection,
outcome: The proposed method achieves near-original model performance and for common architectures like the MobileNet family, it even achieves state-of-the-art quantized model performance.
future_impact: The introduced method, which improves quantization accuracy performance and can be implemented using a simple API call, can be applied to a wide variety of computer vision architectures and tasks enhancing their efficiency and performance without requiring fine-tuning or hyperparameter selection.
title: Data-Free Quantization Through Weight Equalization and Bias Correction

context: Computing features of closed planar boundaries of 2-D digital images, or closed curves, is a task that has been previously tackled in computational vision research, but still poses challenges.
key_idea: The authors propose a novel method called distance accumulation that computes the distance from a point in the boundary to a chord specified by moving end points.
method: The robustness of the distance accumulation method was tested through experimental results using both simulated and real images.
outcome: The experimental results showed that the distance accumulation method was robust and its analysis was closely matched to planar curvature measurements.
future_impact: The successful implementation and results of the distance accumulation method may lead to further research and improvements in feature extraction from 2-D digital images.
title: Distance accumulation and planar curvature

context: Traditional methods struggle to efficiently track point features experiencing affine deformations and changes in illumination.
key_idea: The authors develop an efficient algorithm for tracking point features that are affected by both affine deformations and changes in illumination, utilizing a combined model of geometry and photometry.
method: They use the combined model of geometry and photometry to track features and detect outliers within a hypothesis testing framework.
outcome: The proposed algorithm can track features in real-time on a personal computer.
future_impact: The authors released their algorithm to the public, implying it could be incorporated into other systems that require real-time feature tracking.
title: Real-time feature tracking and outlier rejection with changes in illumination

context: Existing methods for image content authentication have issues with false positive and false negative probabilities.
key_idea: The authors introduce a hierarchical representation of image structure and utilize it for image content authentication. They achieve this through a Bayesian framework, modelling the image with the Markov pixon random field and defining an undirected graph - Bayesian structural content abstraction (BaSCA).
method: An efficient optimization scheme is implemented to iteratively minimize the distance (or learning error) to all content-identical image samples generated by an acceptable operation set defined by the user. The authors also use the regional pixon map to remove spurious vertices and establish a BaSCA hierarchy.
outcome: Experimental results indicate that the proposed approach has significantly less false positive and a comparable false negative probability compared with existing methods.
future_impact: The proposed representation captures the spatial topology information of homogeneous regions as well as their finest scale and interactions. The development of such a hierarchy can help in improving the robustness of image content authentication.
title: Bayesian structural content abstraction for region-level image authentication

context: Extending state-of-the-art object detectors from image to video is challenging due to issues such as motion blur, video defocus, and rare poses. Existing work attempts to exploit temporal information on the box level, but these methods are not trained end-to-end.
key_idea: This paper presents flow-guided feature aggregation, an accurate and end-to-end learning framework for video object detection that improves the video recognition accuracy by leveraging temporal coherence on the feature level and improving per-frame features by aggregation of nearby features along the motion paths.
method: The authors tested their method on the ImageNet VID dataset, especially on more challenging fast moving objects.
outcome: The flow-guided feature aggregation method significantly improves upon strong single-frame baselines in ImageNet VID, and is on par with the best engineered systems that won the ImageNet VID challenges 2016.
future_impact: The authors plan to release their code, which could enable other researchers to build upon this work and further improve video object detection.
title: Flow-Guided Feature Aggregation for Video Object Detection

context: Traditional Markov random field (MRF) models have limitations in defining field potentials according to local image structure.
key_idea: The study proposes a Steerable Random Field (SRF) where the field potentials are defined based on filter responses that are steered to local image structure, making use of the structure tensor to obtain derivative responses aligned with or orthogonal to the predominant local image structure.
method: Clique potentials are defined over steered filter responses using a Gaussian scale mixture model and are learned from training data. Image denoising and inpainting performance is evaluated to test the effectiveness of the SRF model.
outcome: The study demonstrates that steering the random field to the local image structure improves image denoising and inpainting performance compared with traditional pairwise MRFs.
future_impact: The SRF model provides a statistical motivation for anisotropic regularization and may further advance MRF models and methods in image processing.
title: Steerable Random Fields

context: Subspace clustering of data points from a union of subspaces is a popular research area. Clustering based on the assumption of a nonlinear subspace is more difficult for traditional methods. Autoencoders, due to their capacity to extract nonlinear features, are often used, however, the problem of adding constraints to these features for better effectiveness has not been thoroughly addressed in previous work.
key_idea: The paper proposes a method of adding both global and local structure constraints to features in autoencoders using the low-rank property and Laplace operator, respectively. This method improves the effectiveness of feature extraction.
method: The authors conduct extensive experiments to validate the effectiveness of the proposed model.
outcome: Experiments demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method, although specific results are not stated in the abstract.
future_impact: The approach of placing constraints as per the proposed way could potentially be employed in other deep neural network architectures.
title: Structure-Constrained Feature Extraction by Autoencoders for Subspace Clustering

context: Existing approaches to fusing silhouette information from multiple arbitrary views often involve using 3D constructs such as camera calibration to shape 3D voxels or to project visual cones in 3D space.
key_idea: The paper introduces a purely image-based method that uses planar homographies and foreground likelihood information to perform the fusion of multi-view silhouettes, thus avoiding complex 3D constructs.
method: The team uses planar homographies and foreground likelihoods to form a 2D grid which represents a cross-sectional slice of the object. They then extend this process to planes parallel to a reference plane to obtain the object's other slices. These grids are then stacked on top of each other to create a 3D data structure which encapsulates the object's shape and location, and an energy functional is minimized over the object's surface using a level sets formulation.
outcome: The proposed method successfully generates three-dimensional structures that encapsulate complex object shapes and their locations in cluttered environments containing multiple objects.
future_impact: The image-based approach to fusing multi-view silhouette information can simplify the 3D reconstruction process in complicated environments, making it applicable in fields that require efficient and precise object reconstruction.
title: A Homographic Framework for the Fusion of Multi-view Silhouettes

context: Traditional neural networks only try to find a model with fixed parameters that optimize the average behavior over all inputs, without considering data-specific properties.
key_idea: A meta-level neural network (MLNN) model is proposed. This model uses meta-knowledge learned on data-specific properties of images and dynamically adapts its weights based on the properties of the input images.
method: The MLNN model is validated using over ten network architectures under various application scenarios and loss functions. The authors conduct comparison experiments on low-level and high-level vision applications, specifically image super-resolution, demising, and image classification tasks.
outcome: The MLNN model has demonstrated 0.1-0.3 dB improvements on PSNR in low-level vision applications, while for high-level image classification, it has an accuracy improvement of 0.4-0.6% for Cifar10 and 1.2-2.1% for ImageNet, compared to convolutional NNs.
future_impact: The method is expected to lead to more pronounced improvements as the scale or diversity of data is increased.
title: Supplementary Meta-Learning: Towards a Dynamic Model for Deep Neural Networks

context: While generic face detection and facial landmark localization in static imagery are mature areas in machine learning and computer vision, facial landmark tracking in videos has not received the same attention. Tracking-by-detection frameworks that use face detection and landmark localization in every frame to avoid drifting can't outperform static imagery methods.
key_idea: The authors propose using the results of generic face detection and landmark localization methods to recursively train person-specific face detectors and landmark localizers for offline deformable face tracking.
method: The authors apply the proposed pipeline to track landmarks in challenging long-term sequences captured under arbitrary conditions. The pipeline was tested as a semi-automatic annotation tool on the majority of the videos of the 300-VW Challenge.
outcome: The results from the application of the proposed method on the 300-VW Challenge are not explicitly mentioned.
future_impact: The study introduces a novel method for facial landmark tracking in videos which could impact future developments in this area, though no specific impacts or potential research directions are identified.
title: Offline Deformable Face Tracking in Arbitrary Videos

context: State-of-the-art object detectors heavily rely on pre-trained networks on large-scale classification datasets like Image Net, which incurs learning bias due to the difference on both the loss functions and the category distributions between classification and detection tasks. Transferring pre-trained models from classification to detection between discrepant domains is also challenging.
key_idea: The authors propose the Deeply Supervised Object Detector (DSOD), a framework that can train object detectors from scratch, eliminating the need for pre-trained models. This is achieved through deep supervision enabled by dense layer-wise connections.
method: The authors develop DSOD following the single-shot detection (SSD) framework and conduct experiments on the PASCAL VOC 2007, 2012 and MS COCO datasets.
outcome: The DSOD outperforms SSD on all three benchmarks with real-time detection speed, requiring only half the parameters of SSD and one-tenth the parameters of Faster RCNN.
future_impact: The principles and findings in DSOD could potentially influence future work in object detection tasks, especially in training detectors from scratch and creating more compact models.
title: DSOD: Learning Deeply Supervised Object Detectors from Scratch

context: Human parsing and pose estimation are central for understanding human behaviors. Given their close correlation, employing one model for both tasks can yield substantial benefits. However, harmonizing these tasks in joint learning is difficult as they require different processes - pixel-wise classification for human parsing and regression for pose estimation.
key_idea: Inspired by the Neural Architecture Search's (NAS) capability to automatically allocate efficient feature connections for specific tasks, the authors propose a network architecture, NPPNet, designed to handle both tasks simultaneously.
method: The authors propose to search for encoder-decoder architectures respectively for getting task-specific features and laying the foundation of feature interaction. Further, NAS units are added to multi-scale feature interaction and high-level feature fusion to ensure optimal communication between the tasks. They validate this approach by experimental results on benchmark datasets for parsing and pose estimation.
outcome: The experimental results demonstrate that the proposed model achieves state-of-the-art performance on both human parsing and pose estimation tasks.
future_impact: While not explicitly stated in the abstract, the proposal of this method combining NAS and task-specific features could potentially impact future efforts in jointly tackling related tasks in the field of human behaviour understanding.
title: Neural Architecture Search for Joint Human Parsing and Pose Estimation.

context: Existing methods for reconstructing the 3D surface of an object from depth discontinuities when viewed under orthographic projection don't adequately address gaps in the recovered surface.
key_idea: The authors present a new method for 3-D surface reconstruction of an object using depth discontinuity motion under orthographic projection during rigid rotation on a turntable, along with a novel shape completion scheme to fill in the gaps in the recovered surface.
method: The authors validate the theory by constructing a large-format orthographic multi-flash camera capable of recovering the depth discontinuities using controlled illumination. They also analyze the limitations of multi-flash depth edge detection using orthographic imaging with both point sources and directional illumination.
outcome: This paper identifies and presents a new method for dealing with the problem of reconstructing 3D surfaces and shows through verification the practical functionality of their shape completion scheme and large-format orthographic multi-flash camera.
future_impact: The authors anticipate future applications for the shape completion scheme and the specialized hardware introduced in this work.
title: Shape from depth discontinuities under orthographic projection

context: Active Appearance Models (AAMs) are widely used, although they often involve complex optimization problems and can be computationally prohibitive, limiting their utility.
key_idea: A new framework is proposed to derive well-known optimization problems in AAMs, resulting in two optimization problems for fast and exact AAM fitting, and a new algorithm which can be applied to 3D.
method: After proposing the new optimization problems and algorithm, the authors trained AAMs in-the-wild to investigate its performance relative to other methods, without use of sophisticated shape priors, robust features or robust norms.
outcome: The results show that AAMs perform well in comparison to current state-of-the-art methods in some cases. The proposed algorithms are computationally realizable and particularly fast for most current systems.
future_impact: The proposed algorithm and optimization problems for AAM could become more broadly applied, especially if further improvements are made that can replicate the successes shown in this study.
title: Optimization Problems for Fast AAM Fitting in-the-Wild

context: The existing human mesh recovery problem does not deal with the challenges of generating 3D body meshes from partial observation in 2D clothing images.
key_idea: This study defines and tackles the Cloth2Body problem aiming to generate 3D human body meshes from 2D clothing images. The authors propose an end-to-end framework that can estimate 3D body mesh parameterized by pose and shape.
method: Three specific solutions are provided within the framework to address the challenges in the Cloth2Body problem: 1) Kinematics-aware Pose Estimation for estimating body pose parameters; 2) An Adaptive Depth Trick to align the re-projected 3D mesh with the 2D clothing image; 3) Physics-informed Shape Estimation for estimating body shape parameters. A skeleton transplanting method, Evolution-based pose generation, is designed for diverse pose generation during inference.
outcome: Experimental results on both synthetic and real-world data show that the proposed framework can effectively recover natural and diverse 3D body meshes from 2D images that align well with clothing, achieving state-of-the-art performance.
future_impact: The study addresses an emerging challenge in graphics and computer vision, creating a pathway for future research on 3D mesh generation from 2D images.
title: Cloth2Body: Generating 3D Human Body Mesh from 2D Clothing

context: Prior methods for rigid point set registration often rely on solving systems of second-order ordinary differential equations, which can be computationally expensive and sensitive to parameter choices.
key_idea: The authors propose a new registration method, called Barnes-Hut Rigid Gravitational Approach (BH-RGA), that interprets the input as two interacting particle swarms and directly minimizes the gravitational potential energy of the system using non-linear least squares.
method: The approach accelerates exhaustive particle interactions using a Barnes-Hut tree and handles massive point sets in quasilinear time. The performance of the method is evaluated through systematic experiments on handling incomplete, noisy and perturbed data, and alignment with prior matches.
outcome: The experiments demonstrate that BH-RGA surpasses the performance of baseline methods in terms of the convergence basin and accuracy when handling noisy and incomplete data, and that it compares positively to competing methods for alignment with prior matches.
future_impact: One advantage of BH-RGA is the possibility to define boundary conditions or additional alignment cues by varying point masses, which could allow for more flexible uses in future applications.
title: Accelerated Gravitational Point Set Alignment With Altered Physical Laws

context: With the emergence of Vision-Language Pretraining Models (VLMs), prompt learning has become essential for their fast adaptation to downstream tasks with limited resources. However, existing research mostly focuses on single-prompt paradigms and rarely investigates multi-prompt learning.
key_idea: This paper extends the recent constant modality gap phenomenon to learnable prompts and justifies the superiority of vision-language transfer with multi-prompt augmentation. The authors propose an Energy-based Multi-prompt Learning (EMPL) to generate multiple prompt embeddings by drawing instances from an energy-based distribution, which is implicitly defined by VLMs.
method: The authors conducted comprehensive experiments to justify their claims and evaluate the performance of the proposed EMPL model.
outcome: While the specific results are not mentioned in the abstract, it states that comprehensive experiments have justified their claims and shown the excellence of EMPL.
future_impact: The proposed EMPL method could redefine the conventional single-prompt paradigm, offering a more efficient vision-language transfer with multi-prompt augmentation, leading to better balance between in-domain and out-of-domain open-vocabulary generalization.
title: A Retrospect to Multi-prompt Learning across Vision and Language.
